


                     12
  When I do count the clock that tells the time,
  And see the brave day sunk in hideous night,
  When I behold the violet past prime,
  And sable curls all silvered o'er with white:  
  When lofty trees I see barren of leaves,
  Which erst from heat did canopy the herd
  And summer's green all girded up in sheaves
  Borne on the bier with white and bristly beard:
  Then of thy beauty do I question make
  That thou among the wastes of time must go,
  Since sweets and beauties do themselves forsake,
  And die as fast as they see others grow,
    And nothing 'gainst Time's scythe can make defence
    Save breed to brave him, when he takes thee hence.

  So should that beauty which you hold in lease
  Find no determination, then you were
  Your self again after your self's decease,
  When your sweet issue your sweet form should bear.



                     23
  As an unperfect actor on the stage,
  Who with his fear is put beside his part,
  Or some fierce thing replete with too much rage,
  Whose strength's abundance weakens his own heart;
  So I for fear of trust, forget to say,
  The perfect ceremony of love's rite,
  And in mine own love's strength seem to decay,
  O'ercharged with burthen of mine own love's might:  
  O let my looks be then the eloquence,
  And dumb presagers of my speaking breast,
  Who plead for love, and look for recompense,
  More than that tongue that more hath more expressed.

    Lo thus by day my limbs, by night my mind,
    For thee, and for my self, no quiet find.

  And each (though enemies to either's reign)
  Do in consent shake hands to torture me,
  The one by toil, the other to complain
  How far I toil, still farther off from thee.



                     30
  When to the sessions of sweet silent thought,
  I summon up remembrance of things past,
  I sigh the lack of many a thing I sought,
  And with old woes new wail my dear time's waste:
  Then can I drown an eye (unused to flow)
  For precious friends hid in death's dateless night,
  And weep afresh love's long since cancelled woe,
  And moan th' expense of many a vanished sight.

  Thou art the grave where buried love doth live,
  Hung with the trophies of my lovers gone,
  Who all their parts of me to thee did give,
  That due of many, now is thine alone.

    Their images I loved, I view in thee,
    And thou (all they) hast all the all of me.



                     33
  Full many a glorious morning have I seen,
  Flatter the mountain tops with sovereign eye,
  Kissing with golden face the meadows green;
  Gilding pale streams with heavenly alchemy:
  Anon permit the basest clouds to ride,
  With ugly rack on his celestial face,
  And from the forlorn world his visage hide
  Stealing unseen to west with this disgrace:  
  Even so my sun one early morn did shine,
  With all triumphant splendour on my brow,
  But out alack, he was but one hour mine,
  The region cloud hath masked him from me now.
  
    Ah but those tears are pearl which thy love sheds,
    And they are rich, and ransom all ill deeds.
  
  For whether beauty, birth, or wealth, or wit,
  Or any of these all, or all, or more
  Entitled in thy parts, do crowned sit,
  I make my love engrafted to this store:
  So then I am not lame, poor, nor despised,
  Whilst that this shadow doth such substance give,
  That I in thy abundance am sufficed,
  And by a part of all thy glory live:
    Look what is best, that best I wish in thee,
    This wish I have, then ten times happy me.



                     38
  How can my muse want subject to invent
  While thou dost breathe that pour'st into my verse,
  Thine own sweet argument, too excellent,
  For every vulgar paper to rehearse?
  O give thy self the thanks if aught in me,
  Worthy perusal stand against thy sight,
  For who's so dumb that cannot write to thee,
  When thou thy self dost give invention light?  
  Be thou the tenth Muse, ten times more in worth
  Than those old nine which rhymers invocate,
  And he that calls on thee, let him bring forth
  Eternal numbers to outlive long date.



                     43
  When most I wink then do mine eyes best see,
  For all the day they view things unrespected,
  But when I sleep, in dreams they look on thee,
  And darkly bright, are bright in dark directed.



                     44
  If the dull substance of my flesh were thought,
  Injurious distance should not stop my way,
  For then despite of space I would be brought,
  From limits far remote, where thou dost stay,
  No matter then although my foot did stand
  Upon the farthest earth removed from thee,
  For nimble thought can jump both sea and land,
  As soon as think the place where he would be.

  But ah, thought kills me that I am not thought
  To leap large lengths of miles when thou art gone,
  But that so much of earth and water wrought,
  I must attend, time's leisure with my moan.

    Or if they sleep, thy picture in my sight
    Awakes my heart, to heart's and eye's delight.



                     48
  How careful was I when I took my way,
  Each trifle under truest bars to thrust,
  That to my use it might unused stay
  From hands of falsehood, in sure wards of trust!
  But thou, to whom my jewels trifles are,
  Most worthy comfort, now my greatest grief,
  Thou best of dearest, and mine only care,
  Art left the prey of every vulgar thief.
  
  Thee have I not locked up in any chest,
  Save where thou art not, though I feel thou art,
  Within the gentle closure of my breast,
  From whence at pleasure thou mayst come and part,
    And even thence thou wilt be stol'n I fear,
    For truth proves thievish for a prize so dear.



                     51  
  Thus can my love excuse the slow offence,
  Of my dull bearer, when from thee I speed,
  From where thou art, why should I haste me thence?
  Till I return of posting is no need.



                     52
  So am I as the rich whose blessed key,
  Can bring him to his sweet up-locked treasure,
  The which he will not every hour survey,
  For blunting the fine point of seldom pleasure.



                     57
  Being your slave what should I do but tend,
  Upon the hours, and times of your desire?
  I have no precious time at all to spend;
  Nor services to do till you require.
  
    O sure I am the wits of former days,
    To subjects worse have given admiring praise.

    And yet to times in hope, my verse shall stand
    Praising thy worth, despite his cruel hand.

    Tired with all these, from these would I be gone,
    Save that to die, I leave my love alone.



                     67
  Ah wherefore with infection should he live,
  And with his presence grace impiety,
  That sin by him advantage should achieve,
  And lace it self with his society?  
  Why should false painting imitate his cheek,
  And steal dead seeming of his living hue?
  Why should poor beauty indirectly seek,
  Roses of shadow, since his rose is true?
  Why should he live, now nature bankrupt is,
  Beggared of blood to blush through lively veins,
  For she hath no exchequer now but his,
  And proud of many, lives upon his gains?
    O him she stores, to show what wealth she had,
    In days long since, before these last so bad.

  They look into the beauty of thy mind,
  And that in guess they measure by thy deeds,
  Then churls their thoughts (although their eyes were kind)
  To thy fair flower add the rank smell of weeds:  
    But why thy odour matcheth not thy show,
    The soil is this, that thou dost common grow.

  O if (I say) you look upon this verse,
  When I (perhaps) compounded am with clay,
  Do not so much as my poor name rehearse;
  But let your love even with my life decay.



                     73
  That time of year thou mayst in me behold,
  When yellow leaves, or none, or few do hang
  Upon those boughs which shake against the cold,
  Bare ruined choirs, where late the sweet birds sang.

  In me thou seest the twilight of such day,
  As after sunset fadeth in the west,
  Which by and by black night doth take away,
  Death's second self that seals up all in rest.



                     79
  Whilst I alone did call upon thy aid,
  My verse alone had all thy gentle grace,
  But now my gracious numbers are decayed,
  And my sick muse doth give an other place.

    Then if he thrive and I be cast away,
    The worst was this, my love was my decay.

  And do so love, yet when they have devised,
  What strained touches rhetoric can lend,
  Thou truly fair, wert truly sympathized,
  In true plain words, by thy true-telling friend.



                     83
  I never saw that you did painting need,
  And therefore to your fair no painting set,
  I found (or thought I found) you did exceed,
  That barren tender of a poet's debt:
  And therefore have I slept in your report,
  That you your self being extant well might show,
  How far a modern quill doth come too short,
  Speaking of worth, what worth in you doth grow.

  Hearing you praised, I say 'tis so, 'tis true,
  And to the most of praise add something more,
  But that is in my thought, whose love to you
  (Though words come hindmost) holds his rank before,
    Then others, for the breath of words respect,
    Me for my dumb thoughts, speaking in effect.



                     88
  When thou shalt be disposed to set me light,
  And place my merit in the eye of scorn,
  Upon thy side, against my self I'll fight,
  And prove thee virtuous, though thou art forsworn:
  With mine own weakness being best acquainted,
  Upon thy part I can set down a story
  Of faults concealed, wherein I am attainted:
  That thou in losing me, shalt win much glory:  
  And I by this will be a gainer too,
  For bending all my loving thoughts on thee,
  The injuries that to my self I do,
  Doing thee vantage, double-vantage me.

  If thou wilt leave me, do not leave me last,
  When other petty griefs have done their spite,
  But in the onset come, so shall I taste
  At first the very worst of fortune's might.

  And every humour hath his adjunct pleasure,
  Wherein it finds a joy above the rest,
  But these particulars are not my measure,
  All these I better in one general best.

  Thy love is better than high birth to me,
  Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' costs,
  Of more delight than hawks and horses be:
  And having thee, of all men's pride I boast.



                     96  
  Some say thy fault is youth, some wantonness,
  Some say thy grace is youth and gentle sport,
  Both grace and faults are loved of more and less:
  Thou mak'st faults graces, that to thee resort:
  As on the finger of a throned queen,
  The basest jewel will be well esteemed:
  So are those errors that in thee are seen,
  To truths translated, and for true things deemed.

  Yet nor the lays of birds, nor the sweet smell
  Of different flowers in odour and in hue,
  Could make me any summer's story tell:
  Or from their proud lap pluck them where they grew:  
  Nor did I wonder at the lily's white,
  Nor praise the deep vermilion in the rose,
  They were but sweet, but figures of delight:
  Drawn after you, you pattern of all those.

    Yet seemed it winter still, and you away,
    As with your shadow I with these did play.

    Then do thy office Muse, I teach thee how,
    To make him seem long hence, as he shows now.



                     102
  My love is strengthened though more weak in seeming,
  I love not less, though less the show appear,
  That love is merchandized, whose rich esteeming,  
  The owner's tongue doth publish every where.

    Therefore like her, I sometime hold my tongue:
    Because I would not dull you with my song.



                     104
  To me fair friend you never can be old,
  For as you were when first your eye I eyed,
  Such seems your beauty still: three winters cold,
  Have from the forests shook three summers' pride,
  Three beauteous springs to yellow autumn turned,
  In process of the seasons have I seen,
  Three April perfumes in three hot Junes burned,
  Since first I saw you fresh which yet are green.

    Fair, kind, and true, have often lived alone.

    Pity me then dear friend, and I assure ye,
    Even that your pity is enough to cure me.



                     112
  Your love and pity doth th' impression fill,
  Which vulgar scandal stamped upon my brow,
  For what care I who calls me well or ill,  
  So you o'er-green my bad, my good allow?
  You are my all the world, and I must strive,
  To know my shames and praises from your tongue,
  None else to me, nor I to none alive,
  That my steeled sense or changes right or wrong.

  Love's not Time's fool, though rosy lips and cheeks
  Within his bending sickle's compass come,
  Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks,
  But bears it out even to the edge of doom:
    If this be error and upon me proved,
    I never writ, nor no man ever loved.



                     117
  Accuse me thus, that I have scanted all,
  Wherein I should your great deserts repay,
  Forgot upon your dearest love to call,  
  Whereto all bonds do tie me day by day,
  That I have frequent been with unknown minds,
  And given to time your own dear-purchased right,
  That I have hoisted sail to all the winds
  Which should transport me farthest from your sight.



                     122
  Thy gift, thy tables, are within my brain
  Full charactered with lasting memory,
  Which shall above that idle rank remain  
  Beyond all date even to eternity.

    Hence, thou suborned informer, a true soul
    When most impeached, stands least in thy control.



                     129
  Th' expense of spirit in a waste of shame
  Is lust in action, and till action, lust
  Is perjured, murd'rous, bloody full of blame,
  Savage, extreme, rude, cruel, not to trust,
  Enjoyed no sooner but despised straight,
  Past reason hunted, and no sooner had
  Past reason hated as a swallowed bait,
  On purpose laid to make the taker mad.

  I love to hear her speak, yet well I know,
  That music hath a far more pleasing sound:
  I grant I never saw a goddess go,
  My mistress when she walks treads on the ground.

  Yet in good faith some say that thee behold,
  Thy face hath not the power to make love groan;
  To say they err, I dare not be so bold,
  Although I swear it to my self alone.

    In nothing art thou black save in thy deeds,
    And thence this slander as I think proceeds.



                     132
  Thine eyes I love, and they as pitying me,
  Knowing thy heart torment me with disdain,
  Have put on black, and loving mourners be,
  Looking with pretty ruth upon my pain.

    Then will I swear beauty herself is black,
    And all they foul that thy complexion lack.
'


                     136
  If thy soul check thee that I come so near,  
  Swear to thy blind soul that I was thy 'Will',
  And will thy soul knows is admitted there,
  Thus far for love, my love-suit sweet fulfil.

  If I might teach thee wit better it were,
  Though not to love, yet love to tell me so,
  As testy sick men when their deaths be near,
  No news but health from their physicians know.

  To win me soon to hell my female evil,
  Tempteth my better angel from my side,
  And would corrupt my saint to be a devil:
  Wooing his purity with her foul pride.



                     150
  O from what power hast thou this powerful might,
  With insufficiency my heart to sway,
  To make me give the lie to my true sight,
  And swear that brightness doth not grace the day?
  Whence hast thou this becoming of things ill,
  That in the very refuse of thy deeds,
  There is such strength and warrantise of skill,
  That in my mind thy worst all best exceeds?
  Who taught thee how to make me love thee more,
  The more I hear and see just cause of hate?
  O though I love what others do abhor,
  With others thou shouldst not abhor my state.



                     151
  Love is too young to know what conscience is,  
  Yet who knows not conscience is born of love?
  Then gentle cheater urge not my amiss,
  Lest guilty of my faults thy sweet self prove.



                     152
  In loving thee thou know'st I am forsworn,
  But thou art twice forsworn to me love swearing,
  In act thy bed-vow broke and new faith torn,
  In vowing new hate after new love bearing:
  But why of two oaths' breach do I accuse thee,  
  When I break twenty? I am perjured most,
  For all my vows are oaths but to misuse thee:
  And all my honest faith in thee is lost.



                     153
  Cupid laid by his brand and fell asleep,
  A maid of Dian's this advantage found,
  And his love-kindling fire did quickly steep
  In a cold valley-fountain of that ground:
  Which borrowed from this holy fire of Love,
  A dateless lively heat still to endure,
  And grew a seeting bath which yet men prove,
  Against strange maladies a sovereign cure:
  But at my mistress' eye Love's brand new-fired,  
  The boy for trial needs would touch my breast,
  I sick withal the help of bath desired,
  And thither hied a sad distempered guest.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.

  BERTRAM.
 What is it, my good lord, the King languishes of?
  LAFEU.
 A fistula, my lord.
 I heard not of it before.
 I would it were not notorious.
 No
    more of this, Helena; go to, no more, lest it be rather thought
    you affect a sorrow than to have-
  HELENA.
 Be thou blest, Bertram, and succeed thy father
    In manners, as in shape! Thy blood and virtue
    Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness
    Share with thy birthright! Love all, trust a few,
    Do wrong to none; be able for thine enemy
    Rather in power than use, and keep thy friend  
    Under thy own life's key; be check'd for silence,
    But never tax'd for speech.

  COUNTESS.
 'Twere all one
    That I should love a bright particular star
    And think to wed it, he is so above me.
 I love him for his sake;
    And yet I know him a notorious liar,
    Think him a great way fool, solely a coward;  
    Yet these fix'd evils sit so fit in him
    That they take place when virtue's steely bones
    Looks bleak i' th' cold wind; withal, full oft we see
    Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.
 Unfold to us some warlike resistance.
 Bless our poor virginity from underminers and blowers-up!
    Is there no military policy how virgins might blow up men?
  PAROLLES.
 Virginity being blown down, man will quicklier be blown  
    up; marry, in blowing him down again, with the breach yourselves
     made, you lose your city.
 That you were made of is metal to make virgins.
 Virginity breeds mites, much like a
    cheese; consumes itself to the very paring, and so dies with
    feeding his own stomach.

    Within ten year it will make itself ten, which is a goodly  
    increase; and the principal itself not much the worse.

    'Tis a commodity will lose the gloss with lying; the longer kept,
    the less worth.
 Now shall he-
    I know not what he shall.
 What one, i' faith?
  HELENA.
      Exit PAGE  
  PAROLLES.

  HELENA.
 Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a charitable star.
 I especially think, under Mars.

  HELENA.

  PAROLLES.

  HELENA.
 I am so full of business I cannot answer thee acutely.
 The Florentines and Senoys are by th' ears;
    Have fought with equal fortune, and continue
    A braving war.
 So 'tis reported, sir.
 We here receive it,
    A certainty, vouch'd from our cousin Austria,
    With caution, that the Florentine will move us
    For speedy aid; wherein our dearest friend
    Prejudicates the business, and would seem
    To have us make denial.

  FIRST LORD.

  SECOND LORD.
 It well may serve
    A nursery to our gentry, who are sick
    For breathing and exploit.
 He lasted long;
    But on us both did haggish age steal on,
    And wore us out of act.

    So like a courtier, contempt nor bitterness
    Were in his pride or sharpness; if they were,
    His equal had awak'd them; and his honour,
    Clock to itself, knew the true minute when
    Exception bid him speak, and at this time
    His tongue obey'd his hand.

  BERTRAM.
 Would I were with him! He would always say-
    Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words
    He scatter'd not in ears, but grafted them
    To grow there, and to bear- 'Let me not live'-
    This his good melancholy oft began,
    On the catastrophe and heel of pastime,
    When it was out-'Let me not live' quoth he
    'After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff
    Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses
    All but new things disdain; whose judgments are
    Mere fathers of their garments; whose constancies
    Expire before their fashions.
 Some six months since, my lord.
                 Exeunt [Flourish]




ACT I.

Rousillon.

  COUNTESS.
 No, madam, 'tis not so well that I am poor, though many of
    the rich are damn'd; but if I may have your ladyship's good will
    to go to the world, Isbel the woman and I will do as we may.
 In Isbel's case and mine own.
 I am driven on by the
    flesh; and he must needs go that the devil drives.
 May the world know them?
  CLOWN.

  COUNTESS.
 I am out o' friends, madam, and I hope to have friends for
    my wife's sake.
 Such friends are thine enemies, knave.


  COUNTESS.
 May it please you, madam, that he bid Helen come to you.
 One good woman in ten, madam, which is a purifying o' th'
    song.

    I am going, forsooth.
 Well, now.

  STEWARD.
 There is more owing her than is paid; and
    more shall be paid her than she'll demand.
 Her matter was, she loved your
    son.

    Many likelihoods inform'd me of this before, which hung so
    tott'ring in the balance that I could neither believe nor
    misdoubt.
                                           Exit STEWARD

                            Enter HELENA

    Even so it was with me when I was young.
 Mine honourable mistress.

  COUNTESS.
 'Tis often seen
    Adoption strives with nature, and choice breeds
    A native slip to us from foreign seeds.
 That I am not.
 Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law.
 Now to all sense 'tis gross
    You love my son; invention is asham'd,
    Against the proclamation of thy passion,
    To say thou dost not.

  HELENA.
 Love you my son?  
  HELENA.
 Go not about; my love hath in't a bond
    Whereof the world takes note.

  HELENA.
 Had you not lately an intent-speak truly-
    To go to Paris?
  HELENA.

  COUNTESS.
 How shall they credit
    A poor unlearned virgin, when the schools,
    Embowell'd of their doctrine, have let off  
    The danger to itself?
  HELENA.
          Exeunt



<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
 SCENE 1.

  SECOND LORD.
 O my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!
  PAROLLES.

    SECOND LORD.
 I am commanded here and kept a coil with
    'Too young' and next year' and "Tis too early.

  PAROLLES.
 Good sparks and
    lustrous, a word, good metals: you shall find in the regiment of
    the Spinii one Captain Spurio, with his cicatrice, an emblem of
    war, here on his sinister cheek; it was this very sword
    entrench'd it.
 Say to him I live; and observe his reports for me.
 Now, good Lafeu,
    Bring in the admiration, that we with the
    May spend our wonder too, or take off thine
    By wond'ring how thou took'st it.

  KING.
 I knew him.

  HELENA.
 On's bed of death
    Many receipts he gave me; chiefly one,
    Which, as the dearest issue of his practice,
    And of his old experience th' only darling,
    He bade me store up as a triple eye,
    Safer than mine own two, more dear.
 I have so:
    And, hearing your high Majesty is touch'd
    With that malignant cause wherein the honour
    Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power,
    I come to tender it, and my appliance,
    With all bound humbleness.
 Inspired merit so by breath is barr'd.
 Tax of impudence,
    A strumpet's boldness, a divulged shame,
    Traduc'd by odious ballads; my maiden's name
    Sear'd otherwise; ne worse of worst-extended  
    With vilest torture let my life be ended.

    Sweet practiser, thy physic I will try,
    That ministers thine own death if I die.
 But rest
    Unquestion'd welcome and undoubted blest.
 Exeunt]




ACT II.
 I know my
    business is but to the court.

  COUNTESS.

  COUNTESS.

  COUNTESS.
 To be young again, if we could, I will be a fool in
    question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer.
  
  COUNTESS.

  CLOWN.
 O Lord, sir!-Spare not me.
 You would answer very well to a whipping, if you were
    but bound to't.
 I ne'er had worse luck in my life in my 'O Lord, sir!' I see
    thing's may serve long, but not serve ever.
 I play the noble housewife with the time,
    To entertain it so merrily with a fool.

  CLOWN.
 O Lord, sir!-Why, there't serves well again.

  CLOWN.
 Not much commendation to them?
  COUNTESS.
                              Exeunt




ACT II.
 They say miracles are past; and we have our philosophical
    persons to make modern and familiar things supernatural and
    causeless.

  BERTRAM.

  LAFEU.
 So I say-both of Galen and Paracelsus.

  LAFEU.

  LAFEU.
 That's it; I would have said the very same.
 Why, your dolphin is not lustier.
 Lustig, as the Dutchman says.
 Why, he's able to lead her a
    coranto.

  PAROLLES.

                                               Exit an ATTENDANT
    Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side;
    And with this healthful hand, whose banish'd sense
    Thou has repeal'd, a second time receive
    The confirmation of my promis'd gift,
    Which but attends thy naming.

  KING.

  HELENA.

    Please it your Majesty, I have done already.

  HELENA.
 I had rather be in this choice than throw ames-ace for my
    life.
 No better, if you please.
  
    Blessing upon your vows; and in your bed
    Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!
  LAFEU.

    Sure, they are bastards to the English; the French ne'er got 'em.

  KING.
 That is honour's scorn
    Which challenges itself as honour's born
    And is not like the sire.
 The mere word's a slave,
    Debauch'd on every tomb, on every grave
    A lying trophy; and as oft is dumb
    Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb
    Of honour'd bones indeed.
 What should be said?
    If thou canst like this creature as a maid,
    I can create the rest.

  KING.
 Check thy contempt;
    Obey our will, which travails in thy good;
    Believe not thy disdain, but presently
    Do thine own fortunes that obedient right
    Which both thy duty owes and our power claims;
    Or I will throw thee from my care for ever
    Into the staggers and the careless lapse
    Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate
    Loosing upon thee in the name of justice,
    Without all terms of pity.

  KING.

  KING.
 Good fortune and the favour of the King
    Smile upon this contract; whose ceremony
    Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief,
    And be perform'd to-night.

              Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES who stay behind,
                                      commenting of this wedding
  LAFEU.
 Your lord and master did well to make his recantation.
 Recantation! My Lord! my master!
  LAFEU.
 What I dare too well do, I dare not do.
 Yet the scarfs and the bannerets about thee did manifoldly
    dissuade me from believing thee a vessel of too great a burden.
 I
    have now found thee; when I lose thee again I care not; yet art
    thou good for nothing but taking up; and that thou'rt scarce
    worth.

  PAROLLES.
'
  PAROLLES.
 My lord, you do me most insupportable vexation.

  PAROLLES.
 The devil it is that's thy master.
 By mine honour, if I were but two hours younger, I'd beat  
    thee.
 Methink'st thou art a general offence, and every man should
    beat thee.

  BERTRAM.
 Although before the solemn priest I have sworn,
    I will not bed her.
 O my Parolles, they have married me!
    I'll to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.
 France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits
    The tread of a man's foot.
 Will this capriccio hold in thee, art sure?
  BERTRAM.
      Exeunt




ACT II.
 SCENE 4.

Paris.
 Marry, you are the wiser man; for many a man's tongue shakes
    out his master's undoing.

  PAROLLES.
 Did you find me in yourself, sir, or were you taught to find
    me? The search, sir, was profitable; and much fool may you find
    in you, even to the world's pleasure and the increase of
    laughter.

  HELENA.
 That, having this obtain'd, you presently
    Attend his further pleasure.

  PAROLLES.

  LAFEU.

  BERTRAM.
 Then my dial goes not true; I took this lark for a bunting.

  LAFEU.
 I have then sinn'd against his experience and transgress'd
    against his valour; and my state that way is dangerous, since I
    cannot yet find in my heart to repent.
 Ay, sir; he, sir, 's a good workman, a
    very good tailor.

  LAFEU.
  
  BERTRAM.

  LAFEU.
 An idle lord, I swear.
 Why, do you not know him?
  BERTRAM.
 I shall obey his will.
 This drives me to entreat you
    That presently you take your way for home,
    And rather muse than ask why I entreat you;
    For my respects are better than they seem,
    And my appointments have in them a need
    Greater than shows itself at the first view
    To you that know them not.
 This to my mother.

  HELENA.
 Sir, I can nothing say
    But that I am your most obedient servant.

  BERTRAM.

  HELENA.
 Pray, sir, your pardon.
 Well, what would you say?
  HELENA.
 What would you have?
  HELENA.

  HELENA.

  PAROLLES.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
>>




ACT III.
 SCENE 1.
 Therefore we marvel much our cousin France
    Would in so just a business shut his bosom
    Against our borrowing prayers.

  SECOND LORD.

  DUKE.
 You know your places well;
    When better fall, for your avails they fell.
 Flourish.

Rousillon.
 By my troth, I take my young lord to be a very melancholy
    man.
 By what observance, I pray you?
  CLOWN.

                                              [Opening a letter]
  CLOWN.
 I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court.
 Our old ling
    and our Isbels o' th' country are nothing like your old ling and
    your Isbels o' th' court.
 The brains of my Cupid's knock'd out;
    and I begin to love, as an old man loves money, with no stomach.

  COUNTESS.
 What have we here?
  CLOWN.
 I have wedded her, not bedded
    her; and sworn to make the "not" eternal.
  
  COUNTESS.
 Why should he be kill'd?
  CLOWN.
 So say I, madam, if he run away, as I hear he does the
    danger is in standing to 't; that's the loss of men, though it be
    the getting of children.
 Save you, good madam.

  HELENA.

  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 Look on this letter, madam; here's my passport.
"
    This is a dreadful sentence.

  COUNTESS.
 Brought you this letter, gentlemen?
  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 Ay, madam;
    And for the contents' sake are sorry for our pains.
 He was my son;
    But I do wash his name out of my blood,
    And thou art all my child.
'
    'Tis bitter.
 Ay, madam.

  COUNTESS.
 Nothing in France until he have no wife!
    There's nothing here that is too good for him
    But only she; and she deserves a lord
    That twenty such rude boys might tend upon,
    And call her hourly mistress.

  COUNTESS.

    I will entreat you, when you see my son,
    To tell him that his sword can never win
    The honour that he loses.

  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 'Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France.

    Whoever shoots at him, I set him there;
    Whoever charges on his forward breast,
    I am the caitiff that do hold him to't;
    And though I kill him not, I am the cause
    His death was so effected.
 No; come thou home, Rousillon,
    Whence honour but of danger wins a scar,
    As oft it loses all.

    My being here it is that holds thee hence.

    Shall I stay here to do 't? No, no, although
    The air of paradise did fan the house,
    And angels offic'd all.
 Enter the DUKE OF FLORENCE, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, SOLDIERS,
drum and trumpets

  DUKE.
 Sir, it is
    A charge too heavy for my strength; but yet
    We'll strive to bear it for your worthy sake
    To th' extreme edge of hazard.
                   Exeunt




ACT III.
 Ah, what sharp stings are in her mildest words!
    Rinaldo, you did never lack advice so much
    As letting her pass so; had I spoke with her,
    I could have well diverted her intents,
    Which thus she hath prevented.

  COUNTESS.
 Write, write, Rinaldo,
    To this unworthy husband of his wife;
    Let every word weigh heavy of her worth
    That he does weigh too light.
 My greatest grief,
    Though little he do feel it, set down sharply.
 SCENE 5.
 They say the French count has done most honourable service.

  WIDOW.
  [Tucket]
    We have lost our labour; they are gone a contrary way.

  MARIANA.
 Come, let's return again, and suffice ourselves with the
    report of it.
 I know that knave, hang him! one Parolles; a filthy
    officer he is in those suggestions for the young earl.
 I hope I need not to advise you further; but I
    hope your own grace will keep you where you are, though there
    were no further danger known but the modesty which is so lost.


            Enter HELENA in the dress of a pilgrim

  WIDOW.
 I hope so.
 Look, here comes a pilgrim.

    Where do the palmers lodge, I do beseech you?
  WIDOW.
 Is this the way?
                                                  [A march afar]  
  WIDOW.

    If you will tarry, holy pilgrim,
    But till the troops come by,
    I will conduct you where you shall be lodg'd;
    The rather for I think I know your hostess
    As ample as myself.
 He stole from France,
    As 'tis reported, for the King had married him  
    Against his liking.
 Think you it is so?
  HELENA.
 Monsieur Parolles.


    Enter, with drum and colours, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, and the
                          whole ARMY

  MARIANA.
 So, now they come.

    That is Antonio, the Duke's eldest son;
    That, Escalus.

  HELENA.

  PAROLLES.
 Of enjoin'd penitents
    There's four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound,
    Already at my house.

  BERTRAM.
 Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge,
    without any malice, but to speak of him as my kinsman, he's a
    most notable coward, an infinite and endless liar, an hourly
    promise-breaker, the owner of no one good quality worthy your
    lordship's entertainment.
 I with a troop of Florentines will suddenly surprise  
    him; such I will have whom I am sure he knows not from the enemy.

    We will bind and hoodwink him so that he shall suppose no other
    but that he is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries when
    we bring him to our own tents.

  BERTRAM.

  FIRST LORD.
 Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success.

  PAROLLES.

  BERTRAM.
                          Exit
  SECOND LORD.
 Why, do you think he will make no deed at all of this that
    so seriously he does address himself unto?
  SECOND LORD.
 You shall see his fall to-night; for indeed he is
    not for your lordship's respect.

    He was first smok'd by the old Lord Lafeu.
 Your brother, he shall go along with me.
                 Exeunt




ACT III.
 SCENE 7.
 If you misdoubt me that I am not she,
    I know not how I shall assure you further
    But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.

  HELENA.
 The Count he woos your daughter
    Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty,
    Resolv'd to carry her.

    Now his important blood will nought deny
    That she'll demand.

  WIDOW.

  WIDOW.
 I have yielded.
 Every night he comes
    With musics of all sorts, and songs compos'd
    To her unworthiness.
 It nothing steads us
    To chide him from our eaves, for he persists
    As if his life lay on 't.
 Why then to-night
    Let us assay our plot; which, if it speed,
    Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed,
    And lawful meaning in a lawful act;
    Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact.

  SECOND LORD.
 Art not acquainted with him? Knows he not thy voice?
  FIRST SOLDIER.
 This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue was
    guilty of.
 Is it possible he should know what he is, and be that
    he is?
  PAROLLES.

  SECOND LORD.

  SECOND LORD.
 Thirty fathom.
 Cargo, cargo, cargo, villianda par corbo, cargo.

  FIRST SOLDIER.

  PAROLLES.
 Oscorbidulchos volivorco.
 Nay, I'll speak that
    Which you will wonder at.
 Captain, I will.

  BERTRAM.
 So should you be.

  DIANA.

  BERTRAM.

    I was compell'd to her; but I love the
    By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever
    Do thee all rights of service.

  DIANA.
 Ay, so you serve us
    Till we serve you; but when you have our roses
    You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves,
    And mock us with our bareness.
 Change it, change it;
    Be not so holy-cruel.
 Say thou art mine, and ever
    My love as it begins shall so persever.
 I'll lend it thee, my dear, but have no power
    To give it from me.
 It is an honour 'longing to our house,
    Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
    Which were the greatest obloquy i' th' world
    In me to lose.
 Mine honour's such a ring:
    My chastity's the jewel of our house,
    Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
    Which were the greatest obloquy i' th' world  
    In me to lose.
 Thus your own proper wisdom
    Brings in the champion Honour on my part
    Against your vain assault.
 When midnight comes, knock at my chamber window;
    I'll order take my mother shall not hear.
 You have won
    A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

    My mother told me just how he would woo,
    As if she sat in's heart; she says all men
    Have the like oaths.
 There is something
    in't that stings his nature; for on the reading it he chang'd
    almost into another man.
 I will tell you a thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly
    with you.

  FIRST LORD.

  SECOND LORD.
 Is it not meant damnable in us to be trumpeters of our
    unlawful intents? We shall not then have his company to-night?
  FIRST LORD.
 Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.
 I would gladly have him see his
    company anatomiz'd, that he might take a measure of his own
    judgments, wherein so curiously he had set this counterfeit.

  SECOND LORD.
 How is this justified?
  SECOND LORD.
 I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this.
 And how mightily some other times we drown our gain in
    tears! The great dignity that his valour hath here acquir'd for
    him shall at home be encount'red with a shame as ample.

    Here's his lordship now.

  SECOND LORD.
 I will confess what I know without constraint; if ye
    pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.

  FIRST SOLDIER.

  PAROLLES.

  FIRST SOLDIER.
 Shall I set down your answer so?
  PAROLLES.
 Do; I'll take the sacrament on 't, how and which way you
    will.
 Well, that's set down.
 'Demand of him of what strength they are a-foot.
  
  BERTRAM.
 'You shall demand of him
    whether one Captain Dumain be i' th' camp, a Frenchman; what his
    reputation is with the Duke, what his valour, honesty, expertness
    in wars; or whether he thinks it were not possible, with
    well-weighing sums of gold, to corrupt him to a revolt.
' What say
    you to this? What do you know of it?
  PAROLLES.
 Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I know his
    brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.
  
  SECOND LORD.
 What is his reputation with the Duke?
  PAROLLES.

  FIRST SOLDIER.
 Marry, we'll search.

  FIRST SOLDIER.
 Shall I read it to you?
  PAROLLES.

  BERTRAM.
 I pray you, sir, put it up
    again.
 He will lie,
    sir, with such volubility that you would think truth were a fool.

  SECOND LORD.

  BERTRAM.
 A pox on him! he's a cat still.
 What's his brother, the other Captain Dumain?
  FIRST LORD.
 In a retreat he outruns any lackey: marry,
    in coming on he has the cramp.

  FIRST SOLDIER.
 A plague of all drums!
    Only to seem to deserve well, and to beguile the supposition of
    that lascivious young boy the Count, have I run into this danger.
 Come, headsman, of with his head.
 Good morrow, noble Captain.
 God save you, noble Captain.
 If you could find out a country where but women were
    that had received so much shame, you might begin an impudent  
    nation.
 Gentle madam,
    You never had a servant to whose trust
    Your business was more welcome.

    But more of this hereafter.
 Yet, I pray you:
    But with the word the time will bring on summer,
    When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns
    And be as sweet as sharp.

    All's Well that Ends Well.
 The COUNT'S palace

Enter COUNTESS, LAFEU, and CLOWN

  LAFEU.
 If
    she had partaken of my flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a
    mother.
 We may pick a thousand
    sallets ere we light on such another herb.
 Indeed, sir, she was the sweet-marjoram of the sallet, or,
    rather, the herb of grace.

  LAFEU.
 A fool, sir, at a woman's service, and a knave at a man's.

  LAFEU.

  CLOWN.

 Exit
  LAFEU.
 So 'a is.
 My lord that's gone made himself much  sport
    out of him.

  LAFEU.

  COUNTESS.
 His left cheek is a
    cheek of two pile and a half, but his right cheek is worn bare.
 A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good liv'ry of
    honour; so belike is that.
 Let us go see your son, I pray you;
    I long to talk with the young noble soldier.
 Faith, there's a dozen of 'em, with delicate fine hats, and
    most courteous feathers, which bow the head and nod at every man.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
 SCENE 1.

  GENTLEMAN.
 What's your will?
  HELENA.
 Not indeed.
 Lord, how we lose our pains!
  HELENA.
 All's Well That Ends Well yet,
    Though time seem so adverse and means unfit.
 Marry, as I take it, to Rousillon;
    Whither I am going.
 I do beseech you, sir,
    Since you are like to see the King before me,
    Commend the paper to his gracious hand;
    Which I presume shall render you no blame,
    But rather make you thank your pains for it.

  HELENA.

Rousillon.
 Truly, Fortune's displeasure is but sluttish, if it smell
    so strongly as thou speak'st of.

  CLOWN.
 Let the justices make you and Fortune friends; I am for
    other business.
 My name, my good lord, is Parolles.
 Cox my passion! give me your  
    hand.
 It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace, for
    you did bring me out.
                         Exeunt




ACT V SCENE 3.

  COUNTESS.
 My honour'd lady,
    I have forgiven and forgotten all;
    Though my revenges were high bent upon him
    And watch'd the time to shoot.
 He lost a wife
    Whose beauty did astonish the survey
    Of richest eyes; whose words all ears took captive;
    Whose dear perfection hearts that scorn'd to serve
    Humbly call'd mistress.

  KING.

  KING.
 I have letters sent me
    That sets him high in fame.
 He looks well on 't.
 I am not a day of season,
    For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail
    In me at once.
 All is whole;
    Not one word more of the consumed time.
' Our rash faults
    Make trivial price of serious things we have,
    Not knowing them until we know their grave.

    Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust,
    Destroy our friends, and after weep their dust;  
    Our own love waking cries to see what's done,
    While shameful hate sleeps out the afternoon.

    Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin.

    The main consents are had; and here we'll stay
    To see our widower's second marriage-day.

                                          [BERTRAM gives a ring]
    By my old beard,
    And ev'ry hair that's on 't, Helen, that's dead,
    Was a sweet creature; such a ring as this,
    The last that e'er I took her leave at court,
    I saw upon her finger.
 Hers it was not.

  LAFEU.

  KING.
 Take him away.

    We'll sift this matter further.


                        Enter a GENTLEMAN

  GENTLEMAN.
  [Reads the letter]  'Upon his many protestations to marry me
    when his wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won me.
 I will buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and toll for this.
 I wonder, sir, sith wives are monsters to you.

                                           Enter WIDOW and DIANA
    What woman's that?
  DIANA.

    My suit, as I do understand, you know,
    And therefore know how far I may be pitied.
 My lord, I neither can nor will deny
    But that I know them.
 She's none of mine, my lord.
 He blushes, and 'tis it.

    Of six preceding ancestors, that gem
    Conferr'd by testament to th' sequent issue,
    Hath it been ow'd and worn.
 I did, my lord, but loath am to produce
    So bad an instrument; his name's Parolles.

  KING.
        Exit an ATTENDANT
  BERTRAM.

  BERTRAM.
 I think she has.

    She knew her distance, and did angle for me,
    Madding my eagerness with her restraint,
    As all impediments in fancy's course
    Are motives of more fancy; and, in fine,
    Her infinite cunning with her modern grace
    Subdu'd me to her rate.

  BERTRAM.


                       Enter PAROLLES
  
  BERTRAM.

    Is this the man you speak of?
  DIANA.
 Ay, my lord.
 So please your Majesty, my master hath been an honourable
    gentleman; tricks he hath had in him, which gentlemen have.

    What an equivocal companion is this!
  PAROLLES.
 Do you know he promis'd me marriage?
  PAROLLES.
 But wilt thou not speak all thou know'st?
  PAROLLES.
 I did go between them, as I
    said; but more than that, he loved her-for indeed he was mad for
    her, and talk'd of Satan, and of Limbo, and of Furies, and I know
    not what.

  KING.
 Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst say they are
    married; but thou art too fine in thy evidence; therefore stand
    aside.
 I found it not.

  DIANA.
 I think thee now some common customer.

  DIANA.

                                             [Pointing to LAFEU]
  KING.

  DIANA.
 Stay, royal sir;
                                                      Exit WIDOW
    The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for,
    And he shall surety me.
 But for this lord
    Who hath abus'd me as he knows himself,
    Though yet he never harm'd me, here I quit him.
 No, my good lord;
    'Tis but the shadow of a wife you see,
    The name and not the thing.
 There is your ring,
    And, look you, here's your letter.

  HELENA.
 If it appear not plain, and prove untrue,
    Deadly divorce step between me and you!
    O my dear mother, do I see you living?
  LAFEU.
 Let us from point to point this story know,
    To make the even truth in pleasure flow.
 The King's a beggar, now the play is done.

    Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts;
    Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
>>




SCENE:
The Roman Empire

ACT I.
 Those his goodly eyes,
    That o'er the files and musters of the war
    Have glow'd like plated Mars, now bend, now turn,
    The office and devotion of their view
    Upon a tawny front.
 Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, her LADIES, the train,
                    with eunuchs fanning her

    Look where they come!
    Take but good note, and you shall see in him
    The triple pillar of the world transform'd  
    Into a strumpet's fool.
 If it be love indeed, tell me how much.

  ANTONY.
 Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new earth.

  ANTONY.
'
  ANTONY.
 How, my love?
  CLEOPATRA.
 As I am Egypt's Queen,
    Thou blushest, Antony, and that blood of thine
    Is Caesar's homager.
 Else so thy cheek pays shame
    When shrill-tongu'd Fulvia scolds.
 The messengers!
  ANTONY.
 The nobleness of life
    Is to do thus [emhracing], when such a mutual pair
    And such a twain can do't, in which I bind,
    On pain of punishment, the world to weet
    We stand up peerless.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Excellent falsehood!
    Why did he marry Fulvia, and not love her?
    I'll seem the fool I am not.
 But stirr'd by Cleopatra.

    No messenger but thine, and all alone
    To-night we'll wander through the streets and note
    The qualities of people.
 Speak not to us.
 Is Caesar with Antonius priz'd so slight?
  PHILO.
 Rest you happy!            Exeunt




SCENE II.
 Is this the man? Is't you, sir, that know things?
  SOOTHSAYER.

  SOOTHSAYER.

  IRAS.
 Let me have a
    child at fifty, to whom Herod of Jewry may do homage.

  SOOTHSAYER.
 You shall outlive the lady whom you serve.
 You have seen and prov'd a fairer former fortune
    Than that which is to approach.

  CHARMIAN.

  CHARMIAN.
 I have said.
 Not in my husband's nose.
 Therefore,
    dear Isis, keep decorum, and fortune him accordingly!
  CHARMIAN.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Where's Alexas?
  ALEXAS.
 Ay.
 'Tis thus:
    Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death,
    I hear him as he flatter'd.
 From Sicyon, ho, the news! Speak there!
  FIRST ATTENDANT.
 The man from Sicyon- is there such an one?
  SECOND ATTENDANT.
 He stays upon your will.

  ANTONY.
 Let him appear.
 Where died she?
  SECOND MESSENGER.
 Cleopatra, catching but
    the least noise of this, dies instantly; I have seen her die  
    twenty times upon far poorer moment.
 I do think there is mettle
    in death, which commits some loving act upon her, she hath such a
    celerity in dying.
 This cannot be cunning in her; if it be, she
    makes a show'r of rain as well as Jove.
 O Sir, you had then left unseen a wonderful piece of
    work, which not to have been blest withal would have discredited
    your travel.

  ENOBARBUS.

  ENOBARBUS.
 Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice.
 When it
    pleaseth their deities to take the wife of a man from him, it  
    shows to man the tailors of the earth; comforting therein that
    when old robes are worn out there are members to make new.
 If
    there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut,
    and the case to be lamented.

  ANTONY.
 No more light answers.
 Much is breeding
    Which, like the courser's hair, hath yet but life
    And not a serpent's poison.

  ENOBARBUS.
 I shall do't.
                                Exeunt




SCENE III.

Alexandria.
 Where is he?
  CHARMIAN.

    I did not send you.
 If you find him sad,
    Say I am dancing; if in mirth, report
    That I am sudden sick.
 Tempt him not so too far; I wish, forbear;
    In time we hate that which we often fear.

  ANTONY.
 I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose-
  CLEOPATRA.

  ANTONY.

    Would she had never given you leave to come!
    Let her not say 'tis I that keep you here-
    I have no power upon you; hers you are.

  ANTONY.
 When you sued staying,
    Then was the time for words.
 How now, lady!
  CLEOPATRA.
 Our Italy  
    Shines o'er with civil swords: Sextus Pompeius
    Makes his approaches to the port of Rome;
    Equality of two domestic powers
    Breed scrupulous faction; the hated, grown to strength,
    Are newly grown to love.
 My more particular,
    And that which most with you should safe my going,
    Is Fulvia's death.
 Though age from folly could not give me freedom,
     It does from childishness.

  CLEOPATRA.

  ANTONY.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Good now, play one scene
    Of excellent dissembling, and let it look
    Like perfect honour.

  CLEOPATRA.
 And target.

    Sir, you and I must part- but that's not it.

    That you know well.
 Let's grant it is not
    Amiss to tumble on the bed of Ptolemy,
    To give a kingdom for a mirth, to sit
    And keep the turn of tippling with a slave,
    To reel the streets at noon, and stand the buffet
    With knaves that smell of sweat.
 If he fill'd
    His vacancy with his voluptuousness,
    Full surfeits and the dryness of his bones
    Call on him for't! But to confound such time
    That drums him from his sport and speaks as loud
    As his own state and ours- 'tis to be chid
    As we rate boys who, being mature in knowledge,
    Pawn their experience to their present pleasure,
    And so rebel to judgment.

    It hath been taught us from the primal state
    That he which is was wish'd until he were;
    And the ebb'd man, ne'er lov'd till ne'er worth love,
    Comes dear'd by being lack'd.
 Antony,
    Leave thy lascivious wassails.
 When thou once
    Was beaten from Modena, where thou slew'st
    Hirtius and Pansa, consuls, at thy heel
    Did famine follow; whom thou fought'st against,
    Though daintily brought up, with patience more
    Than savages could suffer.
 'Tis time we twain
    Did show ourselves i' th' field; and to that end
    Assemble we immediate council.

  LEPIDUS.
 Ha, ha!
    Give me to drink mandragora.
 'Tis well for thee
    That, being unseminar'd, thy freer thoughts
    May not fly forth of Egypt.
 Indeed?
  MARDIAN.
 O Charmian,
    Where think'st thou he is now? Stands he or sits he?
    Or does he walk? or is he on his horse?
    O happy horse, to bear the weight of Antony!
    Do bravely, horse; for wot'st thou whom thou mov'st?
    The demi-Atlas of this earth, the arm
    And burgonet of men.
 How much unlike art thou Mark Antony!
    Yet, coming from him, that great med'cine hath
    With his tinct gilded thee.
 Last thing he did, dear Queen,
    He kiss'd- the last of many doubled kisses-
    This orient pearl.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Like to the time o' th' year between the extremes
    Of hot and cold; he was nor sad nor merry.

    Why do you send so thick?
  CLEOPATRA.
  
    Welcome, my good Alexas.
'
  CHARMIAN.
 By your most gracious pardon,
    I sing but after you.

  CLEOPATRA.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 If the great gods be just, they shall assist
    The deeds of justest men.
 I shall do well.
 Lepidus flatters both,
    Of both is flatter'd; but he neither loves,
    Nor either cares for him.

  MENAS.
 A mighty strength they carry.
 From Silvius, sir.
 This is most certain that I shall deliver:
    Mark Antony is every hour in Rome
    Expected.
 Menas, I did not think
    This amorous surfeiter would have donn'd his helm
    For such a petty war; his soldiership
    Is twice the other twain.
 I know not, Menas,
    How lesser enmities may give way to greater.

    Be't as our gods will have't! It only stands
    Our lives upon to use our strongest hands.

Rome.
 'Tis not a time
    For private stomaching.
 Every time
    Serves for the matter that is then born in't.

  LEPIDUS.

  LEPIDUS.
 Here comes  
    The noble Antony.
 And yonder, Caesar.

    Hark, Ventidius.

  LEPIDUS.
  
  ANTONY.
                                  [They sit]
  ANTONY.
 My being in Egypt, Caesar,
    What was't to you?
  CAESAR.
 No more than my residing here at Rome
    Might be to you in Egypt.

  ANTONY.
 You do mistake your business; my brother never
    Did urge me in his act.
 You praise yourself
    By laying defects of judgment to me; but
    You patch'd up your excuses.
  
  ANTONY.
 So much uncurbable, her garboils, Caesar,
    Made out of her impatience- which not wanted
    Shrewdness of policy too- I grieving grant
    Did you too much disquiet.
 No;
    Lepidus, let him speak.
 To lend me arms and aid when I requir'd them,
    The which you both denied.
 As nearly as I may,
    I'll play the penitent to you; but mine honesty
    Shall not make poor my greatness, nor my power
    Work without it.
 Or, if you borrow one another's love for the instant,
    you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again.

    You shall have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to
    do.
 Speak no more.
 You wrong this presence; therefore speak no more.
 I do not much dislike the matter, but
    The manner of his speech; for't cannot be
    We shall remain in friendship, our conditions
    So diff'ring in their acts.

  CAESAR.

    If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof
    Were well deserv'd of rashness.
 Let me hear
    Agrippa further speak.
 To hold you in perpetual amity,  
    To make you brothers, and to knit your hearts
    With an unslipping knot, take Antony
    Octavia to his wife; whose beauty claims
    No worse a husband than the best of men;
    Whose virtue and whose general graces speak
    That which none else can utter.

    A sister I bequeath you, whom no brother
    Did ever love so dearly.
 Happily, amen!
  ANTONY.

  LEPIDUS.
 Time calls upon's.
  
  ENOBARBUS.
 Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast, and but
    twelve persons there.
 She's a most triumphant lady, if report be square to her.

    The barge she sat in, like a burnish'd throne,
    Burn'd on the water.
 On each side her
    Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids,
    With divers-colour'd fans, whose wind did seem
    To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool,
    And what they undid did.

  AGRIPPA.
 O, rare for Antony!
  ENOBARBUS.
 At the helm
    A seeming mermaid steers.
 The silken tackle
    Swell with the touches of those flower-soft hands
    That yarely frame the office.
 From the barge
    A strange invisible perfume hits the sense  
    Of the adjacent wharfs.

  AGRIPPA.
 Royal wench!
    She made great Caesar lay his sword to bed.

  MAECENAS.

  ENOBARBUS.

    Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale
    Her infinite variety.
 Other women cloy
    The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry
    Where most she satisfies; for vilest things
    Become themselves in her, that the holy priests
    Bless her when she is riggish.
 If beauty, wisdom, modesty, can settle
    The heart of Antony, Octavia is
    A blessed lottery to him.
                    Exeunt




SCENE III.
 Good night, sir.
 My Octavia,
    Read not my blemishes in the world's report.

  OCTAVIA.
 If you can- your reason.

  ANTONY.
 Say to me,
    Whose fortunes shall rise higher, Caesar's or mine?
  SOOTHSAYER.

    Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side.

  SOOTHSAYER.
 I say again, thy spirit
    Is all afraid to govern thee near him;
    But, he away, 'tis noble.

  ANTONY.
 Get thee gone.
 The very dice obey him;
    And in our sports my better cunning faints
    Under his chance.
 Your commission's ready;
    Follow me and receive't.
 Pray you hasten
    Your generals after.
 Sir, good success!
  LEPIDUS.
 The music, ho!

                    Enter MARDIAN the eunuch

  CLEOPATRA.

  CHARMIAN.
 As well a woman with an eunuch play'd
    As with a woman.
 Come, you'll play with me, sir?
  MARDIAN.
 I'll none now.
'
  CHARMIAN.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Why, there's more gold.
 Bring it to that,
    The gold I give thee will I melt and pour
    Down thy ill-uttering throat.

  MESSENGER.
 Well, go to, I will.

    But there's no goodness in thy face.

  MESSENGER.

  MESSENGER.

  MESSENGER.
 Make thee a fortune from me.
 I do not like 'but yet.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Rogue, thou hast liv'd too long.
             Exit
  CHARMIAN.

    Though I am mad, I will not bite him.

    Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me
    Thou wouldst appear most ugly.
 Take no offence that I would not offend you;
    To punish me for what you make me do
    Seems much unequal.
 Good your Highness, patience.

  CHARMIAN.
 O Iras, Charmian! 'Tis no matter.
 Bring me word quickly.
 Lead me to my chamber.

  ANTONY.
 That's our offer.

  LEPIDUS.

  POMPEY.
 Thus we are agreed.
 And fair words to them.
 Well;
    And well am like to do, for I perceive
    Four feasts are toward.

    I never hated thee; I have seen thee fight,
    When I have envied thy behaviour.

  POMPEY.
- You and I have known, sir.
 We have, sir.

  ENOBARBUS.
 Nor what I have done by water.

  ENOBARBUS.
 There I deny my land service.
 But there is never a fair woman has a true face.
 For my part, I am sorry it is turn'd to a drinking.
 If he do, sure he cannot weep't back again.

  MENAS.
 But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.
 'Tis true.

  MENAS.
 Not he that himself is not so; which is Mark Antony.

  FIRST SERVANT.

  FIRST SERVANT.
 Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the
    operation of your sun; so is your crocodile.

  ANTONY.
 [Aside to MENAS] Say in mine ear; what is't?
  MENAS.
 [Aside to POMPEY] Forsake thy seat, I do beseech thee,
      Captain,
    And hear me speak a word.

  POMPEY.
 Of it own colour too.
 'Tis a strange serpent.
 But entertain it,  
    And though you think me poor, I am the man
    Will give thee all the world.
 No, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup.

  MENAS.
 Let me cut the cable;
    And when we are put off, fall to their throats.
 Thou must know
    'Tis not my profit that does lead mine honour:
    Mine honour, it.
 Being done unknown,
    I should have found it afterwards well done,
    But must condemn it now.
 Bear him ashore.

  ENOBARBUS.
 Why?
  ENOBARBUS.
 'A bears the third part of the world, man; see'st not?
  MENAS.
 It ripens towards it.

  CAESAR.

               [Music plays.
 What would you more? Pompey, good night.
 Good brother,
    Let me request you off; our graver business
    Frowns at this levity.
 Strong Enobarb
    Is weaker than the wine, and mine own tongue
    Splits what it speaks.
 O Antony,  
    You have my father's house- but what? We are friends.
 Take heed you fall not.
 No, to my cabin.

    Who does i' th' wars more than his captain can
    Becomes his captain's captain; and ambition,
    The soldier's virtue, rather makes choice of loss
    Than gain which darkens him.
 Rome.

  AGRIPPA.

  ENOBARBUS.
 O, how he loves Caesar!
  AGRIPPA.
 Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!
  ENOBARBUS.
 O, Antony! O thou Arabian bird!
  ENOBARBUS.

    Hoo! hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot  
    Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number- hoo!-
    His love to Antony.
 They are his shards, and he their beetle.

  AGRIPPA.
 You take from me a great part of myself;
    Use me well in't.
 Make me not offended
    In your distrust.
 You shall not find,
    Though you be therein curious, the least cause
    For what you seem to fear.
 Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well.
 Sir, look well to my husband's house; and-
  CAESAR.

  ENOBARBUS.

  ENOBARBUS.
 [Aside to AGRIPPA] He were the worse for that, were he a
      horse;
    So is he, being a man.
 [Aside to ENOBARBUS] Why, Enobarbus,
    When Antony found Julius Caesar dead,
    He cried almost to roaring; and he wept
    When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.
 Farewell, farewell!                   [Kisses OCTAVIA]
  ANTONY.


                Enter the MESSENGER as before

    Come hither, sir.
 Madam, in Rome
    I look'd her in the face, and saw her led
    Between her brother and Mark Antony.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Didst hear her speak? Is she shrill-tongu'd or low?
  MESSENGER.
 Madam, I heard her speak: she is low-voic'd.

  CLEOPATRA.
 He cannot like her long.

  CLEOPATRA.
 She creeps.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Or I have no observance.
 He's very knowing;
    I do perceive't.

    Her hair, what colour?
  MESSENGER.
 Go make thee ready;
    Our letters are prepar'd.
 Why, methinks, by him,
    This creature's no such thing.

  CHARMIAN.
 Hath he seen majesty? Isis else defend,
    And serving you so long!
  CLEOPATRA.

  CHARMIAN.
 O my good lord,
    Believe not all; or if you must believe,
    Stomach not all.
 A more unhappy lady,
    If this division chance, ne'er stood between,
    Praying for both parts.
 Provide your going;
    Choose your own company, and command what cost
    Your heart has mind to.
 Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon Pompey.

  ENOBARBUS.
 Our great navy's rigg'd.
                                        Exeunt

ACT_3|SC_6
                          SCENE VI.
 CAESAR'S house

             Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS

  CAESAR.

  MAECENAS.
 I' th' common show-place, where they exercise.
 Let Rome be thus
    Inform'd.

  CAESAR.
 Why have you stol'n upon us thus? You come not
    Like Caesar's sister.
 Good my lord,
    To come thus was I not constrain'd, but did it
    On my free will.
 My lord, Mark Antony,
    Hearing that you prepar'd for war, acquainted
    My grieved ear withal; whereon I begg'd
    His pardon for return.
 Do not say so, my lord.

    Where is he now?
  OCTAVIA.
 My lord, in Athens.
  
  CAESAR.
 He hath assembled
    Bocchus, the king of Libya; Archelaus
    Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, king
    Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas;
    King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont;
    Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, king
    Of Comagene; Polemon and Amyntas,
    The kings of Mede and Lycaonia, with
    More larger list of sceptres.

  OCTAVIA.
 Best of comfort,
    And ever welcome to us.

  MAECENAS.
 But why, why,
  CLEOPATRA.
 Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars,
    And say'st it is not fit.
 Your presence needs must puzzle Antony;
    Take from his heart, take from his brain, from's time,
    What should not then be spar'd.
 He is already
    Traduc'd for levity; and 'tis said in Rome
    That Photinus an eunuch and your maids  
    Manage this war.
 Speak not against it;
    I will not stay behind.
 Nay, I have done.

    Here comes the Emperor.
 For that he dares us to't.

  ENOBARBUS.

  CANIDIUS.
 But these offers,
    Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off;
    And so should you.
 I'll fight at sea.
 But if we fail,
    We then can do't at land.


                       Enter a MESSENGER

    Thy business?
  MESSENGER.
 O noble Emperor, do not fight by sea;
    Trust not to rotten planks.

  CANIDIUS.

  SOLDIER.
 You keep by land
    The legions and the horse whole, do you not?  
  CANIDIUS.

  SOLDIER.
 While he was yet in Rome,
    His power went out in such distractions as
    Beguil'd all spies.
 Well I know the man.
 Taurus!
  TAURUS.
 The greater cantle of the world is lost
    With very ignorance; we have kiss'd away  
    Kingdoms and provinces.
 She once being loof'd,
    The noble ruin of her magic, Antony,
    Claps on his sea-wing, and, like a doting mallard,
    Leaving the fight in height, flies after her.

  ENOBARBUS.
 Alack, alack!  

                       Enter CANIDIUS

  CANIDIUS.

  CANIDIUS.

    My very hairs do mutiny; for the white
    Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them
    For fear and doting.
 Pray you look not sad,
    Nor make replies of loathness; take the hint
    Which my despair proclaims.
 To the sea-side straight way.
 No, no, no, no, no.

    Her head's declin'd, and death will seize her but
    Your comfort makes the rescue.

  ANTONY.
 O'er my spirit
    Thy full supremacy thou knew'st, and that
    Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods
    Command me.

  CLEOPATRA.
 O, my pardon!
  ANTONY.
 Fall not a tear, I say; one of them rates
    All that is won and lost.
         Exeunt

ACT_3|SC_12
                         SCENE XII.

  EUPHRONIUS.

  CAESAR.
 This for him.

    Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness,
    Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves
    The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs,
    Now hazarded to thy grace.
 Fortune pursue thee!
  CAESAR.
           Exit EUPHRONIUS
    [To THYREUS] To try thy eloquence, now 'tis time.
 Dispatch;
    From Antony win Cleopatra.
                               Exeunt

ACT_3|SC_13
                           SCENE XIII.

  ANTONY.
 Follow me.
 [Aside] Yes, like enough high-battled Caesar will
    Unstate his happiness, and be stag'd to th' show
    Against a sworder! I see men's judgments are
    A parcel of their fortunes, and things outward
    Do draw the inward quality after them,
    To suffer all alike.
 What, no more ceremony? See, my women!
    Against the blown rose may they stop their nose
    That kneel'd unto the buds.

    The loyalty well held to fools does make
    Our faith mere folly.
 Caesar's will?
  THYREUS.
 Hear it apart.

  THYREUS.

  ENOBARBUS.

    Thus then, thou most renown'd: Caesar entreats
    Not to consider in what case thou stand'st
    Further than he is Caesar.

  ENOBARBUS.
 It much would please him
    That of his fortunes you should make a staff
    To lean upon.
 Tell him I am prompt
    To lay my crown at 's feet, and there to kneel.

  THYREUS.
 'Tis your noblest course.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Your Caesar's father oft,
    When he hath mus'd of taking kingdoms in,
    Bestow'd his lips on that unworthy place,
    As it rain'd kisses.
 Favours, by Jove that thunders!  
    What art thou, fellow?
  THYREUS.
 One that but performs
    The bidding of the fullest man, and worthiest
    To have command obey'd.


                       Enter servants

    Take hence this Jack and whip him.
 Moon and stars!
    Whip him.

  THYMUS.
 Mark Antony-
  ANTONY.
 Tug him away.
 Ha!
    Have I my pillow left unpress'd in Rome,
    Forborne the getting of a lawful race,
    And by a gem of women, to be abus'd
    By one that looks on feeders?
  CLEOPATRA.

    But when we in our viciousness grow hard-
    O misery on't!- the wise gods seel our eyes,
    In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us
    Adore our errors, laugh at's while we strut
    To our confusion.

  CLEOPATRA.
 O, is't come to this?  
  ANTONY.
 Wherefore is this?
  ANTONY.
 To let a fellow that will take rewards,
    And say 'God quit you!' be familiar with
    My playfellow, your hand, this kingly seal
    And plighter of high hearts! O that I were
    Upon the hill of Basan to outroar
    The horned herd! For I have savage cause,
    And to proclaim it civilly were like
    A halter'd neck which does the hangman thank
    For being yare about him.
 Soundly, my lord.
 Get thee back to Caesar;
    Tell him thy entertainment; look thou say
    He makes me angry with him; for he seems
    Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am,
    Not what he knew I was.
 He makes me angry;
    And at this time most easy 'tis to do't,
    When my good stars, that were my former guides,
    Have empty left their orbs and shot their fires
    Into th' abysm of hell.
 If he mislike
    My speech and what is done, tell him he has
    Hipparchus, my enfranched bondman, whom  
    He may at pleasure whip or hang or torture,
    As he shall like, to quit me.
 Urge it thou.
 To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes
    With one that ties his points?
  CLEOPATRA.
 I am satisfied.

    I and my sword will earn our chronicle.

  CLEOPATRA.

    I had thought t'have held it poor; but since my lord
    Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.
 Call all his noble captains to my lord.
 Come on, my queen,
    There's sap in't yet.
     Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS
  ENOBARBUS.
 Caesar must think
    When one so great begins to rage, he's hunted
    Even to falling.
 Why should he not?
  ENOBARBUS.
 [Aside to CLEOPATRA] 'Tis one of those odd tricks which
      sorrow shoots
    Out of the mind.

  ANTONY.
 And thou art honest too.

  SERVANT.

    Tend me to-night two hours, I ask no more,
    And the gods yield you for't!
  ENOBARBUS.
 For shame!
    Transform us not to women.
 Ho, ho, ho!
    Now the witch take me if I meant it thus!
    Grace grow where those drops fall! My hearty friends,
    You take me in too dolorous a sense;
    For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you
    To burn this night with torches.
 To-morrow is the day.

  SECOND SOLDIER.
 It will determine one way.

    Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?
  FIRST SOLDIER.
 What news?
  SECOND SOLDIER.
 Belike 'tis but a rumour.
 Well, sir, good night.

                [The two companies separate and place themselves
                                   in every corner of the stage]
  SECOND SOLDIER.

  THIRD SOLDIER.
 Under the earth.

  THIRD SOLDIER.
 Content.

               Alexandria.
 No, my chuck.
 Eros! Come, mine armour, Eros!

                   Enter EROS with armour

    Come, good fellow, put mine iron on.
 Sooth, la, I'll help.
 Briefly, sir.
 Rarely, rarely!
    He that unbuckles this, till we do please
    To daff't for our repose, shall hear a storm.
 O love,
    That thou couldst see my wars to-day, and knew'st
    The royal occupation! Thou shouldst see
    A workman in't.


                   Enter an armed SOLDIER

    Good-morrow to thee.
 Good morrow, General.
 'Tis well blown, lads.

    So, so.

    Fare thee well, dame, whate'er becomes of me.
 You that will fight,
    Follow me close; I'll bring you to't.
 Well, on.
                      Exeunt

ACT_4|SC_5
                          SCENE V.
 ANTONY'S camp

        Trumpets sound.

  ANTONY.
 Sir,
    He is with Caesar.

  EROS.
 Most certain.
 Write to him-
    I will subscribe- gentle adieus and greetings;
    Say that I wish he never find more cause
    To change a master.
 CAESAR'S camp

       Flourish.
 Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight.
 Caesar, I shall.
                                 Exit
  CAESAR.
 Antony
    Is come into the field.

  CAESAR.
 For this pains
    Casaer hath hang'd him.
 Canidius and the rest
    That fell away have entertainment, but
    No honourable trust.
 I have done ill,
    Of which I do accuse myself so sorely
    That I will joy no more.
                                 Exit
  ENOBARBUS.
 I am alone the villain of the earth,
    And feel I am so most.
                             Exeunt

          Alarums.
 I had a wound here that was like a T,
    But now 'tis made an H.
 They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves
    For a fair victory.

    'Tis sport to maul a runner.

  ANTONY.
                              Exeunt

ACT_4|SC_8
                         SCENE VIII.
 Enter ANTONY, again in a march; SCARUS
                        with others

  ANTONY.
 Run one before
    And let the Queen know of our gests.
 Mine nightingale,
    We have beat them to their beds.

  CLEOPATRA.
 I'll give thee, friend,
    An armour all of gold; it was a king's.

  ANTONY.
 Let's speak to him.
 Let's hear him, for the things he speaks
    May concern Caesar.

  SECOND WATCH.
 The hand of death hath raught him.
 Let us bear him
    To th' court of guard; he is of note.
                     Exeunt with the body

ACT_4|SC_10
                          SCENE X.
 But being charg'd, we will be still by land,
    Which, as I take't, we shall; for his best force
    Is forth to man his galleys.
 I'll bring thee word
    Straight how 'tis like to go.

    My fleet hath yielded to the foe, and yonder  
    They cast their caps up and carouse together
    Like friends long lost.

    What, Eros, Eros!
  
                      Enter CLEOPATRA

    Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!
  CLEOPATRA.
 To th' monument!
    Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself;
    Say that the last I spoke was 'Antony'
    And word it, prithee, piteously.
 Ay, my lord.
 That which is now a horse, even with a thought
    The rack dislimns, and makes it indistinct,
    As water is in water.

  ANTONY.

  MARDIAN.
 The last she spake
    Was 'Antony! most noble Antony!'
    Then in the midst a tearing groan did break
    The name of Antony; it was divided
    Between her heart and lips.

    Eros!- I come, my queen.
 The gods withhold me!
    Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts,
    Though enemy, lost aim and could not?
  ANTONY.
 Eros,
    Wouldst thou be window'd in great Rome and see
    Thy master thus with pleach'd arms, bending down
    His corrigible neck, his face subdu'd
    To penetrative shame, whilst the wheel'd seat
    Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded
    His baseness that ensued?
  EROS.
  
    Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn
    Most useful for thy country.
 O, sir, pardon me!
  ANTONY.

  ANTONY.
 Now, Eros.

  EROS.
                            [Kills himself
  ANTONY.
 My queen and Eros
    Have, by their brave instruction, got upon me
    A nobleness in record.
 Come, then; and, Eros,
    Thy master dies thy scholar.
 The star is fall'n.

  FIRST GUARD.
 Nor any one.
                         Exeunt guard
  DERCETAS.

    This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings,
    Shall enter me with him.


                       Enter DIOMEDES

  DIOMEDES.
 Lives he?
    Wilt thou not answer, man?                     Exit DERCETAS
  ANTONY.
 Where is she?
  DIOMEDES.
 Most heavy day!
  ANTONY.

                   Alexandria.
 His death's upon him, but not dead.
 O sun,
    Burn the great sphere thou mov'st in! Darkling stand
    The varying shore o' th' world.
 So it should be, that none but Antony
    Should conquer Antony; but woe 'tis so!
  ANTONY.
 Not th' imperious show
    Of the full-fortun'd Caesar ever shall
    Be brooch'd with me.
 But come, come, Antony-
    Help me, my women- we must draw thee up;
    Assist, good friends.
 O, quick, or I am gone.

    Quicken with kissing.
 Had my lips that power,
    Thus would I wear them out.

  ANTONY.
 The miserable change now at my end
    Lament nor sorrow at; but please your thoughts
    In feeding them with those my former fortunes
    Wherein I liv'd the greatest prince o' th' world,
    The noblest; and do now not basely die,
    Not cowardly put off my helmet to
    My countryman- a Roman by a Roman
    Valiantly vanquish'd.
 It were for me
    To throw my sceptre at the injurious gods;  
    To tell them that this world did equal theirs
    Till they had stol'n our jewel.

    We'll bury him; and then, what's brave, what's noble,
    Let's do it after the high Roman fashion,
    And make death proud to take us.
 Come, away;
    This case of that huge spirit now is cold.
 SCENE I.
 Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar'st
    Appear thus to us?
  DERCETAS.
 I am call'd Dercetas;
    Mark Antony I serv'd, who best was worthy
    Best to be serv'd.
 If thou please
    To take me to thee, as I was to him
    I'll be to Caesar; if thou pleasest not,  
    I yield thee up my life.
 I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.
 The round world
    Should have shook lions into civil streets,
    And citizens to their dens.
 He is dead, Caesar,
    Not by a public minister of justice,
    Nor by a hired knife; but that self hand
    Which writ his honour in the acts it did
    Hath, with the courage which the heart did lend it,
    Splitted the heart.
  
  AGRIPPA.
 A rarer spirit never
    Did steer humanity.
 I must perforce
    Have shown to thee such a declining day
    Or look on thine; we could not stall together
    In the whole world.
 Go,
    And with your speediest bring us what she says,
    And how you find her.
 Gallus, go you along.
                      Exit GALLUS
    Where's Dolabella, to second Proculeius?
  ALL.
 Dolabella!
  CAESAR.

    Go with me to my tent, where you shall see
    How hardly I was drawn into this war,
    How calm and gentle I proceeded still
    In all my writings.
 The monument

      Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN

  CLEOPATRA.


       Enter, to the gates of the monument, PROCULEIUS, GALLUS,
                          and soldiers

  PROCULEIUS.
 Antony
    Did tell me of you, bade me trust you; but
    I do not greatly care to be deceiv'd,
    That have no use for trusting.
 Hold, worthy lady, hold,             [Disarms her]
    Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this
    Reliev'd, but not betray'd.
  
  CLEOPATRA.
 Know, sir, that I
    Will not wait pinion'd at your master's court,
    Nor once be chastis'd with the sober eye
    Of dull Octavia.
 So, Dolabella,
    It shall content me best.
 I cannot tell.
 Assuredly you know me.

  CLEOPATRA.
 I understand not, madam.
 His face was as the heav'ns, and therein stuck
    A sun and moon, which kept their course and lighted
    The little O, the earth.

  DOLABELLA.
 For his bounty,
    There was no winter in't; an autumn 'twas
    That grew the more by reaping.
 In his livery
    Walk'd crowns and crownets; realms and islands were
    As plates dropp'd from his pocket.

  CLEOPATRA.
 Nature wants stuff
    To vie strange forms with fancy; yet t' imagine
