  KING HENRY.

  KING HENRY.
 How now, madam!
    Still lamenting and mourning for Suffolk's death?
    I fear me, love, if that I had been dead,
    Thou wouldst not have mourn'd so much for me.

  QUEEN.
  
    The citizens fly and forsake their houses;
    The rascal people, thirsting after prey,
    Join with the traitor; and they jointly swear
    To spoil the city and your royal court.

  KING HENRY.
 [To LORD SAY] Farewell, my lord, trust not the Kentish
    rebels.
 The trust I have is in mine innocence,
    And therefore am I bold and resolute.


                    Enter a SOLDIER, running

  SOLDIER.
 If this fellow be wise, he'll never call ye Jack Cade more;
    I think he hath a very fair warning.

  DICK.
 My lord, there's an army gathered together in Smithfield.

  CADE.
 Come then, let's go fight with them.
 MATTHEW GOFFE is slain, and all the rest.
 Be it a lordship, thou shalt have it for that word.

  SMITH.
 I have thought upon it; it shall be so.
 My mouth shall be the Parliament of
    England.
 My lord, a prize, a prize! Here's the Lord Say, which
    sold the towns in France; he that made us pay one and twenty
    fifteens, and one shining to the pound, the last subsidy.


                Enter GEORGE BEVIS, with the LORD SAY

  CADE.
 Well, he shall be beheaded for it ten times.
 Thou hast most
    traitorously corrupted the youth of the realm in erecting a
    grammar school; and whereas, before, our forefathers had no other
    books but the score and the tally, thou hast caused printing to
    be us'd, and, contrary to the King, his crown, and dignity, thou
    hast built a paper-mill.

    Thou hast appointed justices of peace, to call poor men before
    them about matters they were not able to answer.
 Hear me but speak, and bear me where you will.
  
  GEORGE.

  SAY.

  CADE.

  SAY.
- Away with him! He has a familiar under his tongue; he
    speaks not o' God's name.

  ALL.

  CADE.
  [Exeunt some with
    LORD SAY]  The proudest peer in the realm shall not wear a head
    on his shoulders, unless he pay me tribute; there shall not a
    maid be married, but she shall pay to me her maidenhead ere they
    have it.

  DICK.
 Marry, presently.

  ALL.

    Soldiers, defer the spoil of the city until night; for with these
    borne before us instead of maces will we ride through the
    streets, and at every corner have them kiss.
 Away!     Exeunt




SCENE VIII.

    Know, Cade, we come ambassadors from the King
    Unto the commons whom thou hast misled;
    And here pronounce free pardon to them all
    That will forsake thee and go home in peace.
 What, Buckingham and Clifford, are ye so brave?
    And you, base peasants, do ye believe him? Will you needs be
    hang'd with your about your necks? Hath my sword therefore broke
    through London gates, that you should leave me at the White Hart
    in Southwark? I thought ye would never have given out these arms
    till you had recovered your ancient freedom.

  CADE.
 I see them lay their  
    heads together to surprise me.

                                             Exeunt some of them
    Follow me, soldiers; we'll devise a mean
    To reconcile you all unto the King.
                   Exeunt




SCENE IX.
 Enter KING, QUEEN, and SOMERSET, on the terrace

  KING HENRY.
 Why, Buckingham, is the traitor Cade surpris'd?
    Or is he but retir'd to make him strong?

     Enter, below, multitudes, with halters about their necks

  CLIFFORD.
 My lord,
    I'll yield myself to prison willingly,
    Or unto death, to do my country good.

                                                Flourish.

Kent.

  CADE.

    Oppose thy steadfast-gazing eyes to mine;
    See if thou canst outface me with thy looks;
    Set limb to limb, and thou art far the lesser;
    Thy hand is but a finger to my fist,
    Thy leg a stick compared with this truncheon;
    My foot shall fight with all the strength thou hast,
    And if mine arm be heaved in the air,
    Thy grave is digg'd already in the earth.

  CADE.
 [Here they  
    fight; CADE falls] O, I am slain! famine and no other hath slain
    me.
 Is't Cade that I have slain, that monstrous traitor?
    Sword, I will hallow thee for this thy deed
    And hang thee o'er my tomb when I am dead.

    Ne'er shall this blood be wiped from thy point,
    But thou shalt wear it as a herald's coat
    To emblaze the honour that thy master got.
                                        [Dies]
  IDEN.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.

Fields between Dartford and Blackheath

Enter YORK, and his army of Irish, with drum and colours

  YORK.
 From Ireland thus comes York to claim his right
    And pluck the crown from feeble Henry's head:
    Ring bells aloud, burn bonfires clear and bright,
    To entertain great England's lawful king.
 Humphrey of Buckingham, I accept thy greeting.
-
    Buckingham, I prithee, pardon me
    That I have given no answer all this while;
    My mind was troubled with deep melancholy.

  YORK.
 Upon thine honour, is he prisoner?
  BUCKINGHAM.

  YORK.
 In all submission and humility
    York doth present himself unto your Highness.
 To heave the traitor Somerset from hence,
    And fight against that monstrous rebel Cade,
    Who since I heard to be discomfited.


                    Enter IDEN, with CADE's head

  IDEN.

    Shall I endure the sight of Somerset?
    False king, why hast thou broken faith with me,
    Knowing how hardly I can brook abuse?
    King did I call thee? No, thou art not king;
    Not fit to govern and rule multitudes,
    Which dar'st not, no, nor canst not rule a traitor.
 O monstrous traitor! I arrest thee, York,
    Of capital treason 'gainst the King and crown.

    Sirrah, call in my sons to be my bail:        Exit attendant
    I know, ere thy will have me go to ward,
    They'll pawn their swords for my enfranchisement.

  QUEEN.
 Call hither Clifford; bid him come amain,
    To say if that the bastard boys of York
    Shall be the surety for their traitor father.


                     Enter CLIFFORD and his SON

  QUEEN.
 And here comes Clifford to deny their bail.

    We are thy sovereign, Clifford, kneel again;
    For thy mistaking so, we pardon thee.
 Ay, Clifford; a bedlam and ambitious humour
    Makes him oppose himself against his king.

  CLIFFORD.
 And if words will not, then our weapons shall.

  RICHARD.
 Oft have I seen a hot o'er weening cur
    Run back and bite, because he was withheld;
    Who, being suffer'd, with the bear's fell paw,
    Hath clapp'd his tail between his legs and cried;  
    And such a piece of service will you do,
    If you oppose yourselves to match Lord Warwick.
 Hence, heap of wrath, foul indigested lump,
    As crooked in thy manners as thy shape!
  YORK.

  CLIFFORD.
 Take heed, lest by your heat you burn yourselves.

  KING HENRY.
 It is great sin to swear unto a sin;
    But greater sin to keep a sinful oath.

  WARWICK.

  CLIFFORD.

  YOUNG CLIFFORD.

  RICHARD.
 Foul stigmatic, that's more than thou canst tell.
 If not in heaven, you'll surely sup in hell.

  CLIFFORD.
 Nor should thy prowess want praise and esteem
    But that 'tis shown ignobly and in treason.
 Thus war hath given thee peace, for thou art still.

    Peace with his soul, heaven, if it be thy will!         Exit  

                     Enter YOUNG CLIFFORD

  YOUNG CLIFFORD.

    Henceforth I will not have to do with pity:
    Meet I an infant of the house of York,
    Into as many gobbets will I cut it
    As wild Medea young Absyrtus did;
    In cruelty will I seek out my fame.

                                              Exit with the body  

       Enter RICHARD and SOMERSET to fight.
 Enter KING, QUEEN, and others

  QUEEN.

    Well, lords, we have not got that which we have;
    'Tis not enough our foes are this time fled,
    Being opposites of such repairing nature.

  YORK.

    What says Lord Warwick? Shall we after them?
  WARWICK.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

London.
 The Parliament House

Alarum.
 Enter DUKE OF YORK, EDWARD, RICHARD, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, WARWICK,
and soldiers, with white roses in their hats

  WARWICK.
 And, brother, here's the Earl of Wiltshire's blood,
    Whom I encount'red as the battles join'd.
  
  RICHARD.
 Speak thou for me, and tell them what I did.
 Victorious Prince of York,
    Before I see thee seated in that throne
    Which now the house of Lancaster usurps,
    I vow by heaven these eyes shall never close.

  RICHARD.
 Enter KING HENRY, CLIFFORD, NORTHUMBERLAND,
        WESTMORELAND, EXETER, and others, with red roses in  
                            their hats

  KING HENRY.

  CLIFFORD.
 'Twas my inheritance, as the earldom was.

  WESTMORELAND.

  CLIFFORD.

  KING HENRY.
 Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it all.
 The Lord Protector lost it, and not I:
    When I was crown'd, I was but nine months old.
 You are old enough now, and yet methinks you lose.

  MONTAGUE.
 Good brother, as thou lov'st and honourest arms,
    Let's fight it out and not stand cavilling thus.

  YORK.
 Plantagenet shall speak first.
 [Aside] I know not what to say; my title's weak.
 Plantagenet, for all the claim thou lay'st,
    Think not that Henry shall be so depos'd.
 O Clifford, how thy words revive my heart!
  YORK.
 Richard Plantagenet,
    Enjoy the kingdom after my decease.
 What good is this to England and himself!
  WESTMORELAND.
 I cannot stay to hear these articles.

  NORTHUMBERLAND.
 Come, cousin, let us tell the Queen these news.
 Ah, Exeter!
  WARWICK.

    But be it as it may.
 [To YORK] I here entail
    The crown to thee and to thine heirs for ever;
    Conditionally, that here thou take an oath
    To cease this civil war, and, whilst I live,
    To honour me as thy king and sovereign,
    And neither by treason nor hostility
    To seek to put me down and reign thyself.
  
                                        [Coming from the throne]
  WARWICK.

  EXETER.
 And I, with grief and sorrow, to the court.
 Who can be patient in such extremes?
    Ah, wretched man! Would I had died a maid,
    And never seen thee, never borne thee son,
    Seeing thou hast prov'd so unnatural a father!
    Hath he deserv'd to lose his birthright thus?
    Hadst thou but lov'd him half so well as I,
    Or felt that pain which I did for him once,
    Or nourish'd him as I did with my blood,
    Thou wouldst have left thy dearest heart-blood there
    Rather than have made that savage duke thine heir,
    And disinherited thine only son.
 Ah, timorous wretch!
    Thou hast undone thyself, thy son, and me;
    And giv'n unto the house of York such head  
    As thou shalt reign but by their sufferance.

    The northern lords that have forsworn thy colours
    Will follow mine, if once they see them spread;
    And spread they shall be, to thy foul disgrace  
    And utter ruin of the house of York.
 Ay, to be murder'd by his enemies.
 When I return with victory from the field
    I'll see your Grace; till then I'll follow her.

  QUEEN MARGARET.
        Exeunt




SCENE II.
 No, I can better play the orator.

  MONTAGUE.
 Mine, boy? Not till King Henry be dead.
 No; God forbid your Grace should be forsworn.

    You, Edward, shall unto my Lord Cobham,
    With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise;
    In them I trust, for they are soldiers,
    Witty, courteous, liberal, full of spirit.
 Sir john and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine uncles!
    You are come to Sandal in a happy hour;
    The army of the Queen mean to besiege us.

  SIR JOHN.
 What, with five thousand men?
  RICHARD.
 Enter RUTLAND and his TUTOR

  RUTLAND.
 And I, my lord, will bear him company.

  RUTLAND.

  CLIFFORD.

  CLIFFORD.
 I never did thee harm; why wilt thou slay me?
  CLIFFORD.
 Enter the DUKE OF YORK

  YORK.
 The army of the Queen hath got the field.

    The sands are numb'red that make up my life;
    Here must I stay, and here my life must end.


         Enter QUEEN MARGARET, CLIFFORD, NORTHUMBERLAND,
               the PRINCE OF WALES, and soldiers

    Come, bloody Clifford, rough Northumberland,
    I dare your quenchless fury to more rage;
    I am your butt, and I abide your shot.
  
    Now Phaethon hath tumbled from his car,
    And made an evening at the noontide prick.

    Why come you not? What! multitudes, and fear?
  CLIFFORD.
 I will not bandy with thee word for word,
    But buckler with thee blows, twice two for one.
 Ay, ay, so strives the woodcock with the gin.
 So doth the cony struggle in the net.
 So triumph thieves upon their conquer'd booty;
    So true men yield, with robbers so o'er-match'd.
 Brave warriors, Clifford and Northumberland,
    Come, make him stand upon this molehill here
    That raught at mountains with outstretched arms,
    Yet parted but the shadow with his hand.
 Nay, stay; let's hear the orisons he makes.
  
  YORK.
 She-wolf of France, but worse than wolves of France,
    Whose tongue more poisons than the adder's tooth!
    How ill-beseeming is it in thy sex
    To triumph like an Amazonian trull
    Upon their woes whom fortune captivates!
    But that thy face is visard-like, unchanging,
    Made impudent with use of evil deeds,
    I would assay, proud queen, to make thee blush.

    O tiger's heart wrapp'd in a woman's hide!
    How couldst thou drain the life-blood of the child,
    To bid the father wipe his eyes withal,
    And yet be seen to bear a woman's face?
    Women are soft, mild, pitiful, and flexible:
    Thou stern, obdurate, flinty, rough, remorseless.

  NORTHUMBERLAND.
 Had he been slaughter-man to all my kin,
    I should not for my life but weep with him,  
    To see how inly sorrow gripes his soul.
 Here's for my oath, here's for my father's death.

    Methought he bore him in the thickest troop
    As doth a lion in a herd of neat;
    Or as a bear, encompass'd round with dogs,
    Who having pinch'd a few and made them cry,
    The rest stand all aloof and bark at him.
 Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun;
    Not separated with the racking clouds,
    But sever'd in a pale clear-shining sky.

    See, see! they join, embrace, and seem to kiss,
    As if they vow'd some league inviolable.

    Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun.
 'Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of.

    Whate'er it bodes, henceforward will I bear
    Upon my target three fair shining suns.


                 Enter a MESSENGER, blowing

    But what art thou, whose heavy looks foretell
    Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue?
  MESSENGER.

  RICHARD.
 Environed he was with many foes,
    And stood against them as the hope of Troy
    Against the Greeks that would have ent'red Troy.

    By many hands your father was subdu'd;
    But only slaught'red by the ireful arm
    Of unrelenting Clifford and the Queen,
    Who crown'd the gracious Duke in high despite,
    Laugh'd in his face; and when with grief he wept,
    The ruthless Queen gave him to dry his cheeks
    A napkin steeped in the harmless blood
    Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford slain;
    And after many scorns, many foul taunts,
    They took his head, and on the gates of York
    They set the same; and there it doth remain,
    The saddest spectacle that e'er I view'd.
  
    Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body
    Might in the ground be closed up in rest!
    For never henceforth shall I joy again;
    Never, O never, shall I see more joy.
 His name that valiant duke hath left with thee;
    His dukedom and his chair with me is left.
 Great Lord of Warwick, if we should recount
    Our baleful news and at each word's deliverance
    Stab poinards in our flesh till all were told,
    The words would add more anguish than the wounds.

    After the bloody fray at Wakefield fought,
    Where your brave father breath'd his latest gasp,
    Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could run,
    Were brought me of your loss and his depart.
 Where is the Duke of Norfolk, gentle Warwick?
    And when came George from Burgundy to England?
  WARWICK.

  RICHARD.

    'Tis love I bear thy glories makes me speak.
 Why, therefore Warwick came to seek you out;
    And therefore comes my brother Montague.
 The proud insulting Queen,
    With Clifford and the haught Northumberland,
    And of their feather many moe proud birds,
    Have wrought the easy-melting King like wax.

    Their power, I think, is thirty thousand strong.
 Lord Warwick, on thy shoulder will I lean;
    And when thou fail'st- as God forbid the hour!-
    Must Edward fall, which peril heaven forfend.
  
  WARWICK.

  RICHARD.
  
  WARWICK.

Before York

Flourish.
 Ay, as the rocks cheer them that fear their wreck-
    To see this sight, it irks my very soul.
 My lord, cheer up your spirits; our foes are nigh,
    And this soft courage makes your followers faint.

    You promis'd knighthood to our forward son:
    Unsheathe your sword and dub him presently.

  PRINCE OF WALES.

  QUEEN MARGARET.

  NORTHUMBERLAND.

  PRINCE OF WALES.
 Ay, crook-back, here I stand to answer thee,
    Or any he, the proudest of thy sort.

  RICHARD.
 'Twas not your valour, Clifford, drove me thence.
 No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.
  
  RICHARD.

  KING HENRY.

  CLIFFORD.

  RICHARD.

    By Him that made us all, I am resolv'd
    That Clifford's manhood lies upon his tongue.

  EDWARD.
  
  WARWICK.
 If thou deny, their blood upon thy head;
    For York in justice puts his armour on.

  PRINCE OF WALES.

  RICHARD.

  QUEEN MARGARET.

    His father revell'd in the heart of France,
    And tam'd the King, and made the Dauphin stoop;
    And had he match'd according to his state,
    He might have kept that glory to this day;
    But when he took a beggar to his bed
    And grac'd thy poor sire with his bridal day,
    Even then that sunshine brew'd a show'r for him
    That wash'd his father's fortunes forth of France
    And heap'd sedition on his crown at home.
 But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring,
    And that thy summer bred us no increase,
    We set the axe to thy usurping root;
    And though the edge hath something hit ourselves,
    Yet know thou, since we have begun to strike,
    We'll never leave till we have hewn thee down,  
    Or bath'd thy growing with our heated bloods.

A field of battle between Towton and Saxton, in Yorkshire

Alarum; excursions.
 Smile, gentle heaven, or strike, ungentle death;
    For this world frowns, and Edward's sun is clouded.
 What hap? What hope of good?

                         Enter GEORGE

  GEORGE.
 Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself?
    Thy brother's blood the thirsty earth hath drunk,
    Broach'd with the steely point of Clifford's lance;
    And in the very pangs of death he cried,
    Like to a dismal clangor heard from far,
    'Warwick, revenge! Brother, revenge my death.
 Then let the earth be drunken with our blood.

    I'll kill my horse, because I will not fly.

    I that did never weep now melt with woe
    That winter should cut off our spring-time so.
 Yet let us all together to our troops,
    And give them leave to fly that will not stay,
    And call them pillars that will stand to us;
    And if we thrive, promise them such rewards
    As victors wear at the Olympian games.

    Forslow no longer; make we hence amain.

    This is the hand that stabbed thy father York;
    And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland;
    And here's the heart that triumphs in their death
    And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother
    To execute the like upon thyself;
    And so, have at thee!                           [They fight]

                 Enter WARWICK; CLIFFORD flies

  RICHARD.

Another part of the field

Alarum.
 This battle fares like to the morning's war,
    When dying clouds contend with growing light,
    What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails,
    Can neither call it perfect day nor night.

    Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind;
    Now one the better, then another best;
    Both tugging to be victors, breast to breast,
    Yet neither conqueror nor conquered.

    And to conclude: the shepherd's homely curds,
    His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle,
    His wonted sleep under a fresh tree's shade,
    All which secure and sweetly he enjoys,
    Is far beyond a prince's delicates-
    His viands sparkling in a golden cup,
    His body couched in a curious bed,
    When care, mistrust, and treason waits on him.


       Alarum.

    This man whom hand to hand I slew in fight
    May be possessed with some store of crowns;
    And I, that haply take them from him now,
    May yet ere night yield both my life and them
    To some man else, as this dead man doth me.

    O heavy times, begetting such events!
    From London by the King was I press'd forth;
    My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man,
    Came on the part of York, press'd by his master;
    And I, who at his hands receiv'd my life,
    Have by my hands of life bereaved him.

    My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks;
    And no more words till they have flow'd their fill.
 O piteous spectacle! O bloody times!
    Whiles lions war and battle for their dens,
    Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity.
 Is this our foeman's face?
    Ah, no, no, no, no, it is mine only son!
    Ah, boy, if any life be left in thee,
    Throw up thine eye! See, see what show'rs arise,
    Blown with the windy tempest of my heart
    Upon thy wounds, that kills mine eye and heart!
    O, pity, God, this miserable age!
    What stratagems, how fell, how butcherly,  
    Erroneous, mutinous, and unnatural,
    This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!
    O boy, thy father gave thee life too soon,
    And hath bereft thee of thy life too late!
  KING HENRY.
 How will my wife for slaughter of my son
    Shed seas of tears, and ne'er be satisfied!
  KING HENRY.
 Was ever son so rued a father's death?  
  FATHER.
 I'll bear thee hence, where I may weep my fill.
 Fly, father, fly; for all your friends are fled,
    And Warwick rages like a chafed bull.
 Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain.
 Away! for vengeance comes along with them.
 Enter EDWARD, GEORGE, RICHARD
               MONTAGUE, WARWICK, and soldiers

  EDWARD.

    But think you, lords, that Clifford fled with them?
  WARWICK.

                                     [CLIFFORD groans, and dies]
  RICHARD.
 Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?
    A deadly groan, like life and death's departing.

  EDWARD.
 From off the gates of York fetch down the head,
    Your father's head, which Clifford placed there;
    Instead whereof let this supply the room.

  RICHARD.

  GEORGE.

  EDWARD.

  RICHARD.
 What, not an oath? Nay, then the world goes hard
    When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath.

  RICHARD.

  WARWICK.
>>



ACT III.
 SCENE I.
 Let me embrace thee, sour adversity,
    For wise men say it is the wisest course.

    She, on his left side, craving aid for Henry:
    He, on his right, asking a wife for Edward.

    She weeps, and says her Henry is depos'd:
    He smiles, and says his Edward is install'd;
    That she, poor wretch, for grief can speak no more;
    Whiles Warwick tells his title, smooths the wrong,
    Inferreth arguments of mighty strength,
    And in conclusion wins the King from her
    With promise of his sister, and what else,
    To strengthen and support King Edward's place.

  KING HENRY.
 My crown is call'd content;
    A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy.

  KING HENRY.

    Go where you will, the King shall be commanded;
    And be you kings: command, and I'll obey.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

    Her suit is now to repossess those lands;
    Which we in justice cannot well deny,
    Because in quarrel of the house of York
    The worthy gentleman did lose his life.
 Your Highness shall do well to grant her suit;
    It were dishonour to deny it her.

  KING EDWARD.

    May it please your Highness to resolve me now;
    And what your pleasure is shall satisfy me.

  GLOUCESTER.

  CLARENCE.

  KING EDWARD.

  CLARENCE.
 [Aside] You shall have four if you'll be rul'd by him.
 Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it, then.
 Lords, give us leave; I'll try this widow's wit.

                              [GLOUCESTER and CLARENCE withdraw]
  KING EDWARD.
 Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?
  LADY GREY.

  KING EDWARD.
 What service wilt thou do me if I give them?
  LADY GREY.

  KING EDWARD.
 Why, then I will do what your Grace commands.
 That's soon perform'd, because I am a subject.

  KING EDWARD.

  LADY GREY.
 The match is made; she seals it with a curtsy.

  LADY GREY.
 My mind will never grant what I perceive
    Your Highness aims at, if I aim aright.
 To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.
 Herein your Highness wrongs both them and me.
 Ay, if thou wilt say ay to my request;
    No, if thou dost say no to my demand.

  KING EDWARD.

  KING EDWARD.

  KING EDWARD.

  CLARENCE.
 To who, my lord?
  KING EDWARD.

  GLOUCESTER.
 By so much is the wonder in extremes.

  KING EDWARD.
 See that he be convey'd unto the Tower.

    And go we, brothers, to the man that took him
    To question of his apprehension.
 Lords, use her honourably.

    And am I, then, a man to be belov'd?
    O monstrous fault to harbour such a thought!  
    Then, since this earth affords no joy to me
    But to command, to check, to o'erbear such
    As are of better person than myself,
    I'll make my heaven to dream upon the crown,
    And whiles I live t' account this world but hell,
    Until my misshap'd trunk that bear this head
    Be round impaled with a glorious crown.

    I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall;
    I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk;
    I'll play the orator as well as Nestor,
    Deceive more slily than Ulysses could,
    And, like a Sinon, take another Troy.
           Exit




SCENE III.
  LEWIS sits, and riseth up again

  LEWIS.
 It ill befits thy state
    And birth that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit.

    Be plain, Queen Margaret, and tell thy grief;
    It shall be eas'd, if France can yield relief.

    Scotland hath will to help, but cannot help;  
    Our people and our peers are both misled,
    Our treasure seiz'd, our soldiers put to flight,
    And, as thou seest, ourselves in heavy plight.

  QUEEN MARGARET.
 Ay, now begins a second storm to rise;
    For this is he that moves both wind and tide.

  QUEEN MARGARET.
 [To BONA] And, gracious madam, in our king's behalf,
    I am commanded, with your leave and favour,
    Humbly to kiss your hand, and with my tongue
    To tell the passion of my sovereign's heart;
    Where fame, late ent'ring at his heedful ears,
    Hath plac'd thy beauty's image and thy virtue.
 Injurious Margaret!
  PRINCE OF WALES.
 And why not Queen?
  WARWICK.
 Because thy father Henry did usurp;
    And thou no more art prince than she is queen.

    From these our Henry lineally descends.

  WARWICK.

  OXFORD.

  WARWICK.
 Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford,  
    Vouchsafe at our request to stand aside
    While I use further conference with Warwick.

  LEWIS.
 Then, Warwick, thus: our sister shall be Edward's.

  QUEEN MARGARET.

    Before thy coming, Lewis was Henry's friend.

    Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand
    That your estate requires and mine can yield.
 Henry now lives in Scotland at his case,
    Where having nothing, nothing can he lose.

  QUEEN MARGARET.

    These from our King unto your Majesty.

  PRINCE OF WALES.
 Nay, mark how Lewis stamps as he were nettled.

  WARWICK.

    I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona,
    And replant Henry in his former state.

  WARWICK.
 So much his friend, ay, his unfeigned friend,  
    That if King Lewis vouchsafe to furnish us
    With some few bands of chosen soldiers,
    I'll undertake to land them on our coast
    And force the tyrant from his seat by war.
 Dear brother, how shall Bona be reveng'd
    But by thy help to this distressed queen?
  QUEEN MARGARET.
 Renowned Prince, how shall poor Henry live
    Unless thou rescue him from foul despair?
  BONA.
 Let me give humble thanks for all at once.
 Then, England's messenger, return in post  
    And tell false Edward, thy supposed king,
    That Lewis of France is sending over masquers
    To revel it with him and his new bride.

  QUEEN MARGARET.
 But, Warwick,
    Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men,
    Shall cross the seas and bid false Edward battle:
    And, as occasion serves, this noble Queen
    And Prince shall follow with a fresh supply.
 Yes, I agree, and thank you for your motion.

    Son Edward, she is fair and virtuous,
    Therefore delay not- give thy hand to Warwick;
    And with thy hand thy faith irrevocable
    That only Warwick's daughter shall be thine.

  PRINCE OF WALES.
 Yes, I accept her, for she well deserves it;
    And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand.

                                  [He gives his hand to WARWICK]
  LEWIS.

    I long till Edward fall by war's mischance
    For mocking marriage with a dame of France.
                   Exit




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.

  CLARENCE.
 Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice
    That you stand pensive as half malcontent?
  CLARENCE.

  GLOUCESTER.
 Not I.
 But the safer when 'tis back'd with France.

  HASTINGS.
 'Tis better using France than trusting France.

    Let us be back'd with God, and with the seas
    Which He hath giv'n for fence impregnable,
    And with their helps only defend ourselves.
 For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves
    To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.

  KING EDWARD.
 Ay, what of that? it was my will and grant;
    And for this once my will shall stand for law.
 Alas, poor Clarence! Is it for a wife
    That thou art malcontent? I will provide thee.

  QUEEN ELIZABETH.

  KING EDWARD.
 These were her words, utt'red with mild disdain:
    'Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly,
    I'll wear the willow-garland for his sake.

    But what said Warwick to these injuries?
  MESSENGER.
'
  KING EDWARD.

                                      Exit, and SOMERSET follows
  GLOUCESTER.
 [Aside] Not I.

    My thoughts aim at a further matter; I
    Stay not for the love of Edward but the crown.

    Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf
    Go levy men and make prepare for war;
    They are already, or quickly will be landed.

                                    Exeunt PEMBROKE and STAFFORD
    But ere I go, Hastings and Montague,
    Resolve my doubt.

  MONTAGUE.
 So God help Montague as he proves true!
  HASTINGS.
 Why, so! then am I sure of victory.
  
    Now therefore let us hence, and lose no hour
    Till we meet Warwick with his foreign pow'r.

    Speak suddenly, my lords- are we all friends?
  CLARENCE.

  WARWICK.
 Come on, my masters, each man take his stand;
    The King by this is set him down to sleep.

  SECOND WATCHMAN.
 O, is it So? But why commands the King
    That his chief followers lodge in towns about him,
    While he himself keeps in the cold field?
  SECOND WATCHMAN.
 GLOUCESTER and HASTINGS fly over the stage

  SOMERSET.

    Though fortune's malice overthrow my state,
    My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.

    My Lord of Somerset, at my request,
    See that forthwith Duke Edward be convey'd
    Unto my brother, Archbishop of York.
 These news, I must confess, are full of grief;
    Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may:
    Warwick may lose that now hath won the day.

  RIVERS.
 But, madam, where is Warwick then become?
  QUEEN ELIZABETH.
 I am inform'd that he comes towards London
    To set the crown once more on Henry's head.

    Guess thou the rest: King Edward's friends must down.

    There shall I rest secure from force and fraud.


             Enter KING EDWARD and a HUNTSMAN with him
  
  HUNTSMAN.
 To Lynn, my lord; and shipt from thence to Flanders.

  KING EDWARD.
 Shield thee from Warwick's frown,
    And pray that I may repossess the crown.

  KING HENRY.

    Therefore, that I may conquer fortune's spite
    By living low where fortune cannot hurt me,
    And that the people of this blessed land
    May not be punish'd with my thwarting stars,
    Warwick, although my head still wear the crown,
    I here resign my government to thee,
    For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.

  WARWICK.

    Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts,
    That no dissension hinder government.

    And, Clarence, now then it is more than needful
    Forthwith that Edward be pronounc'd a traitor,
    And all his lands and goods confiscated.

  KING HENRY.

  CLARENCE.


                          Enter a POST

  WARWICK.

  WARWICK.

                   Exeunt all but SOMERSET, RICHMOND, and OXFORD
  SOMERSET.

    As Henry's late presaging prophecy
    Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond,
    So doth my heart misgive me, in these conflicts,
    What may befall him to his harm and ours.
 Ay, for if Edward repossess the crown,
    'Tis like that Richmond with the rest shall down.

    Come therefore, let's about it speedily.
 Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest,
    Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends,
    And says that once more I shall interchange
    My waned state for Henry's regal crown.
 Why, and I challenge nothing but my dukedom,
    As being well content with that alone.

  GLOUCESTER.

  MAYOR.
 Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery,
    Our trusty friend, unless I be deceiv'd.

  KING EDWARD.

    Why shall we fight, if you pretend no title?
  GLOUCESTER.
 Away with scrupulous wit! Now arms must rule.

  HASTINGS.

    Now for this night let's harbour here in York;
    And when the morning sun shall raise his car
    Above the border of this horizon,
    We'll forward towards Warwick and his mates;  
    For well I wot that Henry is no soldier.
 What counsel, lords? Edward from Belgia,
    With hasty Germans and blunt Hollanders,
    Hath pass'd in safety through the narrow seas
    And with his troops doth march amain to London;
    And many giddy people flock to him.
 Let's levy men and beat him back again.

  KING HENRY.
 Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate!
  MONTAGUE.

                      [Shout within 'A Lancaster! A Lancaster!']
  EXETER.
 Seize on the shame-fac'd Henry, bear him hence;
    And once again proclaim us King of England.


                   Enter SIR JOHN SOMERVILLE

  WARWICK.
 At Southam I did leave him with his forces,
    And do expect him here some two hours hence.
 It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies.

  WARWICK.
 They are at hand, and you shall quickly know.


        March.
 Flourish.

  WARWICK.
 O unbid spite! Is sportful Edward come?
    Where slept our scouts or how are they seduc'd
    That we could hear no news of his repair?
  KING EDWARD.

  WARWICK.
 Why then 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift.

  GLOUCESTER.
 Come, Warwick, take the time; kneel down, kneel down.
 O, welcome, Oxford! for we want thy help.

  
             Enter CLARENCE, with drum and colours

  WARWICK.
 Come, Clarence, come.
 Thou wilt if Warwick call.

    I will not ruinate my father's house,
    Who gave his blood to lime the stones together,
    And set up Lancaster.
 Now welcome more, and ten times more belov'd,
    Than if thou never hadst deserv'd our hate.
 Enter KING EDWARD, bringing forth WARWICK, wounded

  KING EDWARD.
 So, lie thou there.
 Die thou, and die our fear;
    For Warwick was a bug that fear'd us all.
 Ah, who is nigh? Come to me, friend or foe,
    And tell me who is victor, York or Warwick?
    Why ask I that? My mangled body shows,
    My blood, my want of strength, my sick heart shows,
    That I must yield my body to the earth
    And, by my fall, the conquest to my foe.


                  Enter OXFORD and SOMERSET

  SOMERSET.

    The Queen from France hath brought a puissant power;
    Even now we heard the news.

    Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead.
 The Queen is valued thirty thousand strong,
    And Somerset, with Oxford, fled to her.

    If she have time to breathe, be well assur'd  
    Her faction will be full as strong as ours.
 are advertis'd by our loving friends
    That they do hold their course toward Tewksbury;
    We, having now the best at Barnet field,
    Will thither straight, for willingness rids way;
    And as we march our strength will be augmented
    In every county as we go along.

    Strike up the drum; cry 'Courage!' and away.

Plains wear Tewksbury

Flourish.
 March.
 Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their
      loss,
    But cheerly seek how to redress their harms.

    And what is Edward but a ruthless sea?
    What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit?
    And Richard but a ragged fatal rock?
    All these the enemies to our poor bark.
 Thanks, gentle Somerset; sweet Oxford, thanks.

  PRINCE OF WALES.


                        Enter a MESSENGER

  MESSENGER.
 I thought no less.

    Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords.

  QUEEN MARGARET.

    Therefore, no more but this: Henry, your sovereign,
    Is prisoner to the foe; his state usurp'd,
    His realm a slaughter-house, his subjects slain,
    His statutes cancell'd, and his treasure spent;
    And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil.
 Then, in God's name, lords,
    Be valiant, and give signal to the fight.

  SOMERSET.


                Enter soldiers, with PRINCE EDWARD
  
  KING EDWARD.

    Suppose that I am now my father's mouth;
    Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou,
    Whilst I propose the self-same words to the
    Which, traitor, thou wouldst have me answer to.

  GLOUCESTER.

  QUEEN MARGARET.
 Nay, take away this scolding crookback rather.
 I know my duty; you are all undutiful.
 And there's for twitting me with perjury.
 Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done to much.

    Butchers and villains! bloody cannibals!
    How sweet a plant have you untimely cropp'd!
    You have no children, butchers, if you had,
    The thought of them would have stirr'd up remorse.
 Away with her; go, bear her hence perforce.
 Nay, never bear me hence; dispatch me here.

    Here sheathe thy sword; I'll pardon thee my death.

  CLARENCE.
 Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?
  QUEEN MARGARET.

    'Twas sin before, but now 'tis charity.

  KING EDWARD.

  QUEEN MARGARET.

    'Tis sin to flatter; 'good' was little better.
'
  GLOUCESTER.

                                                 Exit LIEUTENANT
  KING HENRY.
 So flies the reckless shepherd from the wolf;
    So first the harmless sheep doth yield his fleece,
    And next his throat unto the butcher's knife.

    What scene of death hath Roscius now to act?
  GLOUCESTER.

  GLOUCESTER.

  KING HENRY.
 Think'st thou I am an executioner?
  KING HENRY.
 Thy son I kill'd for his presumption.
 I'll hear no more.
 Die, prophet, in thy speech.
 Ay, and for much more slaughter after this.

    See how my sword weeps for the poor King's death.

    I have no brother, I am like no brother;
    And this word 'love,' which greybeards call divine,
    Be resident in men like one another,
    And not in me! I am myself alone.

    What valiant foemen, like to autumn's corn,
    Have we mow'd down in tops of all their pride!
    Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renown'd
    For hardy and undoubted champions;
    Two Cliffords, as the father and the son;
    And two Northumberlands- two braver men
    Ne'er spurr'd their coursers at the trumpet's sound;
    With them the two brave bears, Warwick and Montague,
    That in their chains fetter'd the kingly lion
    And made the forest tremble when they roar'd.

  KING EDWARD.


    I come no more to make you laugh; things now
    That bear a weighty and a serious brow,
    Sad, high, and working, full of state and woe,
    Such noble scenes as draw the eye to flow,
    We now present.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE

PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.
 SCENE 1.


London.
 The palace

Enter the DUKE OF NORFOLK at one door; at the other,
the DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM and the LORD ABERGAVENNY

  BUCKINGHAM.
 How have ye done
    Since last we saw in France?
  NORFOLK.

  NORFOLK.
 To-day the French,
    All clinquant, all in gold, like heathen gods,
    Shone down the English; and to-morrow they
    Made Britain India: every man that stood
    Show'd like a mine.
 Now this masque
    Was cried incomparable; and th' ensuing night
    Made it a fool and beggar.
 All was royal:
    To the disposing of it nought rebell'd;
    Order gave each thing view.

  BUCKINGHAM.
 I do know
    Kinsmen of mine, three at the least, that have
    By this so sicken'd their estates that never  
    They shall abound as formerly.

  ABERGAVENNY.

  NORFOLK.
 Lo, where comes that rock
    That I advise your shunning.
 Here, so please you.
 Well, we shall then know more, and Buckingham
    shall lessen this big look.
 A beggar's book
    Outworths a noble's blood.

  NORFOLK.

  BUCKINGHAM.

  BUCKINGHAM.
 Now this follows,
    Which, as I take it, is a kind of puppy
    To th' old dam treason: Charles the Emperor,  
    Under pretence to see the Queen his aunt-
    For 'twas indeed his colour, but he came
    To whisper Wolsey-here makes visitation-
    His fears were that the interview betwixt
    England and France might through their amity
    Breed him some prejudice; for from this league
    Peep'd harms that menac'd him-privily
    Deals with our Cardinal; and, as I trow-
    Which I do well, for I am sure the Emperor
    Paid ere he promis'd; whereby his suit was granted
    Ere it was ask'd-but when the way was made,
    And pav'd with gold, the Emperor thus desir'd,
    That he would please to alter the King's course,
    And break the foresaid peace.

  SERGEANT.

  BUCKINGHAM.
 Lo you, my lord,
    The net has fall'n upon me! I shall perish
    Under device and practice.

  BRANDON.

  BUCKINGHAM.

    I am the shadow of poor Buckingham,
    Whose figure even this instant cloud puts on
    By dark'ning my clear sun.

    Exeunt




ACT I.


London.
 The CARDINAL places himself
under the KING'S feet on his right side

  KING.
 Let be call'd before us
    That gentleman of Buckingham's.
 In person
    I'll hear his confessions justify;
    And point by point the treasons of his master
    He shall again relate.
 Half your suit
    Never name to us: you have half our power.

  KING.
 Lady mine, proceed.
 Taxation!
    Wherein? and what taxation? My Lord Cardinal,
    You that are blam'd for it alike with us,
    Know you of this taxation?
  WOLSEY.
 Please you, sir,
    I know but of a single part in aught  
    Pertains to th' state, and front but in that file
    Where others tell steps with me.
 These exactions,
    Whereof my sovereign would have note, they are
    Most pestilent to th' hearing; and to bear 'em
    The back is sacrifice to th' load.

  KING.
 And for me,
    I have no further gone in this than by
    A single voice; and that not pass'd me but
    By learned approbation of the judges.
 If we shall stand still,
    In fear our motion will be mock'd or carp'd at,
    We should take root here where we sit, or sit
    State-statues only.

    We must not rend our subjects from our laws,
    And stick them in our will.

  WOLSEY.
 I shall anon advise you
    Further in the proceeding.
 This man so complete,
    Who was enroll'd 'mongst wonders, and when we,
    Almost with ravish'd list'ning, could not find
    His hour of speech a minute-he, my lady,
    Hath into monstrous habits put the graces
    That once were his, and is become as black
    As if besmear'd in hell.
 Stand forth, and with bold spirit relate what you,
    Most like a careful subject, have collected  
    Out of the Duke of Buckingham.

  KING.
 These very words
    I've heard him utter to his son-in-law,
    Lord Aberga'ny, to whom by oath he menac'd
    Revenge upon the Cardinal.
 Presently the Duke
    Said 'twas the fear indeed and that he doubted
    'Twould prove the verity of certain words
    Spoke by a holy monk 'that oft' says he
    'Hath sent to me, wishing me to permit
    John de la Car, my chaplain, a choice hour
    To hear from him a matter of some moment;  
    Whom after under the confession's seal
    He solemnly had sworn that what he spoke
    My chaplain to no creature living but
    To me should utter, with demure confidence
    This pausingly ensu'd: "Neither the King nor's heirs,
    Tell you the Duke, shall prosper; bid him strive
    To gain the love o' th' commonalty; the Duke
    Shall govern England.
 If I know you well,
    You were the Duke's surveyor, and lost your office
    On the complaint o' th' tenants.

  SURVEYOR.

    I told my lord the Duke, by th' devil's illusions
    The monk might be deceiv'd, and that 'twas dangerous
      for him  
    To ruminate on this so far, until
    It forg'd him some design, which, being believ'd,
    It was much like to do.

  KING.
 'If' quoth he 'I for this had been committed-
    As to the Tower I thought-I would have play'd
    The part my father meant to act upon  
    Th' usurper Richard; who, being at Salisbury,
    Made suit to come in's presence, which if granted,
    As he made semblance of his duty, would
    Have put his knife into him.
 God mend all!
  KING.


London.
 Is't possible the spells of France should juggle
    Men into such strange mysteries?
  SANDYS.
 One would take it,
    That never saw 'em pace before, the spavin
    Or springhalt reign'd among 'em.
 What is't for?
  LOVELL.

  LOVELL.
 Ay, marry,
    There will be woe indeed, lords: the sly whoresons
    Have got a speeding trick to lay down ladies.

  SANDYS.
 Now
    An honest country lord, as I am, beaten
    A long time out of play, may bring his plainsong  
    And have an hour of hearing; and, by'r Lady,
    Held current music too.
 O, 'tis true;
    This night he makes a supper, and a great one,
    To many lords and ladies; there will be
    The beauty of this kingdom, I'll assure you.

  CHAMBERLAIN.
 He may, my lord; has wherewithal.
 In him  
    Sparing would show a worse sin than ill doctrine:
    Men of his way should be most liberal,
    They are set here for examples.


London.
 The Presence Chamber in York Place

Hautboys.

  CHAMBERLAIN.
 You are young, Sir Harry Guildford.

  CHAMBERLAIN.
  
  SANDYS.
 By your leave, sweet ladies.

                 [Seats himself between ANNE BULLEN and another lady]
    If I chance to talk a little wild, forgive me;
    I had it from my father.
 Was he mad, sir?
  SANDYS.

    But he would bite none; just as I do now,
    He would kiss you twenty with a breath.
 That noble lady  
    Or gentleman that is not freely merry
    Is not my friend.
 Cheer your neighbours.
 Gentlemen,
    Whose fault is this?
  SANDYS.
 The red wine first must rise
    In their fair cheeks, my lord; then we shall have 'em
    Talk us to silence.

  ANNE.

  SANDYS.
 You cannot show me.
 Th' have left their barge and landed,
    And hither make, as great ambassadors
    From foreign princes.

    A good digestion to you all; and once more
    I show'r a welcome on ye; welcome all.


      Hautboys.
 Pray tell 'em thus much from me:
    There should be one amongst 'em, by his person,
    More worthy this place than myself; to whom,
    If I but knew him, with my love and duty
    I would surrender it.
 Let me see, then.

    You are a churchman, or, I'll tell you, Cardinal,
    I should judge now unhappily.

  WOLSEY.
 O, God save ye!
    Ev'n to the Hall, to hear what shall become
    Of the great Duke of Buckingham.
 I'll save you
    That labour, sir.
 All's now done but the ceremony
    Of bringing back the prisoner.
 Were you there?
  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 Yes, truly is he, and condemn'd upon't.

  SECOND GENTLEMAN.
 I am sorry for't.
 The great Duke.

    The King's attorney, on the contrary,
    Urg'd on the examinations, proofs, confessions,
    Of divers witnesses; which the Duke desir'd
    To have brought, viva voce, to his face;
    At which appear'd against him his surveyor,
    Sir Gilbert Peck his chancellor, and John Car,
    Confessor to him, with that devil-monk,
    Hopkins, that made this mischief.

  SECOND GENTLEMAN.
 The same.
 'Tis likely,
    By all conjectures: first, Kildare's attainder,
    Then deputy of Ireland, who remov'd,
    Earl Surrey was sent thither, and in haste too,
    Lest he should help his father.

  BUCKINGHAM.
 To th' water side I must conduct your Grace;
    Then give my charge up to Sir Nicholas Vaux,
    Who undertakes you to your end.

  BUCKINGHAM.

    My noble father, Henry of Buckingham,
    Who first rais'd head against usurping Richard,
    Flying for succour to his servant Banister,
    Being distress'd, was by that wretch betray'd
    And without trial fell; God's peace be with him!  
    Henry the Seventh succeeding, truly pitying
    My father's loss, like a most royal prince,
    Restor'd me to my honours, and out of ruins
    Made my name once more noble.
 All good people,  
    Pray for me! I must now forsake ye; the last hour
    Of my long weary life is come upon me.
 Let me have it;
    I do not talk much.
 Did you not of late days hear
    A buzzing of a separation
    Between the King and Katharine?
  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 Yes, but it held not;
    For when the King once heard it, out of anger
    He sent command to the Lord Mayor straight
    To stop the rumour and allay those tongues
    That durst disperse it.
 I think you have hit the mark; but is't
        not cruel
    That she should feel the smart of this? The Cardinal
    Will have his will, and she must fall.
 'Tis woeful.


London.
 They were
    young and handsome, and of the best breed in the north.
 Well, let him have them.

    He will have all, I think.
 It seems the marriage with his brother's wife
    Has crept too near his conscience.

  NORFOLK.

  SUFFOLK.

  NORFOLK.

    Health to your lordships!
  NORFOLK.
  [To WOLSEY]  My good lord, have great care
    I be not found a talker.

  WOLSEY.

    I would your Grace would give us but an hour
    Of private conference.
  [Aside to SUFFOLK]  This priest has no pride in him!
  SUFFOLK.
  [Aside to NORFOLK]  Not to speak of!
    I would not be so sick though for his place.

    But this cannot continue.
  [Aside to SUFFOLK]  If it do,
    I'll venture one have-at-him.

  KING.

    They have sent me such a man I would have wish'd for.
 The Queen shall be acquainted
    Forthwith for what you come.
 God forbid else.
                   [Walks and whispers]
  CAMPEIUS.
 My Lord of York, was not one Doctor Pace
    In this man's place before him?
  WOLSEY.
 Yes, he was.
 For living murmurers
    There's places of rebuke.
 O, my lord,  
    Would it not grieve an able man to leave
    So sweet a bedfellow? But, conscience, conscience!
    O, 'tis a tender place! and I must leave her.

  OLD LADY.
 Verily,
    I swear 'tis better to be lowly born
    And range with humble livers in content
    Than to be perk'd up in a glist'ring grief
    And wear a golden sorrow.

  OLD LADY.

  ANNE.
 No, in truth.
 If your back
    Cannot vouchsafe this burden, 'tis too weak
    Ever to get a boy.

  ANNE.

    Our mistress' sorrows we were pitying.
 Now, I pray God, amen!
  CHAMBERLAIN.
 This is strange to me.
 Have you heard it?
  ANNE.

  OLD LADY.
 By this time
    I know your back will bear a duchess.
 Pray, do not deliver
    What here y' have heard to her.


London.
 The KING takes place under the cloth of state;
the two CARDINALS sit under him as judges.
 The QUEEN takes place
some distance from the KING.
 The BISHOPS place themselves on each side
of the court, in manner of consistory; below them the SCRIBES.
 Whilst our commission from Rome is read,
    Let silence be commanded.

  WOLSEY.
 Be't so; proceed.

  SCRIBE.
 Sir, I desire you do me right and justice,
    And to bestow your pity on me; for
    I am a most poor woman and a stranger,
    Born out of your dominions, having here
    No judge indifferent, nor no more assurance
    Of equal friendship and proceeding.
 It is not to be question'd  
    That they had gather'd a wise council to them
    Of every realm, that did debate this business,
    Who deem'd our marriage lawful.
 Your pleasure, madam?
  QUEEN KATHARINE.
 Madam, you do me wrong:
    I have no spleen against you, nor injustice
    For you or any; how far I have proceeded,
    Or how far further shall, is warranted
    By a commission from the Consistory,
    Yea, the whole Consistory of Rome.
 You charge me
    That I have blown this coal: I do deny it.

    The King is present; if it be known to him
    That I gainsay my deed, how may he wound,
    And worthily, my falsehood! Yea, as much
    As you have done my truth.
 If he know
    That I am free of your report, he knows
    I am not of your wrong.

  QUEEN KATHARINE.

    You have, by fortune and his Highness' favours,
    Gone slightly o'er low steps, and now are mounted
    Where pow'rs are your retainers, and your words,
    Domestics to you, serve your will as't please
    Yourself pronounce their office.
 I must tell you
    You tender more your person's honour than
    Your high profession spiritual; that again
    I do refuse you for my judge and here,
    Before you all, appeal unto the Pope,
    To bring my whole cause 'fore his Holiness
    And to be judg'd by him.

  GENTLEMAN USHER.
 Pray you pass on.
           Exeunt QUEEN and her attendants
  KING.
 She's noble born;
    And like her true nobility she has
    Carried herself towards me.

  WOLSEY.
 My Lord Cardinal,
    I do excuse you; yea, upon mine honour,
    I free you from't.
 By some of these
    The Queen is put in anger.
 This respite shook
    The bosom of my conscience, enter'd me,
    Yea, with a splitting power, and made to tremble
    The region of my breast, which forc'd such way
    That many maz'd considerings did throng
    And press'd in with this caution.
 Hence I took a thought
    This was a judgment on me, that my kingdom,
    Well worthy the best heir o' th' world, should not
    Be gladded in't by me.
 Thus hulling in
    The wild sea of my conscience, I did steer
    Toward this remedy, whereupon we are
    Now present here together; that's to say
    I meant to rectify my conscience, which
    I then did feel full sick, and yet not well,
    By all the reverend fathers of the land
    And doctors learn'd.

  KING.
 Unsolicited
    I left no reverend person in this court,
    But by particular consent proceeded
    Under your hands and seals; therefore, go on,
    For no dislike i' th' world against the person
    Of the good Queen, but the sharp thorny points
    Of my alleged reasons, drives this forward.
 -Break up the court;
    I say, set on.


London.


        Every thing that heard him play,
        Even the billows of the sea,
          Hung their heads and then lay by.
 Peace to your Highness!
  QUEEN KATHARINE.
 May it please you, noble madam, to withdraw
    Into your private chamber, we shall give you
    The full cause of our coming.
 Would all other women
    Could speak this with as free a soul as I do!
    My lords, I care not-so much I am happy
    Above a number-if my actions
    Were tried by ev'ry tongue, ev'ry eye saw 'em,
    Envy and base opinion set against 'em,
    I know my life so even.
 Tanta est erga te mentis integritas, regina serenis-sima-
  QUEEN KATHARINE.

  QUEEN KATHARINE.
 Madam, you wrong the King's love with these fears;
    Your hopes and friends are infinite.
 I would your Grace
    Would leave your griefs, and take my counsel.
 'Twill be much
    Both for your honour better and your cause;
    For if the trial of the law o'ertake ye  
    You'll part away disgrac'd.

  CAMPEIUS.
 Pray hear me.

    What will become of me now, wretched lady?
    I am the most unhappy woman living.

  WOLSEY.
 If your Grace
    Could but be brought to know our ends are honest,
    You'd feel more comfort.
 You wrong your virtues
    With these weak women's fears.
 The palace

Enter the DUKE OF NORFOLK, the DUKE OF SUFFOLK, the EARL OF SURREY,
and the LORD CHAMBERLAIN

  NORFOLK.

  SURREY.
 Most Strangely.
 Has the King this?
  SUFFOLK.

  SURREY.
 But in this point
    All his tricks founder, and he brings his physic
    After his patient's death: the King already
    Hath married the fair lady.
 Now, all my joy
    Trace the conjunction!
  SUFFOLK.
 But, my lords,
    She is a gallant creature, and complete
    In mind and feature.
 But will the King
    Digest this letter of the Cardinal's?
    The Lord forbid!
  NORFOLK.
 Marry, amen!
  SUFFOLK.
 Cardinal Campeius
    Is stol'n away to Rome; hath ta'en no leave;  
    Has left the cause o' th' King unhandled, and
    Is posted, as the agent of our Cardinal,
    To second all his plot.

  NORFOLK.

  WOLSEY.
  
  WOLSEY.

    Anne Bullen! No, I'll no Anne Bullens for him;
    There's more in't than fair visage.
 Bullen!
    No, we'll no Bullens.
 The Marchioness of Pembroke!
  NORFOLK.
 He's discontented.
 What though I know her virtuous
    And well deserving? Yet I know her for
    A spleeny Lutheran; and not wholesome to
    Our cause that she should lie i' th' bosom of  
    Our hard-rul'd King.
 What piles of wealth hath he accumulated
    To his own portion! And what expense by th' hour
    Seems to flow from him! How, i' th' name of thrift,
    Does he rake this together?-Now, my lords,
    Saw you the Cardinal?
  NORFOLK.
 My lord, we have
    Stood here observing him.
 Some strange commotion
    Is in his brain: he bites his lip and starts,
    Stops on a sudden, looks upon the ground,  
    Then lays his finger on his temple; straight
    Springs out into fast gait; then stops again,
    Strikes his breast hard; and anon he casts
    His eye against the moon.

  KING.
 This morning
    Papers of state he sent me to peruse,
    As I requir'd; and wot you what I found
    There-on my conscience, put unwittingly?
    Forsooth, an inventory, thus importing
    The several parcels of his plate, his treasure,
    Rich stuffs, and ornaments of household; which
    I find at such proud rate that it outspeaks
    Possession of a subject.
 It's heaven's will;
    Some spirit put this paper in the packet
    To bless your eye withal.
 Good, my lord,
    You are full of heavenly stuff, and bear the inventory
    Of your best graces in your mind; the which
    You were now running o'er.
 'Tis well said again;
    And 'tis a kind of good deed to say well;
    And yet words are no deeds.
 Since I had my office
    I have kept you next my heart; have not alone
    Employ'd you where high profits might come home,
    But par'd my present havings to bestow
    My bounties upon you.
 Have I not made you
    The prime man of the state? I pray you tell me  
    If what I now pronounce you have found true;
    And, if you may confess it, say withal
    If you are bound to us or no.
 What say you?
  WOLSEY.
 My sovereign, I confess your royal graces,
    Show'r'd on me daily, have been more than could
    My studied purposes requite; which went
    Beyond all man's endeavours.
 My endeavours,
    Have ever come too short of my desires,
    Yet fil'd with my abilities; mine own ends
    Have been mine so that evermore they pointed
    To th' good of your most sacred person and
    The profit of the state.
 'Tis nobly spoken.
  
    Take notice, lords, he has a loyal breast,
    For you have seen him open 't.
 Nay then, farewell!
    I have touch'd the highest point of all my greatness,
    And from that full meridian of my glory
    I haste now to my setting.
 I shall fall
    Like a bright exhalation in the evening,
    And no man see me more.
 Hear the King's pleasure, Cardinal, who commands you
    To render up the great seal presently
    Into our hands, and to confine yourself  
    To Asher House, my Lord of Winchester's,
    Till you hear further from his Highness.

  WOLSEY.

    The heads of all thy brother cardinals,
    With thee and all thy best parts bound together,
    Weigh'd not a hair of his.
 Plague of your policy!
    You sent me deputy for Ireland;
    Far from his succour, from the King, from all
    That might have mercy on the fault thou gav'st him;
    Whilst your great goodness, out of holy pity,
    Absolv'd him with an axe.

  WOLSEY.
 This, and all else  
    This talking lord can lay upon my credit,
    I answer is most false.
 The Duke by law
    Found his deserts; how innocent I was
    From any private malice in his end,
    His noble jury and foul cause can witness.
 My lords
    Can ye endure to hear this arrogance?
    And from this fellow? If we live thus tamely,
    To be thus jaded by a piece of scarlet,
    Farewell nobility! Let his Grace go forward
    And dare us with his cap like larks.
 So much fairer  
    And spotless shall mine innocence arise,
    When the King knows my truth.
 This cannot save you.

    I thank my memory I yet remember
    Some of these articles; and out they shall.
 If I blush,
    It is to see a nobleman want manners.

  NORFOLK.

  SURREY.
 That out of mere ambition you have caus'd
    Your holy hat to be stamp'd on the King's coin.
 Many more there are,
    Which, since they are of you, and odious,
    I will not taint my mouth with.

  CHAMBERLAIN.
 Lord Cardinal, the King's further pleasure is-
    Because all those things you have done of late,
    By your power legatine within this kingdom,
    Fall into th' compass of a praemunire-
    That therefore such a writ be sued against you:
    To forfeit all your goods, lands, tenements,
    Chattels, and whatsoever, and to be
    Out of the King's protection.
 What, amaz'd
    At my misfortunes? Can thy spirit wonder
    A great man should decline? Nay, an you weep,
    I am fall'n indeed.

    O, 'tis a burden, Cromwell, 'tis a burden
    Too heavy for a man that hopes for heaven!
  CROMWELL.
 The heaviest and the worst
    Is your displeasure with the King.

  WOLSEY.
 He will advance thee;
    Some little memory of me will stir him-
    I know his noble nature-not to let
    Thy hopeful service perish too.
  
  CROMWELL.

    The King shall have my service; but my prayers
    For ever and for ever shall be yours.

    Mark but my fall and that that ruin'd me.
 Be just, and fear not;
    Let all the ends thou aim'st at be thy country's,
    Thy God's, and truth's; then, if thou fall'st, O Cromwell,
    Thou fall'st a blessed martyr!
    Serve the King, and-prithee lead me in.
 O Cromwell, Cromwell!
    Had I but serv'd my God with half the zeal
    I serv'd my King, he would not in mine age
    Have left me naked to mine enemies.


A street in Westminster

Enter two GENTLEMEN, meeting one another

  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 You come to take your stand here, and
      behold
    The Lady Anne pass from her coronation?
  SECOND GENTLEMAN.

  FIRST GENTLEMAN.

  SECOND GENTLEMAN.
 The citizens,
    I am sure, have shown at full their royal minds-
    As, let 'em have their rights, they are ever forward-
    In celebration of this day with shows,
    Pageants, and sights of honour.

  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 Yes; 'tis the list
    Of those that claim their offices this day,
    By custom of the coronation.

  SECOND GENTLEMAN.
 Then two JUDGES.
 With him, the EARL OF SURREY,
       bearing the rod of silver with the dove, crowned with an
       earl's coronet.
 Collars of Esses.

    9.
 The old DUCHESS OF NORFOLK, in a coronal of gold
       wrought with flowers, bearing the QUEEN'S train.

   10.
 A bold brave gentleman.
 Yes.

  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 These are stars indeed,
    And sometimes falling ones.

                   Exit Procession, with a great flourish of trumpets

               Enter a third GENTLEMAN

    God save you, sir! Where have you been broiling?
  THIRD GENTLEMAN.
 You saw
    The ceremony?
  THIRD GENTLEMAN.

  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 As well as I am able.
 But what follow'd?
  THIRD GENTLEMAN.
' So she parted,
    And with the same full state pac'd back again
    To York Place, where the feast is held.
 What two reverend bishops
    Were those that went on each side of the Queen?
  THIRD GENTLEMAN.
 When it comes,
    Cranmer will find a friend will not shrink from him.
 The King has made him Master
    O' th' jewel House,
    And one, already, of the Privy Council.

    Come, gentlemen, ye shall go my way, which
    Is to th' court, and there ye shall be my guests:
    Something I can command.
 O Griffith, sick to death!
    My legs like loaden branches bow to th' earth,
    Willing to leave their burden.

    So-now, methinks, I feel a little ease.

  GRIFFITH.
  
  GRIFFITH.

    He was a scholar, and a ripe and good one;
    Exceeding wise, fair-spoken, and persuading;
    Lofty and sour to them that lov'd him not,
    But to those men that sought him sweet as summer.
 They
      first congee unto her, then dance; and, at certain
      changes, the first two hold a spare garland over her
      head, at which the other four make reverent curtsies.
 I shall, assuredly.
 An't like your Grace-
  KATHARINE.
 Go to, kneel.

  CAPUCIUS.

  KATHARINE.
 O, my Lord,  
    The times and titles now are alter'd strangely
    With me since first you knew me.

  KATHARINE.
 No, madam.
 Sir, I most humbly pray you to deliver
    This to my lord the King.
  
    The last is for my men-they are the poorest,
    But poverty could never draw 'em from me-
    That they may have their wages duly paid 'em,
    And something over to remember me by.

  CAPUCIUS.
 By heaven, I will,
    Or let me lose the fashion of a man!
  KATHARINE.
 I thank you, honest lord.
 Embalm me,
    Then lay me forth; although unqueen'd, yet like
    A queen, and daughter to a king, inter me.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
