Windsor.
 A street

Enter MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS QUICKLY, and WILLIAM

  MRS.
 I'll be with her by and by; I'll but bring my
    young man here to school.
 Look where his master comes;
    'tis a playing day, I see.
 Blessing of his heart!
  MRS.

  MRS.

  EVANS.
 Two.

  QUICKLY.
'
  EVANS.
 A pebble.
 No, it is 'lapis'; I pray you remember in your prain.

  WILLIAM.
 Lapis.

  EVANS.

    Accusativo, hung, hang, hog.
 Remember, William: focative is caret.
 Genitive: horum, harum, horum.

  MRS.
                 Exit SIR HUGH
    Get you home, boy.
 Come, we stay too long.
 Mistress Ford, your sorrow hath eaten up my
    sufferance.
 He's a-birding, sweet Sir John.
  [Within]  What hoa, gossip Ford, what hoa!
  MRS.
 FORD.
 PAGE.
 PAGE.
 No, certainly.
 I am glad the fat knight
    is not here.
 Why, does he talk of him?
  MRS.

  MRS.
 How near is he, Mistress Page?
  MRS.
 FORD.
 What a woman are you! Away with him,
    away with him; better shame than murder.

  MRS.
 Which way should he go? How should I bestow
    him? Shall I put him into the basket again?

                  Re-enter FALSTAFF

  FALSTAFF.

  MRS.

  MRS.
 Go, go, sweet Sir John.
 Mistress Page and I will
    look some linen for your head.
                         Exit FALSTAFF
  MRS.
 I would my husband would meet him in this
    shape; he cannot abide the old woman of Brainford; he
    swears she's a witch, forbade her my house, and hath
    threat'ned to beat her.
 Ay, in good sadness is he; and talks of the basket
    too, howsoever he hath had intelligence.

  MRS.
 I'll first direct my men what they shall do with
    the basket.
 Hang him, dishonest varlet! we cannot misuse
    him enough.
 Come, come, take it up.

  SECOND SERVANT.
 Ay, but if it prove true, Master Page, have you any
    way then to unfool me again? Set down the basket, villain!
    Somebody call my wife.

                           [Pulling clothes out of the basket]
  PAGE.
 I shall find you anon.

  MRS.
 FORD.

  SHALLOW.

  PAGE.
 She works by
    charms, by spells, by th' figure, and such daub'ry as this
    is, beyond our element.
 Nay, good sweet husband! Good gentlemen, let
    him not strike the old woman.
 PAGE.

  FORD.
 Hang her, witch!
  EVANS.
 By yea and no, I think the oman is a witch indeed; I
    like not when a oman has a great peard; I spy a great peard
    under his muffler.
 FORD.
 FORD.
 Shall we tell our husbands how we have serv'd
    him?
  MRS.
 Sir, the Germans desire to have three of your
    horses; the Duke himself will be to-morrow at court, and
    they are going to meet him.

  PAGE.

  FORD.
 Pardon me, wife.
 Henceforth, do what thou wilt;
    I rather will suspect the sun with cold
    Than thee with wantonness.
 There is no better way than that they spoke of.
 There is an old tale goes that Heme the Hunter,
    Sometime a keeper here in Windsor Forest,
    Doth all the winter-time, at still midnight,
    Walk round about an oak, with great ragg'd horns;
    And there he blasts the tree, and takes the cattle,
    And makes milch-kine yield blood, and shakes a chain
    In a most hideous and dreadful manner.

    You have heard of such a spirit, and well you know
    The superstitious idle-headed eld
    Receiv'd, and did deliver to our age,  
    This tale of Heme the Hunter for a truth.

  PAGE.
 Why yet there want not many that do fear
    In deep of night to walk by this Herne's oak.

  FORD.
 That will be excellent.
-Go, send to Falstaff straight.

  FORD.

  MRS.
               Exeunt PAGE, FORD, and EVANS
  MRS.

                                                  Exit MRS.

    That Slender, though well landed, is an idiot;
    And he my husband best of all affects.
      Exit




SCENE 5.
 Marry, sir, I come to speak with Sir John Falstaff
    from Master Slender.

  SIMPLE.

    Bully knight! Bully Sir John! Speak from thy lungs
    military.

  FALSTAFF.
  [Above]  How now, mine host?
  HOST.
 There was, mine host, an old fat woman even
    now with, me; but she's gone.
 Pray you, sir, was't not the wise woman of
    Brainford?
  FALSTAFF.
 What would you
    with her?
  SIMPLE.

  SIMPLE.
 I would I could have spoken with the woman
    herself; I had other things to have spoken with her too,  
    from him.
 What are they? Let us know.

  SIMPLE.
 I may not conceal them, sir.
.
 'Tis, 'tis his fortune.

  SIMPLE.
 They are gone but to meet the Duke, villain; do not
    say they be fled.


                 Enter SIR HUGH EVANS

  EVANS.
 What is the matter, sir?
  EVANS.
 Have a care of your entertainments.
 By my
    trot, dere is no duke that the court is know to come; I
    tell you for good will.
 Adieu.

                                        Exeunt HOST and BARDOLPH
  FALSTAFF.
 From the two parties, forsooth.
 And have not they suffer'd? Yes, I warrant;
    speciously one of them; Mistress Ford, good heart, is beaten
    black and blue, that you cannot see a white spot about her.
  
  FALSTAFF.

  FALSTAFF.
 Come up into my chamber.
 Master Fenton, talk not to me; my mind is heavy; I
    will give over all.

  FENTON.
 To this her mother's plot
    She seemingly obedient likewise hath
    Made promise to the doctor.
 Now thus it rests:
    Her father means she shall be all in white;
    And in that habit, when Slender sees his time  
    To take her by the hand and bid her go,
    She shall go with him; her mother hath intended
    The better to denote her to the doctor-
    For they must all be mask'd and vizarded-
    That quaint in green she shall be loose enrob'd,
    With ribands pendent, flaring 'bout her head;
    And when the doctor spies his vantage ripe,
    To pinch her by the hand, and, on that token,
    The maid hath given consent to go with him.
 So shall I evermore be bound to thee;
    Besides, I'll make a present recompense.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.


The Garter Inn

Enter FALSTAFF and MISTRESS QUICKLY

  FALSTAFF.
 Master Brook, the matter will
    be known tonight or never.
 Went you not to her yesterday, sir, as you told me
    you had appointed?  
  FALSTAFF.
 That same knave Ford, her husband, hath
    the finest mad devil of jealousy in him, Master Brook, that
    ever govern'd frenzy.
 Come, come; we'll couch i' th' Castle ditch till we
    see the light of our fairies.
 That's good too; but what needs either your mum
    or her budget? The white will decipher her well enough.

    It hath struck ten o'clock.
 The night is dark; light and spirits will become it well.
 PAGE.
 I know vat I have to do; adieu.
 Fare you well, sir.

  MRS.

    Be pold, I pray you; follow me into the pit; and when I
    give the watch-ords, do as I pid you.
 You were also,
    Jupiter, a swan, for the love of Leda.

  FALSTAFF.
 My doe with the black scut! Let the sky rain
    potatoes; let it thunder to the tune of Greensleeves, hail
    kissing-comfits, and snow eringoes; let there come a tempest
    of provocation, I will shelter me here.
 FORD.
 } Away, away.

  MRS.
 PAGE.

  FALSTAFF.

                                       [Lies down upon his face]
  EVANS.
 Where's Pede? Go you, and where you find a maid  
    That, ere she sleep, has thrice her prayers said,
    Raise up the organs of her fantasy
    Sleep she as sound as careless infancy;
    But those as sleep and think not on their sins,
    Pinch them, arms, legs, backs, shoulders, sides, and shins.

    Fairies use flow'rs for their charactery.

  FALSTAFF.

  EVANS.
 Oh, oh, oh!
  FAIRY QUEEN.

    Now, good Sir John, how like you Windsor wives?
    See you these, husband? Do not these fair yokes
    Become the forest better than the town?
  FORD.

  FORD.

  FALSTAFF.

  MRS.
 And one that is as slanderous as Satan?
  PAGE.
 Whoa, ho, ho, father Page!
  PAGE.
 Son, how now! how now, son! Have you dispatch'd'?
  SLENDER.
 If it had not been i'
    th' church, I would have swing'd him, or he should have
    swing'd me.
 Upon my life, then, you took the wrong.
 I went to her in white and cried 'mum' and she
    cried 'budget' as Anne and I had appointed; and yet it was
    not Anne, but a postmaster's boy.
 Vere is Mistress Page? By gar, I am cozened; I ha'
    married un garcon, a boy; un paysan, by gar, a boy; it is
    not Anne Page; by gar, I am cozened.
 PAGE.
 Why, did you take her in green?
  CAIUS.
                                          Exit CAIUS
  FORD.
 Pardon, good father.
 Good my mother, pardon.
 Why went you not with Master Doctor, maid?
  FENTON.
 Hear the truth of it.

    The truth is, she and I, long since contracted,
    Are now so sure that nothing can dissolve us.
 PAGE.
 Let it be so.
     Exit PHILOSTRATE
    Hippolyta, I woo'd thee with my sword,  
    And won thy love doing thee injuries;
    But I will wed thee in another key,
    With pomp, with triumph, and with revelling.
 Happy be Theseus, our renowned Duke!
  THESEUS.
 Thanks, good Egeus; what's the news with thee?
  EGEUS.
 My noble lord,
    This man hath my consent to marry her.

    To you your father should be as a god;
    One that compos'd your beauties; yea, and one
    To whom you are but as a form in wax,
    By him imprinted, and within his power
    To leave the figure, or disfigure it.
 So is Lysander.

  THESEUS.
 Either to die the death, or to abjure
    For ever the society of men.
 Take time to pause; and by the next new moon-
    The sealing-day betwixt my love and me
    For everlasting bond of fellowship-
    Upon that day either prepare to die
    For disobedience to your father's will,
    Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would,
    Or on Diana's altar to protest
    For aye austerity and single life.
 Scornful Lysander, true, he hath my love;
    And what is mine my love shall render him;
    And she is mine; and all my right of her
    I do estate unto Demetrius.

  LYSANDER.
 I must confess that I have heard so much,  
    And with Demetrius thought to have spoke thereof;
    But, being over-full of self-affairs,
    My mind did lose it.

    For you, fair Hermia, look you arm yourself
    To fit your fancies to your father's will,
    Or else the law of Athens yields you up-
    Which by no means we may extenuate-
    To death, or to a vow of single life.
 Or else it stood upon the choice of friends-
  HERMIA.

  LYSANDER.
 If then true lovers have ever cross'd,  
    It stands as an edict in destiny.

  LYSANDER.
 If thou lovest me then,
    Steal forth thy father's house to-morrow night;
    And in the wood, a league without the town,
    Where I did meet thee once with Helena
    To do observance to a morn of May,
    There will I stay for thee.
 Keep promise, love.

    Sickness is catching; O, were favour so,  
    Yours would I catch, fair Hermia, ere I go!
    My ear should catch your voice, my eye your eye,
    My tongue should catch your tongue's sweet melody.

    O, teach me how you look, and with what art
    You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart!
  HERMIA.

  HELENA.
 The more I love, the more he hateth me.

  HERMIA.
 None, but your beauty; would that fault were mine!
  HERMIA.

    O, then, what graces in my love do dwell,  
    That he hath turn'd a heaven unto a hell!
  LYSANDER.
 And in the wood where often you and I
    Upon faint primrose beds were wont to lie,
    Emptying our bosoms of their counsel sweet,
    There my Lysander and myself shall meet;
    And thence from Athens turn away our eyes,
    To seek new friends and stranger companies.
 How happy some o'er other some can be!  
    Through Athens I am thought as fair as she.

    I will go tell him of fair Hermia's flight;  
    Then to the wood will he to-morrow night
    Pursue her; and for this intelligence
    If I have thanks, it is a dear expense.

  BOTTOM.
'
  BOTTOM.
 Nick Bottom, the weaver.
 What is Pyramus? A lover, or a tyrant?
  QUINCE.

  BOTTOM.
 That will ask some tears in the true performing of it.
'

    This was lofty.
 Now name the rest of the players.
 This is
    Ercles' vein, a tyrant's vein: a lover is more condoling.
 Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.

  FLUTE.

  FLUTE.
 That's all one; you shall play it in a mask, and you may
    speak as small as you will.

  QUINCE.
 Robin Starveling, you must play Thisby's mother.

  QUINCE.

  BOTTOM.
 Let me play the lion too.

  BOTTOM.

    In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties, such as our
    play wants.

>>



ACT II.
 SCENE I.


    I must go seek some dewdrops here,
    And hang a pearl in every cowslip's ear.

    But room, fairy, here comes Oberon.

  TITANIA.

  OBERON.
 Then I must be thy lady; but I know
    When thou hast stolen away from fairy land,
    And in the shape of Corin sat all day,
    Playing on pipes of corn, and versing love
    To amorous Phillida.
 How canst thou thus, for shame, Titania,
    Glance at my credit with Hippolyta,
    Knowing I know thy love to Theseus?
    Didst not thou lead him through the glimmering night
    From Perigouna, whom he ravished?
    And make him with fair Aegles break his faith,
    With Ariadne and Antiopa?
  TITANIA.

    Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain,
    As in revenge, have suck'd up from the sea
    Contagious fogs; which, falling in the land,
    Hath every pelting river made so proud  
    That they have overborne their continents.

    The ox hath therefore stretch'd his yoke in vain,
    The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn
    Hath rotted ere his youth attain'd a beard;
    The fold stands empty in the drowned field,
    And crows are fatted with the murrion flock;
    The nine men's morris is fill'd up with mud,
    And the quaint mazes in the wanton green,
    For lack of tread, are undistinguishable.

    And thorough this distemperature we see
    The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts
    Fall in the fresh lap of the crimson rose;
    And on old Hiems' thin and icy crown
    An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds
    Is, as in mockery, set.
 The spring, the summer,  
    The childing autumn, angry winter, change
    Their wonted liveries; and the mazed world,
    By their increase, now knows not which is which.

    And this same progeny of evils comes
    From our debate, from our dissension;
    We are their parents and original.
 Do you amend it, then; it lies in you.

  OBERON.

    If you will patiently dance in our round,
    And see our moonlight revels, go with us;
    If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.

  TITANIA.

  OBERON.
  

               Enter DEMETRIUS, HELENA following him

  DEMETRIUS.

    Thou told'st me they were stol'n unto this wood,
    And here am I, and wood within this wood,
    Because I cannot meet my Hermia.

  HELENA.

    I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius,
    The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.
 And I am sick when I look not on you.

  DEMETRIUS.
 You do impeach your modesty too much
    To leave the city and commit yourself
    Into the hands of one that loves you not;
    To trust the opportunity of night,
    And the ill counsel of a desert place,
    With the rich worth of your virginity.

  HELENA.
 Your virtue is my privilege for that:
    It is not night when I do see your face,
    Therefore I think I am not in the night;
    Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company,
    For you, in my respect, are all the world.
 I'll run from thee and hide me in the brakes,
    And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.
 The wildest hath not such a heart as you.

    Run when you will; the story shall be chang'd:
    Apollo flies, and Daphne holds the chase;
    The dove pursues the griffin; the mild hind
    Makes speed to catch the tiger- bootless speed,
    When cowardice pursues and valour flies.

    And look thou meet me ere the first cock crow.
 Sing me now asleep;
    Then to your offices, and let me rest.

  HERMIA.

  LYSANDER.
 Nay, good Lysander; for my sake, my dear,
    Lie further off yet; do not lie so near.
 Lysander riddles very prettily.
 With half that wish the wisher's eyes be press'd!
                                                    [They sleep]

                          Enter PUCK  

  PUCK.

  DEMETRIUS.
            Exit
  HELENA.

    What wicked and dissembling glass of mine
    Made me compare with Hermia's sphery eyne?
    But who is here? Lysander! on the ground!
    Dead, or asleep? I see no blood, no wound.

    What though he love your Hermia? Lord, what though?
    Yet Hermia still loves you; then be content.

  HELENA.

    Either death or you I'll find immediately.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 SCENE I.

The wood.
 Are we all met?
  QUINCE.
 This green plot shall be our stage, this hawthorn
    brake our tiring-house; and we will do it in action, as we will
    do it before the Duke.
 What sayest thou, bully Bottom?
  BOTTOM.

  STARVELING.
 I fear it, I promise you.
 Yes, it doth shine that night.
 Ay; or else one must come in with a bush of thorns and a
    lantern, and say he comes to disfigure or to present the person
    of Moonshine.
 Some man or other must present Wall; and let him have some
    plaster, or some loam, or some rough-cast about him, to signify
    wall; and let him hold his fingers thus, and through that cranny
    shall Pyramus and Thisby whisper.
 What hempen homespuns have we swagg'ring here,
    So near the cradle of the Fairy Queen?
    What, a play toward! I'll be an auditor;
    An actor too perhaps, if I see cause.
 Must I speak now?  
  QUINCE.
 Why do they run away? This is a knavery of them to make me
    afeard.


  TITANIA.

    Mine ear is much enamoured of thy note;
    So is mine eye enthralled to thy shape;
    And thy fair virtue's force perforce doth move me,  
    On the first view, to say, to swear, I love thee.

  BOTTOM.
 Methinks, mistress, you should have little reason for that.
 Hail, mortal!  
  COBWEB.

  BOTTOM.
 I shall desire you of more acquaintance, good Master
    Cobweb.

    The moon, methinks, looks with a wat'ry eye;
    And when she weeps, weeps every little flower;
    Lamenting some enforced chastity.


                          Enter PUCK

    Here comes my messenger.
 When they him spy,
    As wild geese that the creeping fowler eye,
    Or russet-pated choughs, many in sort,
    Rising and cawing at the gun's report,
    Sever themselves and madly sweep the sky,
    So at his sight away his fellows fly;
    And at our stamp here, o'er and o'er one falls;
    He murder cries, and help from Athens calls.

    I led them on in this distracted fear,
    And left sweet Pyramus translated there;
    When in that moment, so it came to pass,
    Titania wak'd, and straightway lov'd an ass.
 This falls out better than I could devise.


                 Enter DEMETRIUS and HERMIA

  OBERON.

    If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep,
    Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep,
    And kill me too.

  HERMIA.
 You spend your passion on a mispris'd mood:
    I am not guilty of Lysander's blood;
    Nor is he dead, for aught that I can tell.

    By some illusion see thou bring her here;
    I'll charm his eyes against she do appear.
       Flower of this purple dye,
                Hit with Cupid's archery,
                Sink in apple of his eye.


                       Re-enter PUCK
  
  PUCK.
 O, let me kiss
    This princess of pure white, this seal of bliss!
  HELENA.
 Never did mockers waste more idle breath.

    If e'er I lov'd her, all that love is gone.
  
    But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?
  LYSANDER.
 Lysander's love, that would not let him bide-
    Fair Helena, who more engilds the night
    Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.

  HERMIA.

  HERMIA.

    If you have any pity, grace, or manners,
    You would not make me such an argument.
  
    But fare ye well; 'tis partly my own fault,
    Which death, or absence, soon shall remedy.

  LYSANDER.
 If she cannot entreat, I can compel.

  LYSANDER.

  HERMIA.
 No, no, he will
    Seem to break loose- take on as you would follow,
    But yet come not.
 What, should I hurt her, strike her, kill her dead?
    Although I hate her, I'll not harm her so.
 What! Can you do me greater harm than hate?
    Hate me! wherefore? O me! what news, my love?
    Am not I Hermia? Are not you Lysander?
    I am as fair now as I was erewhile.

    Why then, you left me- O, the gods forbid!-
    In earnest, shall I say?  
  LYSANDER.

    Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt;
    Be certain, nothing truer; 'tis no jest
    That I do hate thee and love Helena.
 I pray you, though you mock me, gentlemen,
    Let her not hurt me.
 I was never curst;
    I have no gift at all in shrewishness;
    I am a right maid for my cowardice;
    Let her not strike me.
 Good Hermia, do not be so bitter with me.

    I evermore did love you, Hermia,
    Did ever keep your counsels, never wrong'd you;
    Save that, in love unto Demetrius,
    I told him of your stealth unto this wood.

    He followed you; for love I followed him;
    But he hath chid me hence, and threat'ned me
    To strike me, spurn me, nay, to kill me too;
    And now, so you will let me quiet go,  
    To Athens will I bear my folly back,
    And follow you no further.

    You see how simple and how fond I am.
 What! with Lysander?
  HELENA.
 I will not trust you, I;
    Nor longer stay in your curst company.
            Exit
  OBERON.
 This is thy negligence.
 Thou seest these lovers seek a place to fight.

    Whiles I in this affair do thee employ,
    I'll to my queen, and beg her Indian boy;
    And then I will her charmed eye release
    From monster's view, and all things shall be peace.

  PUCK.

  OBERON.

    Here comes one.
 I will be with thee straight.
      Exit LYSANDER as following the voice  

                      Enter DEMETRIUS

  DEMETRIUS.

    Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled?
    Speak! In some bush? Where dost thou hide thy head?
  PUCK.
 Thou coward, art thou bragging to the stars,
    Telling the bushes that thou look'st for wars,
    And wilt not come? Come, recreant, come, thou child;
    I'll whip thee with a rod.

  DEMETRIUS.

    I followed fast, but faster he did fly,  
    That fallen am I in dark uneven way,
    And here will rest me.
       Yet but three? Come one more;
              Two of both kinds makes up four.
 Never so weary, never so in woe,
    Bedabbled with the dew, and torn with briers,
    I can no further crawl, no further go;
    My legs can keep no pace with my desires.
          On the ground
                 Sleep sound;
                 I'll apply
                 To your eye,
          Gentle lover, remedy.
  
 Exit

SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 Ready.

    Where's Mounsieur Cobweb?
  COBWEB.
 Ready.
 Ready.
 I have a reasonable good ear in music.
 Or say, sweet love, what thou desirest to eat.

  TITANIA.

  BOTTOM.
 Sleep thou, and I will wind thee in my arms.

    Fairies, be gone, and be all ways away.

    O, how I love thee! how I dote on thee!         [They sleep]

                         Enter PUCK

  OBERON.

    But first I will release the Fairy Queen.
 My Oberon! What visions have I seen!
    Methought I was enamour'd of an ass.
 Now when thou wak'st with thine own fool's eyes peep.
 Sound, music.
     Then, my Queen, in silence sad,
              Trip we after night's shade.
 Go, one of you, find out the forester;
    For now our observation is perform'd,
    And since we have the vaward of the day,
    My love shall hear the music of my hounds.

  HIPPOLYTA.
 A cry more tuneable
    Was never holla'd to, nor cheer'd with horn,
    In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thessaly.

    I wonder of their being here together.

  THESEUS.
 My lord, I shall reply amazedly,
    Half sleep, half waking; but as yet, I swear,
    I cannot truly say how I came here,
    But, as I think- for truly would I speak,
    And now I do bethink me, so it is-
    I came with Hermia hither.

    But, like a sickness, did I loathe this food;
    But, as in health, come to my natural taste,
    Now I do wish it, love it, long for it,
    And will for evermore be true to it.

    And, for the morning now is something worn,
    Our purpos'd hunting shall be set aside.
 Are you sure
    That we are awake? It seems to me
    That yet we sleep, we dream.

  DEMETRIUS.
 Why, then, we are awake; let's follow him;
    And by the way let us recount our dreams.
             Exeunt  
  BOTTOM.
 My
    next is 'Most fair Pyramus.
' Heigh-ho! Peter Quince! Flute, the
    bellows-mender! Snout, the tinker! Starveling! God's my life,
    stol'n hence, and left me asleep! I have had a most rare vision.

  FLUTE.
 If he come not, then the play is marr'd; it goes not
    forward, doth it?
  QUINCE.


                           Enter BOTTOM

  BOTTOM.

  QUINCE.

    Away, go, away!                                       Exeunt




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

    Lovers and madmen have such seething brains,
    Such shaping fantasies, that apprehend
    More than cool reason ever comprehends.

    The lunatic, the lover, and the poet,
    Are of imagination all compact.
 But all the story of the night told over,
    And all their minds transfigur'd so together,
    More witnesseth than fancy's images,
    And grows to something of great constancy,
    But howsoever strange and admirable.

    'The thrice three Muses mourning for the death
    Of Learning, late deceas'd in beggary.

    And tragical, my noble lord, it is;
    For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.

    Which when I saw rehears'd, I must confess,
    Made mine eyes water; but more merry tears
    The passion of loud laughter never shed.

  THESEUS.
 Trust me, sweet,
    Out of this silence yet I pick'd a welcome;
    And in the modesty of fearful duty
    I read as much as from the rattling tongue
    Of saucy and audacious eloquence.

    Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity
    In least speak most to my capacity.

  LYSANDER.
 He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt; he knows not
    the stop.
 A good moral, my lord: it is not enough to speak, but
    to speak true.

    This man is Pyramus, if you would know;
    This beauteous lady Thisby is certain.

    This loam, this rough-cast, and this stone, doth show
    That I am that same wall; the truth is so;
    And this the cranny is, right and sinister,
    Through which the fearful lovers are to whisper.
 O grim-look'd night! O night with hue so black!
    O night, which ever art when day is not!
    O night, O night, alack, alack, alack,
    I fear my Thisby's promise is forgot!
    And thou, O wall, O sweet, O lovely wall,
    That stand'st between her father's ground and mine;  
    Thou wall, O wall, O sweet and lovely wall,
    Show me thy chink, to blink through with mine eyne.

    O wicked wall, through whom I see no bliss,
    Curs'd he thy stones for thus deceiving me!
  THESEUS.
 The wall, methinks, being sensible, should curse again.

  PYRAMUS.

  PYRAMUS.
 Think what thou wilt, I am thy lover's grace;
    And like Limander am I trusty still.
 Now is the moon used between the two neighbours.
 The best in this kind are but shadows; and the worst are
    no worse, if imagination amend them.


                   Enter LION and MOONSHINE

  LION.

  LYSANDER.

  THESEUS.
 Not so, my lord; for his valour cannot carry his  
    discretion, and the fox carries the goose.
 Leave it to his
    discretion, and let us listen to the Moon.
 This lanthorn doth the horned moon present-
  DEMETRIUS.
 He should have worn the horns on his head.

  DEMETRIUS.
 Well run, Thisby.


                        Re-enter PYRAMUS

  DEMETRIUS.
 And then came Pyramus.

  PYRAMUS.
 Sweet Moon, I thank thee for thy sunny beams;  
    I thank thee, Moon, for shining now so bright;
    For, by thy gracious golden, glittering gleams,
    I trust to take of truest Thisby sight.

             O Fates! come, come;
             Cut thread and thrum;
           Quail, crush, conclude, and quell.
 O wherefore, Nature, didst thou lions frame?
    Since lion vile hath here deflower'd my dear;  
    Which is- no, no- which was the fairest dame
    That liv'd, that lov'd, that lik'd, that look'd with cheer.

             Now am I dead,
             Now am I fled;
           My soul is in the sky.

             Tongue, lose thy light;
             Moon, take thy flight.
                   [Dies]
  DEMETRIUS.
 Here she comes; and her
    passion ends the play.

  HIPPOLYTA.

  DEMETRIUS.
      Asleep, my love?
               What, dead, my dove?
             O Pyramus, arise,
               Speak, speak.

               These lily lips,
               This cherry nose,  
             These yellow cowslip cheeks,
               Are gone, are gone;
               Lovers, make moan;
             His eyes were green as leeks.

               Come, trusty sword;
             Come, blade, my breast imbrue.

  DEMETRIUS.
 Marry, if he that writ it had played Pyramus, and
    hang'd himself in Thisby's garter, it would have been a fine
    tragedy.

    Lovers, to bed; 'tis almost fairy time.

             Trip away; make no stay;
             Meet me all by break of day.

             If you pardon, we will mend.

  Beatrice, niece to Leonato.

  Ursula, waiting gentlewoman attending on Hero.
>>



SCENE.
--Messina.

An orchard before Leonato's house.
 I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honour on
    a young Florentine called Claudio.

  Mess.

  Leon.
 In great measure.
 There are no faces truer than
    those that are so wash'd.
 How much better is it to weep at joy
    than to joy at weeping!
  Beat.
 I pray you, is Signior Mountanto return'd from the wars or no?
  Mess.
 There was none such in the
    army of any sort.
 My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.
 Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much; but he'll  
    be meet with you, I doubt it not.
 He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

  Beat.
 He is no less than a stuff'd man; but for
    the stuffing--well, we are all mortal.
 There is a kind of merry
    war betwixt Signior Benedick and her.

  Beat.
 He wears his faith but as the fashion
    of his hat; it ever changes with the next block.

  Mess.
 I will hold friends with you, lady.
 Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of your Grace;
    for trouble being gone, comfort should remain; but when you depart
    from me, sorrow abides and happiness takes his leave.

  Pedro.
 I think this is your
    daughter.
 Be happy, lady;
    for you are like an honourable father.
 If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not have his head
    on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.

  Beat.
 Is it possible Disdain should die while she hath such meet
    food to feed it as Signior Benedick? Courtesy itself must convert  
    to disdain if you come in her presence.
 God keep your ladyship still in that mind! So some gentleman
    or other shall scape a predestinate scratch'd face.
 Scratching could not make it worse an 'twere such a face as
    yours were.

  Beat.
 You always end with a jade's trick.
 Signior Claudio and Signior
    Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all.
 I tell him
    we shall stay here at the least a month, and he heartly prays  
    some occasion may detain us longer.

  John.
 Please it your Grace lead on?
  Pedro.
 Your hand, Leonato.
 We will go together.
 Manent Benedick and Claudio.
 I pray thee tell me truly how
    thou lik'st her.


                       Enter Don Pedro.
 What secret hath held you here, that you followed not to
    Leonato's?
  Bene.
  
  Pedro.
 Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well worthy.
 You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.
 And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

    I will die in it at the stake.
 Because I will not do them
    the wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the right to trust
    none; and the fine is (for the which I may go the finer), I will  
    live a bachelor.

  Pedro.

  Bene.
'
  Bene.
 The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible Benedick bear
    it, pluck off the bull's horns and set them in my forehead, and
    let me be vilely painted, and in such great letters as they write
    'Here is good horse to hire,' let them signify under my sign
    'Here you may see Benedick the married man.
  
  Pedro.

  Bene.
 Well, you will temporize with the hours.
 In the meantime,
    good Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato's, commend me to him and
    tell him I will not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath made
    great preparation.

  Bene.
 The sixth of July.
 Ere you flout old ends any further, examine
    your conscience.

  Pedro.
 What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
    The fairest grant is the necessity.


  Leon.
 He is very busy about it.
 But, brother, I can tell you strange
    news that you yet dreamt not of.

  Leon.
 A good sharp fellow.
                              [Exit Antonio.

  John.
 I am trusted with a muzzle and
    enfranchis'd with a clog; therefore I have decreed not to sing in
    my cage.

  Con.


    Who comes here? What news, Borachio?
  Bora.
 The Prince your brother is
    royally entertain'd by Leonato, and I can give you intelligence  
    of an intended marriage.

  John.
 Marry, it is your brother's right hand.

  John.

  John.
 If I can cross him any way, I bless myself every way.

    You are both sure, and will assist me?
  Con.
 To the death, my lord.
>>



ACT II.
 How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see him but I am
    heart-burn'd an hour after.
  
  Ant.

  Leon.
 Lord, I could not
    endure a husband with a beard on his face.
 Adam's sons are my brethren, and truly I
    hold it a sin to match in my kinred.

  Leon.
 I have a good eye, uncle; I can see a church by daylight.
 Make good room.
]

    Enter, [masked,] Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, and Balthasar.

       [With them enter Antonio, also masked.
 Lady, will you walk a bout with your friend?
  Hero.

  Pedro.
 Well, I would you did like me.

  Marg.
 And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is done!
    Answer, clerk.

  Balth.

                                              [Takes her aside.
]
  Urs.
 I know you well enough.
  
  Ant.
 What's he?
  Beat.
 Not I, believe me.

  Bene.
 You may do the part of an honest man in it.

  Claud.
 How know you he loves her?
  John.
 I heard him swear his affection.
 The Prince wooes for himself.

    This is an accident of hourly proof,
    Which I mistrusted not.

  Claud.
 Ho! now you strike like the blind man! 'Twas the boy that
    stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.
 Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he creep into sedges.
 Now, signior, where's the Count? Did you see him?
  Bene.
 Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame, I found
    him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren.
  
  Pedro.

  Pedro.
 Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The transgression is
    in the stealer.

  Pedro.
 O, she misus'd me past the endurance of a block! An oak but
    with one green leaf on it would have answered her; my very visor
    began to assume life and scold with her.
 If her breath were as terrible as her terminations,
    there were no living near her; she would infect to the North
    Star.
 Come, talk not of her.
 I would to God some scholar would
    conjure her, for certainly, while she is here, a man may live as
    quiet in hell as in a sanctuary; and people sin upon purpose,
    because they would go thither; so indeed all disquiet, horror,
    and perturbation follows her.
                                              [Exit.
 Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile, and I gave him use for
    it--a double heart for his single one.
 So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I should prove
    the mother of fools.
 Not sad, my lord.

  Pedro.

  Beat.
 I have broke with
    her father, and his good will obtained.
 Speak, Count, 'tis your cue.
 Silence is the perfectest herald of joy.
 I were but little
    happy if I could say how much.

  Claud.
 And so she doth, cousin.

  Beat.
 I may sit in a corner and cry 'Heigh-ho for
    a husband!'
  Pedro.
 Will you have me, lady?
  Beat.
 No, my lord, unless I might have another for working days:
    your Grace is too costly to wear every day.
 Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best becomes
    you, for out o' question you were born in a merry hour.
 Cousins, God give you joy!
  Leon.
 I cry you mercy, uncle, By your Grace's pardon.

  Pedro.
 She were an excellent wife for Benedick.

  Pedro.
 And you too, gentle Hero?
  Hero.
 Go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.

A hall in Leonato's house.

  John.
 Go you to the  
    Prince your brother; spare not to tell him that he hath wronged
    his honour in marrying the renowned Claudio (whose estimation do
    you mightily hold up) to a contaminated stale, such a one as
    Hero.

  John.
 Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo
    Hero, and kill Leonato.
 Boy!

                    [Enter Boy.

    (Exit Boy.
                                         [Hides.

                      Music [within].
 Yea, my good lord.
 How still the evening is,
    As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony!
  Pedro.


  Pedro.

  Balth.
 O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice
    To slander music any more than once.
 Because you talk of wooing, I will sing,
    Since many a wooer doth commence his suit
    To her he thinks not worthy, yet he wooes,
    Yet will he swear he loves.
]
                      The Song.

            Then sigh not so,
            But let them go,
          And be you blithe and bonny,
        Converting all your sounds of woe  
          Into Hey nonny, nonny.


  Pedro.
 By my troth, a good song.

  Pedro.

  Bene.
 [aside] An he had been a dog that should have howl'd thus,
    they would have hang'd him; and I pray God his bad voice bode no
    mischief.
 Do so.
 Farewell.
  
                                Exit Balthasar [with Musicians].
 O, ay!-[Aside to Pedro] Stalk on, stalk on; the fowl sits.

  Leon.
 What effects, my lord? She will sit you--you heard my
    daughter tell you how.

  Claud.
  
  Leon.
 O, when she had writ it, and was reading it over, she found
    'Benedick' and 'Beatrice' between the sheet?
  Claud.

  Leon.
 Yea, though I
    love him, I should.
 Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs, beats her
    heart, tears her hair, prays, curses--'O sweet Benedick! God give
    me patience!'
  Leon.
  
  Claud.

  Pedro.
 I would she had bestowed this dotage on me.
 I pray you
    tell Benedick of it and hear what 'a will say.

  Pedro.
 Shall we go seek Benedick and tell him of
    her love?
  Claud.
 Nay, that's impossible; she may wear her heart out first.
]  
  Claud.
 Let there be the same net spread for her, and that must your
    daughter and her gentlewomen carry.
]

  Bene.
 They say the
    lady is fair--'tis a truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous  
    --'tis so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for loving me--by
    my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor no great argument of
    her folly, for I will be horribly in love with her.
 I may chance
    have some odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me because I
    have railed so long against marriage.
 When I said I would die a bachelor, I did not
    think I should live till I were married.

  Beat.
 Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.
 I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to
    thank me.
 If it had been painful, I would not have come.

  Bene.

Exit.

  Bene.
 'I took no more pains for those
    thanks than you took pains to thank me.
                   Exit.

    There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
    Proposing with the Prince and Claudio.

  Marg.
 Of this matter
    Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,
    That only wounds by hearsay.
 The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish
    Cut with her golden oars the silver stream
    And greedily devour the treacherous bait.
]
    No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful.
 But are you sure
    That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
  Hero.

  Urs.

  Urs.

  Hero.
 Yet tell her of it.
 Hear what she will say.

    And truly, I'll devise some honest slanders
    To stain my cousin with.

  Urs.

  Hero.

  Urs.
]
  Urs.


  Pedro.

  Pedro.

  Bene.
 So say I.
 I hope he be in love.

  Bene.
 Well, every one can master a grief but he that has it.
 Unless he have a fancy to this
    foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you
    would have it appear he is.
 Hath any man seen him at the barber's?
  Claud.

  Pedro.
 Yes, and his ill conditions; and in despite of all, dies for
    him.
 Yet is this no charm for the toothache.
]  
  Pedro.
 Good den, brother.
 In private?
  John.
 Yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I
    would speak of concerns him.

  Pedro.
 What's the matter?
  John.
 The word is too good to paint out her wickedness.
 If you love her then, to-morrow wed her.
 But it
    would better fit your honour to change your mind.
 May this be so?
  Pedro.
 O day untowardly turned!
  Claud.
 O plague right well prevented!
    So will you say when you have seen the Sequel.

                                                         Exeunt.
 Are you good men and true?
  Verg.
 Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer salvation,
    body and soul.

  Verg.
 God hath bless'd you with a
    good name.
 You have.
 Therefore
    bear you the lanthorn.
 Watch.
 You shall also make no noise in the streets; for for
    the watch to babble and to talk is most tolerable, and not to be
    endured.
 We will rather sleep than talk.
 How if they will not?
  Dog.
 If they make you
    not then the better answer, You may say they are not the men you
    took them for.
 Watch.

  Dog.
 Why then, depart in peace and let the child wake her with
    crying; for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baes will
    never answer a calf when he bleats.

  Verg.

  Dog.
 Ha, ah, ha! Well, masters, good night.
 An there be any matter
    of weight chances, call up me.
 Come, neighbour.

  2.
 Watch.
 Well, masters, we hear our charge.
 Let us go sit here
    upon the church bench till two, and then all to bed.


  Bora.
 I am at thy elbow.
 I will owe thee an answer for that; and now forward with thy
    tale.
 Is it possible that any villany should be so dear?
  Bora.
 I wonder at it.

  Con.
 Yes, the fashion is the fashion.
 Tush! I may as well say the fool's the fool.
 But seest thou
    not what a deformed thief this fashion is?
  2.

  Bora.
 No; 'twas the vane on the house.
 And thought they Margaret was Hero?
  Bora.

  2.
 Watch.
 Come, we'll obey you.

                                                         Exeunt.

A Room in Leonato's house.
 I will, lady.
                                             [Exit.
]
  Marg.
 By my troth, 's not so good, and I warrant your cousin will
    say so.
 I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a
    thought browner; and your gown's a most rare fashion, i' faith.

    I saw the Duchess of Milan's gown that they praise so.

  Hero.
 Is there any harm in 'the heavier for a husband'?
    None, I think, an it be the right husband and the right wife.
 Good morrow, coz.
  
  Marg.

  Beat.

  Marg.

    By my troth, I am exceeding ill.

  Marg.
 Nothing I; but God send every one their heart's desire!
  Hero.
 Doth not my wit become me rarely?  
  Beat.
 It is not seen enough.
 Moral? No, by my troth, I have no moral meaning; I meant
    plain holy thistle.
 Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you that decerns
    you nearly.

  Verg.
 Yes, in truth it is, sir.

  Leon.
 Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living that is an
    old man and no honester than I.
 Neighbours, you are tedious.

  Dog.
 All thy tediousness on me, ah?
  Dog.
 Yea, in 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis; for I hear as
    good exclamation on your worship as of any man in the city; and
    though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.

  Verg.
 A good old man, sir; he will be talking.
' God help us! it is a world to
    see! Well said, i' faith, neighbour Verges.
 One word, sir.
 Our watch, sir, have indeed comprehended two
    aspicious persons, and we would have them this morning examined
    before your worship.

  Leon.
 Take their examination yourself and bring it me.

  Leon.
 My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her
    husband.
 I'll wait upon them.
]




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
 Only to the plain form of
    marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties
    afterwards.

  Friar.
 You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady?
  Claud.

  Friar.
 Know you any, Count?
  Leon.
 And what have I to give you back whose worth
    May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?
  Pedro.

    Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
    O, what authority and show of truth
    Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
    Comes not that blood as modest evidence
    To witness simple virtue, Would you not swear,
    All you that see her, that she were a maid
    By these exterior shows? But she is none:  
    She knows the heat of a luxurious bed;
    Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.
 What do you mean, my lord?
  Claud.

    No, Leonato,
    I never tempted her with word too large,
    But, as a brother to his sister, show'd
    Bashful sincerity and comely love.
 Out on the seeming! I will write against it.
 What should I speak?
    I stand dishonour'd that have gone about
    To link my dear friend to a common stale.
 Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

  Hero.

  Leon.
 To make you answer truly to your name.
 O Hero! what a Hero hadst thou been
    If half thy outward graces had been plac'd
    About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!
    But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! Farewell,
    Thou pure impiety and impious purity!
    For thee I'll lock up all the gates of love,
    And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang,
    To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,
    And never shall it more be gracious.
 Why, how now, cousin? Wherefore sink you down?
  John.

                      [Exeunt Don Pedro, Don Juan, and Claudio.
]
  Bene.
 How doth the lady?
  Beat.
 Yea, wherefore should she not?
  Leon.
 Wherefore? Why, doth not every earthly thing
    Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny
    The story that is printed in her blood?
    Do not live, Hero; do not ope thine eyes;
    For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,
    Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,
    Myself would on the rearward of reproaches
    Strike at thy life.
 Griev'd I, I had but one?
    Child I for that at frugal nature's frame?
    O, one too much by thee! Why had I one?
    Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
    Why had I not with charitable hand  
    Took up a beggar's issue at my gates,
    Who smirched thus and mir'd with infamy,
    I might have said, 'No part of it is mine;
    This shame derives itself from unknown loins'?
    But mine, and mine I lov'd, and mine I prais'd,
    And mine that I was proud on--mine so much
    That I myself was to myself not mine,
    Valuing of her--why, she, O, she is fall'n
    Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea
    Hath drops too few to wash her clean again,
    And salt too little which may season give
    To her foul tainted flesh!
  Bene.
 Sir, sir, be patient.

  Friar.
 Hear me a little;
    For I have only been silent so long,
    And given way unto this course of fortune,
    By noting of the lady.
 Call me a fool;
    Trust not my reading nor my observation,
    Which with experimental seal doth warrant
    The tenure of my book; trust not my age,
    My reverence, calling, nor divinity,
    If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here
    Under some biting error.
 I know not.
 Then shall he mourn
    (If ever love had interest in his liver)
    And wish he had not so accused her--
    No, though be thought his accusation true.

    Let this be so, and doubt not but success
    Will fashion the event in better shape
    Than I can lay it down in likelihood.

    And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,
    As best befits her wounded reputation,
    In some reclusive and religious life,
    Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.

  Bene.

                         Exeunt [all but Benedick and Beatrice].

  Bene.
 Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

  Beat.

  Bene.

  Bene.
 I do love nothing in the world so well as you.
 As strange as the thing I know not.
 But believe me not; and
    yet I lie not.
 I confess nothing, nor I deny nothing.

  Bene.

  Beat.

  Beat.
 Kill Claudio.
 You kill me to deny it.
 Tarry, sweet Beatrice.

  Beat.
 He is now
    as valiant as Hercules that only tells a lie,and swears it.

  Beat.
 Enough, I am engag'd, I will challenge him.
 Go comfort your
    cousin.

                                                       [Exeunt.

  Verg.

  Sex.

  Dog.
 How answer
    you for yourselves?
  Con.
 Sir, I say
    to you, it is thought you are false knaves.
 Sir, I say to you we are none.

  Dog.

  1.
 Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John
    for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.

  Dog.
 I will go before and show him their
    examination.
 Off, coxcomb!
  Dog.
 God's my life, where's the sexton? Let him write down the
    Prince's officer coxcomb.
 Though it be not written down, yet
    forget not that I am an ass.
 Bring him
    away.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE

 Scene I.

The street, near Leonato's house.

    No, no! 'Tis all men's office to speak patience
    To those that wring under the load of sorrow,
    But no man's virtue nor sufficiency
    To be so moral when he shall endure
    The like himself.

  Ant.

  Leon.

  Ant.

  Leon.

    My soul doth tell me Hero is belied;
    And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince,
    And all of them that thus dishonour her.

  Pedro.

  Claud.

  Claud.
 Tush, tush, man! never fleer and jest at me
    I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,
    As under privilege of age to brag
    What I have done being young, or what would do,
    Were I not old.
 Thine, Claudio; thine I say.

  Pedro.

    Come, follow me, boy,.
 God knows I lov'd my niece,  
    And she is dead, slander'd to death by villains,
    That dare as well answer a man indeed
    As I dare take a serpent by the tongue.
  
  Leon.
 And shall, or some of us will smart for it.


                  Enter Benedick.

  Claud.
 We had lik'd to have had our two noses snapp'd off with two
    old men without teeth.
 In a false quarrel there is no true valour.
 I jest not; I will make
    it good how you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare.
 You have kill'd a
    sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you.
 Let me hear
    from you.
 Shall I not find a woodcock too?
  Bene.
' 'No,' said I, 'a great wit.
' 'Right,' says she, 'a great
    gross one.
' 'Just,' said she, 'it
    hurts nobody.
 Yet at last she
    concluded with a sigh, thou wast the proper'st man in Italy.
 All, all! and moreover, God saw him when he was hid in the
    garden.
 I must discontinue your company.

                                                         [Exit.
 In most profound earnest; and, I'll warrant you, for the  
    love of Beatrice.

  Pedro.

  Pedro.

  Pedro.
 Do you
    hear me, and let this Count kill me.
 I have deceived even your
    very eyes.
 Yea, and paid me richly for the practice of it.
 He is compos'd and fram'd of treachery,
    And fled he is upon this villany.
 Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the sexton too.


          Enter Leonato, his brother [Antonio], and the Sexton.
 Which of these is he?
  Bora.

  Leon.

  Leon.
 Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent youth,
    and I praise God for you.
 God restore you
    to health! I humbly give you leave to depart; and if a merry
    meeting may be wish'd, God prohibit it! Come, neighbour.
 Until to-morrow morning, lords, farewell.

  Claud.
 Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty?
  Bene.

  Marg.

    And so I pray thee call Beatrice.

  Marg.
 Marry, I cannot show it in
    rhyme.


                    Enter Beatrice.

  Bene.
 O, stay but till then!
  Beat.

  Bene.
 For them all together, which maintain'd so politic a state of
    evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle with
    them.
 So much for praising
    myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is praiseworthy.
 And now
    tell me, how doth your cousin?
  Beat.
 Madam, you must come to your uncle.

    It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely accus'd, the Prince
    and Claudio mightily abus'd, and Don John is the author of all,
    who is fled and gone.


Enter Claudio, Don Pedro, and three or four with tapers,
[followed by Musicians].
 It is, my lord.

        Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,
          Gives her fame which never dies.

    The wolves have prey'd, and look, the gentle day,
    Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about  
    Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.
 Fare you well.
 Each his several way.
          Exeunt.
 Did I not tell you she was innocent?
  Leon.
 Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

  Friar.

  Leon.
 That eye my daughter lent her.
 And I do with an eye of love requite her.

  Leon.
 Good morrow, Prince; good morrow, Claudio.

  Leon.
 Here's the friar ready.
 Good morrow, Benedick.
 Why, what's the matter
    That you have such a February face,
    So full of frost, of storm, and cloudiness?
  Claud.

  Bene.
 Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low,
    And some such strange bull leap'd your father's cow
    And got a calf in that same noble feat  
    Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

  Claud.

    I am your husband if you like of me.
 Another Hero!
  Hero.

    One Hero died defil'd; but I do live,
    And surely as I live, I am a maid.

  Pedro.
 The former Hero! Hero that is dead!  
  Leon.
 Soft and fair, friar.

  Beat.
 They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

  Bene.
 'Tis no such matter.
 And here's another,
    Writ in my cousin's hand, stol'n from her pocket,
    Containing her affection unto Benedick.
 Dost thou think I care for a satire or
    an epigram? No.
 If a man will be beaten with brains, 'a shall
    wear nothing handsome about him.
 I had well hop'd thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, that I
    might have cudgell'd thee out of thy single life, to make thee a
    double-dealer, which out of question thou wilt be if my cousin do
    not look exceeding narrowly to thee.

  Bene.
 First, of my word! Therefore play, music.
 Think not on him till to-morrow.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.
 SCENE I.

    If ever I did dream of such a matter,
    Abhor me.

    But he, as loving his own pride and purposes,
    Evades them, with a bumbast circumstance
    Horribly stuff'd with epithets of war,
    And, in conclusion,
    Nonsuits my mediators; for, "Certes," says he,
    "I have already chose my officer.

  IAGO.

    For when my outward action doth demonstrate
    The native act and figure of my heart
    In complement extern, 'tis not long after
    But I will wear my heart upon my sleeve
    For daws to peck at: I am not what I am.

  RODERIGO.
 Not I.
 What are you?
  RODERIGO.
 My name is Roderigo.

    I have charged thee not to haunt about my doors.

    In honest plainness thou hast heard me say
    My daughter is not for thee; and now, in madness,
    Being full of supper and distempering draughts,
    Upon malicious bravery, dost thou come
    To start my quiet.
 Sir, sir, sir-
  BRABANTIO.

  RODERIGO.
                      Patience, good sir.
 What tell'st thou me of robbing? This is Venice;
    My house is not a grange.
                   Most grave Brabantio,
    In simple and pure soul I come to you.

  IAGO.

  BRABANTIO.
 This thou shalt answer; I know thee, Roderigo.
               Strike on the tinder, ho!
    Give me a taper! Call up all my people!
    This accident is not unlike my dream;
    Belief of it oppresses me already.
  
    It seems not meet, nor wholesome to my place,
    To be produced- as, if I stay, I shall-
    Against the Moor; for I do know, the state,
    However this may gall him with some check,
    Cannot with safety cast him, for he's embark'd
    With such loud reason to the Cyprus wars,
    Which even now stands in act, that, for their souls,
    Another of his fathom they have none
    To lead their business; in which regard,
    Though I do hate him as I do hell pains,
    Yet for necessity of present life,
    I must show out a flag and sign of love,
    Which is indeed but sign.
 That you shall surely find him,
    Lead to the Sagittary the raised search,
    And there will I be with him.


  BRABANTIO.
 Pray you, lead on.
               Exeunt.

  OTHELLO.
 But I pray you, sir,
    Are you fast married? Be assured of this,
    That the magnifico is much beloved,
    And hath in his effect a voice potential
    As double as the Duke's.

  
           Enter Cassio and certain Officers with torches.

    I will but spend a word here in the house  
    And go with you.
 It is Brabantio.
 I'll have't disputed on;
    'Tis probable, and palpable to thinking.
 If he do resist,
    Subdue him at his peril.

  BRABANTIO.
                How? The Duke in council?
    In this time of the night? Bring him away;
    Mine's not an idle cause.
            Exeunt.

  FIRST SENATOR.

  SECOND SENATOR.
 Nay, it is possible enough to judgement.

  SAILOR.
                                Now, what's the business?
  SAILOR.
                    This cannot be,
    By no assay of reason; 'tis a pageant
    To keep us in false gaze.


  MESSENGER.
 The Ottomites, reverend and gracious,
    Steering with due course toward the isle of Rhodes,
    Have there injointed them with an after fleet.

  DUKE.
 Write from us to him, post-post-haste dispatch.

  FIRST SENATOR.


  DUKE.

  DUKE.

    She is abused, stol'n from me and corrupted
    By spells and medicines bought of mountebanks;
    For nature so preposterously to err,  
    Being not deficient, blind, or lame of sense,
    Sans witchcraft could not.

    Here is the man, this Moor, whom now, it seems,
    Your special mandate for the state affairs
    Hath hither brought.
 I therefore vouch again
    That with some mixtures powerful o'er the blood,
    Or with some dram conjured to this effect,
    He wrought upon her.
                     I do beseech you,
    Send for the lady to the Sagittary,
    And let her speak of me before her father.

  DUKE.
               I pray you, hear her speak.

  BRABANTIO.
 For your sake, jewel,
    I am glad at soul I have no other child;
    For thy escape would teach me tyranny,
    To hang clogs on them.

  DUKE.
 So let the Turk of Cyprus us beguile;
    We lose it not so long as we can smile.

    These sentences, to sugar or to gall,
    Being strong on both sides, are equivocal.

    Othello, the fortitude of the place is best known to you; and
    though we have there a substitute of most allowed sufficiency,
    yet opinion, a sovereign mistress of effects, throws a more safer
    voice on you.
 I do agnize
    A natural and prompt alacrity
    I find in hardness and do undertake
    These present wars against the Ottomites.

    Most humbly therefore bending to your state,
    I crave fit disposition for my wife,
    Due reference of place and exhibition,
    With such accommodation and besort
    As levels with her breeding.
              I'll not have it so.

  DESDEMONA.

  OTHELLO.
 Let her have your voices.
 No, when light-wing'd toys
    Of feather'd Cupid seel with wanton dullness
    My speculative and officed instruments,
    That my disports corrupt and taint my business,
    Let housewives make a skillet of my helm,
    And all indign and base adversities
    Make head against my estimation!
  DUKE.
 Be it as you shall privately determine,
    Either for her stay or going.
  
    To his conveyance I assign my wife,
    With what else needful your good Grace shall think
    To be sent after me.
 Adieu, brave Moor, use Desdemona well.
 We must obey the time.
 What should I do? I confess it is my shame to be so fond,
    but it is not in my virtue to amend it.
 Virtue? a fig! 'Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus.

  IAGO.
 I have professed me thy friend, and I confess me knit to
    thy deserving with cables of perdurable toughness; I could never
    better stead thee than now.
 I say, put
    money in thy purse.
 It was a violent commencement, and thou shalt see an
    answerable sequestration- put but money in thy purse.
 She must have change, she must; therefore put money in
    thy purse.
 If thou wilt needs damn thyself, do it a more delicate
    way than drowning.
 Traverse, go, provide thy money.

  RODERIGO.
 I'll be with thee betimes.
 I am changed; I'll go sell all my land.
  
    He hath a person and a smooth dispose
    To be suspected- framed to make women false.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.

A seaport in Cyprus.
 What from the cape can you discern at sea?
  FIRST GENTLEMAN.
 Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land;
    A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements.

    For do but stand upon the foaming shore,
    The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds;
    The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane,
    Seems to cast water on the burning bear,
    And quench the guards of the ever-fixed pole.

    I never did like molestation view
    On the enchafed flood.


                       Enter a third Gentleman.

                              A cry within, "A sail, a sail, a sail!"

                      Enter a fourth Gentleman.

  SECOND GENTLEMAN.
 They do discharge their shot of courtesy-
    Our friends at least.

  CASSIO.
                 I pray you, sir, go forth,
    And give us truth who 'tis that is arrived.

  MONTANO.


                      Re-enter second Gentleman.

  CASSIO.
 He has had most favorable and happy speed:
    Tempests themselves, high seas, and howling winds,
    The gutter'd rocks, and congregated sands,
    Traitors ensteep'd to clog the guiltless keel,
    As having sense of beauty, do omit
    Their mortal natures, letting go safely by
    The divine Desdemona.

  MONTANO.
                What is she?
  CASSIO.
            I thank you, valiant Cassio.
 He is not yet arrived, nor know I aught
    But that he's well and will be shortly here.

                          A cry within, "A sail, a sail!" Guns heard.
] Welcome, mistress.

    Let it not gall your patience, good Iago,
    That I extend my manners; 'tis my breeding
    That gives me this bold show of courtesy.
 Sir, would she give you so much of her lips
    As of her tongue she oft bestows on me,
    You'ld have enough.

  EMILIA.

  IAGO.
 What wouldst thou write of me, if thou shouldst
    praise me?
  IAGO.
 Come on, assay- There's one gone to the harbor?
  IAGO.
 I am not merry, but I do beguile
    The thing I am by seeming otherwise.

    Come, how wouldst thou praise me?
  IAGO.
 But my Muse labors,
    And thus she is deliver'd.
 How if fair and foolish?
  IAGO.
 What miserable praise hast thou for her that's foul and
    foolish?
  IAGO.
 There's none so foul and foolish thereunto,
    But does foul pranks which fair and wise ones do.
 How say you, Cassio? Is he not
    a most profane and liberal counselor?
  CASSIO.
  
    With as little a web as this will I ensnare as great a fly as
    Cassio.

  DESDEMONA.
             Come, let us to the castle.
  
    News, friends: our wars are done, the Turks are drown'd.

    Bring thou the master to the citadel;
    He is a good one, and his worthiness
    Does challenge much respect.
 I cannot believe that in her; she's full of most blest
    condition.
 Lechery, by this hand; an index and obscure prologue to the
    history of lust and foul thoughts.
 They met so near with their
    lips that their breaths embraced together.

  IAGO.

    Or failing so, yet that I put the Moor
    At least into a jealousy so strong
    That judgement cannot cure.


Enter a Herald with a proclamation; people following.
 All offices are open, and
    there is full liberty of feasting from this present hour of five
    till the bell have told eleven.


  OTHELLO.

                           Exeunt Othello, Desdemona, and Attendants.


  CASSIO.
 Our
    general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona; who let
    us not therefore blame.
 She is indeed perfection.
 Here at the door; I pray you, call them in.


           Re-enter Cassio; with him Montano and Gentlemen;
                    Servants following with wine.
 'Fore God, they have given me a rouse already.
 Some wine, ho!

    [Sings.
 I learned it in England, where indeed they are most potent in
    potting.

  CASSIO.

  CASSIO.
 I am for it, lieutenant, and I'll do you justice.


               "He was a wight of high renown,
                 And thou art but of low degree.
 It's true, good lieutenant.

  CASSIO.

  CASSIO.
 You see this fellow that is gone before;
    He is a soldier fit to stand by Caesar
    And give direction.

    He'll watch the horologe a double set,
    If drink rock not his cradle.
 [Aside to him.

  IAGO.
             Not I, for this fair island.
 A knave teach me my duty! But I'll beat the knave into a
    twiggen bottle.

  IAGO.
] Away, I say; go out and cry a mutiny.
 God's will, lieutenant, hold!
    You will be shamed forever.
 Nor know I aught
    By me that's said or done amiss this night,
    Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice,
    And to defend ourselves it be a sin
    When violence assails us.
                  Touch me not so near:
    I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth
    Than it should do offense to Michael Cassio;  
    Yet, I persuade myself, to speak the truth
    Shall nothing wrong him.

    Montano and myself being in speech,
    There comes a fellow crying out for help,
    And Cassio following him with determined sword,
    To execute upon him.

    Myself the crying fellow did pursue,
    Lest by his clamor- as it so fell out-
    The town might fall in fright.
 When I came back-
    For this was brief- I found them close together,
    At blow and thrust, even as again they were
    When you yourself did part them.

    More of this matter cannot I report.

    But men are men; the best sometimes forget.

    Iago, look with care about the town,
    And silence those whom this vile brawl distracted.

  IAGO.
 I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly; a
    quarrel, but nothing wherefore.

  CASSIO.

  IAGO.
 I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.

  CASSIO.
 I think it freely; and betimes in the morning I will beseech
    the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me.
 For whiles this honest fool
    Plies Desdemona to repair his fortune,
    And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor,
    I'll pour this pestilence into his ear,
    That she repeals him for her body's lust;
    And by how much she strives to do him good,
    She shall undo her credit with the Moor.


                           Enter Roderigo.
 I do follow here in the chase, not like a hound that
    hunts, but one that fills up the cry.

  IAGO.

    Content thyself awhile.





<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.


  CLOWN.
 Ay, marry, are they, sir.

  CLOWN.

  FIRST MUSICIAN.
 Well, sir, we will not.
 Then put up your pipes in your bag, for I'll away.

  CASSIO.
 There's a poor piece of gold
    for thee.
 Wilt thou do this?
  CLOWN.
 If she will stir hither, I shall seem
    to notify unto her.

  CASSIO.
 Do, good my friend.


                             Enter Iago.
 Why, no; the day had broke
    Before we parted.
] I never knew
    A Florentine more kind and honest.


  EMILIA.
 The Moor replies
    That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus  
    And great affinity and that in wholesome wisdom
    He might not but refuse you; but he protests he loves you
    And needs no other suitor but his likings
    To take the safest occasion by the front
    To bring you in again.

   Exeunt.

The garden of the castle.


Enter Desdemona, Cassio, and Emilia.
 Be thou assured, good Cassio, I will do
    All my abilities in thy behalf.

  EMILIA.
 Good madam, do.

  CASSIO.
 I am very ill at ease,  
    Unfit for mine own purposes.

  DESDEMONA.
 Ha! I like not that.
 What dost thou say?
  IAGO.

  OTHELLO.

  OTHELLO.
 Who is't you mean?
  DESDEMONA.
 Not now, sweet Desdemona; some other time.
 Shall't be tonight at supper?
  OTHELLO.
                                 No, not tonight.
 I wonder in my soul,
    What you would ask me, that I should deny,
    Or stand so mammering on.
 Let him come when he will;
    I will deny thee nothing.

  OTHELLO.
 Emilia, come.

  OTHELLO.
 I did not think he had been acquainted with her.
                    Men should be what they seem;
    Or those that be not, would they might seem none!
  OTHELLO.

  IAGO.

  IAGO.
                         I do beseech you-
    Though I perchance am vicious in my guess,
    As, I confess, it is my nature's plague
    To spy into abuses, and oft my jealousy
    Shapes faults that are not- that your wisdom yet,
    From one that so imperfectly conceits,
    Would take no notice, nor build yourself a trouble
    Out of his scattering and unsure observance.

    Who steals my purse steals trash; 'tis something, nothing;
    'Twas mine, 'tis his, and has been slave to thousands;
    But he that filches from me my good name
    Robs me of that which not enriches him
    And makes me poor indeed.

  OTHELLO.
 That cuckold lives in bliss
    Who, certain of his fate, loves not his wronger;
    But O, what damned minutes tells he o'er
    Who dotes, yet doubts, suspects, yet strongly loves!
  OTHELLO.
 Exchange me for a goat
    When I shall turn the business of my soul
    To such exsufflicate and blown surmises,
    Matching thy inference.
 'Tis not to make me jealous
    To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company,
    Is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances well;
    Where virtue is, these are more virtuous.

    I know our country disposition well;
    In Venice they do let heaven see the pranks
    They dare not show their husbands; their best conscience
    Is not to leave't undone, but keep't unknown.
 She did deceive her father, marrying you;
    And when she seem'd to shake and fear your looks,
    She loved them most.
                   I am bound to thee forever.
                          I'faith, I fear it has.

  OTHELLO.
 And yet, how nature erring from itself-
  IAGO.
              Farewell, farewell.
] My lord, I would I might entreat your honor
    To scan this thing no further; leave it to time.
 If I do prove her haggard,
    Though that her jesses were my dear heartstrings,
    I'ld whistle her off and let her down the wind
    To prey at fortune.

  DESDEMONA.
 Come, I'll go in with you.


                            Re-enter Iago.


  IAGO.
                         What handkerchief?
  EMILIA.
 What handkerchief?
    Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona,
    That which so often you did bid me steal.

  EMILIA.
 What will you do with't, that you have been so earnest
    To have me filch it?
  IAGO.
] Why, what is that to you?
  EMILIA.

    I will in Cassio's lodging lose this napkin,
    And let him find it.
 Avaunt! be gone! Thou hast set me on the rack.
                          How now, my lord?
  OTHELLO.

    He that is robb'd, not wanting what is stol'n,
    Let him not know't and he's not robb'd at all.
 I am sorry to hear this.

  IAGO.
 O wretched fool,
    That livest to make thine honesty a vice!
    O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world,
    To be direct and honest is not safe.

    I thank you for this profit, and from hence
    I'll love no friend sith love breeds such offense.

  OTHELLO.
 I should be wise; for honesty's a fool,
    And loses that it works for.
                  Would? Nay, I will.
 I lay with Cassio lately
    And, being troubled with a raging tooth,
    I could not sleep.
 But this denoted a foregone conclusion.
 I know not that; but such a handkerchief-
    I am sure it was your wife's- did I today
    See Cassio wipe his beard with.

  OTHELLO.

    Now do I see 'tis true.

    Arise, black vengeance, from thy hollow hell!
    Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne
    To tyrannous hate! Swell, bosom, with thy fraught,
    For 'tis of aspics' tongues!
  IAGO.
 O, blood, blood, blood!
  IAGO.
            Damn her, lewd minx! O, damn her!
    Come, go with me apart; I will withdraw,
    To furnish me with some swift means of death
    For the fair devil.

  IAGO.
 I am your own forever.

  DESDEMONA.
 Can anything be made of this?
  CLOWN.
 I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a lodging,
    and say he lies here or he lies there, were to lie in mine own
    throat.
 Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?
  EMILIA.
 I will not leave him now till Cassio
    Be call'd to him.
               Well, my good lord.

  OTHELLO.

  DESDEMONA.
 That handkerchief
    Did an Egyptian to my mother give;
    She was a charmer, and could almost read
    The thoughts of people.

  DESDEMONA.
 Why, so I can, sir, but I will not now.

    This is a trick to put me from my suit.
  
    Pray you, let Cassio be received again.
 The handkerchief!
  DESDEMONA.
 The handkerchief!
  DESDEMONA.
 Is not this man jealous?
  DESDEMONA.

    Sure there's some wonder in this handkerchief;
    I am most unhappy in the loss of it.

    They are all but stomachs and we all but food;
    They eat us hungerly, and when they are full  
    They belch us.
 How now, good Cassio! What's the news with you?
  CASSIO.
 Madam, my former suit: I do beseech you
    That by your virtuous means I may again
    Exist and be a member of his love
    Whom I with all the office of my heart
    Entirely honor.
           Alas, thrice-gentle Cassio!
    My advocation is not now in tune;
    My lord is not my lord, nor should I know him
    Were he in favor as in humor alter'd.
 Is my lord angry?
  EMILIA.

  DESDEMONA.
 Nay, we must think men are not gods,
    Nor of them look for such observancy
    As fits the bridal.
 Beshrew me much, Emilia,
    I was, unhandsome warrior as I am,
    Arraigning his unkindness with my soul;
    But now I find I had suborn'd the witness,
    And he's indicted falsely.

  DESDEMONA.

  CASSIO.

  BIANCA.

    What, keep a week away? seven days and nights?
    Eight score eight hours? and lovers' absent hours,  
    More tedious than the dial eight score times?
    O weary reckoning!
  CASSIO.

    Is't come to this? Well, well.
 Ere it be demanded-  
    As like enough it will- I'ld have it copied.
                       Why, I pray you?
  CASSIO.
 Not that I love you not.
                          But that you do not love me.


Enter Othello and Iago.

  IAGO.

    But if I give my wife a handkerchief-
  OTHELLO.
 What then?
  IAGO.

  OTHELLO.
 By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it.
                                           What,
    If I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
    Or heard him say- as knaves be such abroad,
    Who having, by their own importunate suit,
    Or voluntary dotage of some mistress,
    Convinced or supplied them, cannot choose
    But they must blab-
  OTHELLO.
              Hath he said anything?
  IAGO.
 Faith, that he did- I know not what he did.
 Work on,
    My medicine, work! Thus credulous fools are caught,
    And many worthy and chaste dames even thus,
    All guiltless, meet reproach.

    Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
    He will recover straight.

    How is it, general? Have you not hurt your head?
  OTHELLO.
 Dost thou mock me?
  IAGO.

    Would you would bear your fortune like a man!
  OTHELLO.
  
  IAGO.
 There's many a beast then in a populous city,
    And many a civil monster.
 Did he confess it?
  IAGO.
 Your case is better.

  IAGO.

  OTHELLO.
  
    He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain
    From the excess of laughter.


                           Re-enter Cassio.
 I never knew a woman love man so.
 She gives it out that you shall marry her.
 I marry her! What? A customer! I prithee, bear some charity
    to my wit; do not think it so unwholesome.

  CASSIO.
 This is the monkey's own giving out.
 She is persuaded I
    will marry her, out of her own love and flattery, not out of my
    promise.
 Iago beckons me; now he begins the story.

  CASSIO.
 She was here even now; she haunts me in every place.
 I was
    the other day talking on the sea bank with certain Venetians, and
    thither comes the bauble, and, by this hand, she falls me thus  
    about my neck-
  OTHELLO.

  CASSIO.
 Well, I must leave her company.
 'Tis such another fitchew! marry, a perfumed one.
 Wheresoever you had it, I'll take  
    out no work on't.

  IAGO.
 Prithee, come; will you?
  IAGO.
] How shall I murther him, Iago?
  IAGO.
 A fine woman! a fair
    woman! a sweet woman!
  IAGO.
 O, the world hath not a sweeter creature.

  IAGO.

  OTHELLO.
 She's the worse for all this.
 And then, of so gentle a
    condition!
  IAGO.
 O, 'tis foul in her.

  OTHELLO.
 I'll not expostulate
    with her, lest her body and beauty unprovide my mind again.

  IAGO.

  IAGO.
 Something from Venice, sure.
 'Tis Lodovico
    Come from the Duke.
  
  LODOVICO.
 The Duke and Senators of Venice greet you.

                                                  Gives him a letter.
 I kiss the instrument of their pleasures.

                                         Opens the letter, and reads.

  LODOVICO.
 I thank you.
 Are you sure of that?
  DESDEMONA.
 Devil!                                        Strikes her.

    Make her amends; she weeps.
  
  LODOVICO.
 What would you with her, sir?
  LODOVICO.

    Sir, she can turn and turn, and yet go on,
    And turn again; and she can weep, sir, weep;
    And she's obedient, as you say, obedient,
    Very obedient.
 Proceed you in your tears.
 He's that he is.
 You shall observe him,
    And his own courses will denote him so  
    That I may save my speech.
 I am sorry that I am deceived in him.

A room in the castle.
 Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.

  OTHELLO.

    If any wretch have put this in your head,
    Let heaven requite it with the serpent's curse!  
    For if she be not honest, chaste, and true,
    There's no man happy; the purest of their wives
    Is foul as slander.


  DESDEMONA.
] Some of your function, mistress,
    Leave procreants alone and shut the door;
    Cough, or cry "hem," if anybody come.
           Exit Emilia.
