ACT III.
 Miranda-O my father,
    I have broke your hest to say so!
  FERDINAND.
 Admir'd Miranda!
    What's dearest to the world! Full many a lady
    I have ey'd with best regard; and many a time
    Th' harmony of their tongues hath into bondage
    Brought my too diligent ear; for several virtues
    Have I lik'd several women, never any
    With so full soul, but some defect in her
    Did quarrel with the noblest grace she ow'd,  
    And put it to the foil; but you, O you,
    So perfect and so peerless, are created
    Of every creature's best!
  MIRANDA.

  MIRANDA.
 But this is trifling;  
    And all the more it seeks to hide itself,
    The bigger bulk it shows.
 To be your fellow
    You may deny me; but I'll be your servant,
    Whether you will or no.

  MIRANDA.
 I'll to my book;
    For yet ere supper time must I perform  
    Much business appertaining.
                             Exit




SCENE 2

Another part of the island

Enter CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO

  STEPHANO.
 Tell not me-when the butt is out we will drink
    water, not a drop before; therefore bear up, and board
    'em.

  TRINCULO.
 Drink, servant-monster, when I bid thee; thy
    eyes are almost set in thy head.
 Where should they be set else? He were a brave
    monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.
 Nor go neither; but you'll lie like dogs, and
    yet say nothing neither.

  STEPHANO.
 Thou liest.

  STEPHANO.
 Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in's tale,
    by this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.

  STEPHANO.
 Mum, then, and no more.

  STEPHANO.

  CALIBAN.
 What a pied ninny's this! Thou scurvy patch!
    I do beseech thy greatness, give him blows,
    And take his bottle from him.

  STEPHANO.

  STEPHANO.

  TRINCULO.
 Out o' your wits and
    hearing too? A pox o' your bottle! This can sack and
    drinking do.
 Beat him enough; after a little time, I'll beat
    him too.
 Come, proceed.

    And that most deeply to consider is
    The beauty of his daughter; he himself
    Calls her a nonpareil.
 Give me thy hand; I am sorry I beat thee; but
    while thou liv'st, keep a good tongue in thy head.
 This is the tune of our catch, play'd by the
    picture of Nobody.

  TRINCULO.
 Mercy
    upon us!
  CALIBAN.
 That shall be by and by; I remember the story.
 Lead, monster; we'll follow.

  ANTONIO.
  [Aside to ANTONIO]  The next advantage  
    Will we take throughly.

  ANTONIO.
  [Aside to SEBASTIAN]  Let it be to-night;
    For, now they are oppress'd with travel, they
    Will not, nor cannot, use such vigilance
    As when they are fresh.
  [Aside to ANTONIO]  I say, to-night; no more.
 A living drollery.

  ALONSO.
 I will stand to, and feed,
    Although my last; no matter, since I feel
    The best is past.
 Enter ARIEL, like a harpy;
       claps his wings upon the table; and, with a quaint
                device, the banquet vanishes  

  ARIEL.
 Bravely the figure of this harpy hast thou
    Perform'd, my Ariel; a grace it had, devouring.
 My high charms work,
    And these mine enemies are all knit up
    In their distractions.
 They now are in my pow'r;
    And in these fits I leave them, while I visit
    Young Ferdinand, whom they suppose is drown'd,
    And his and mine lov'd darling.
 Follow, I pray you.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.
 O Ferdinand!
    Do not smile at me that I boast her off,
    For thou shalt find she will outstrip all praise,
    And make it halt behind her.

  PROSPERO.
 But
    If thou dost break her virgin-knot before
    All sanctimonious ceremonies may  
    With full and holy rite be minist'red,
    No sweet aspersion shall the heavens let fall
    To make this contract grow; but barren hate,
    Sour-ey'd disdain, and discord, shall bestrew
    The union of your bed with weeds so loathly
    That you shall hate it both.

  PROSPERO.

    Incite them to quick motion; for I must
    Bestow upon the eyes of this young couple
    Some vanity of mine art; it is my promise,
    And they expect it from me.

  ARIEL.

  PROSPERO.
 Her peacocks fly amain.

  IRIS.

  JUNO.
 Earth's increase, foison plenty,
    Barns and gamers never empty;
    Vines with clust'ring bunches growing,
    Plants with goodly burden bowing;
    Spring come to you at the farthest,
    In the very end of harvest!
    Scarcity and want shall shun you,
    Ceres' blessing so is on you.
 Sweet now, silence;
    Juno and Ceres whisper seriously.

    There's something else to do; hush, and be mute,
    Or else our spell is marr'd.
  

                      Enter certain NYMPHS

    You sun-burnt sicklemen, of August weary,
    Come hither from the furrow, and be merry;
    Make holiday; your rye-straw hats put on,
    And these fresh nymphs encounter every one
    In country footing.
  [Aside]  I had forgot that foul conspiracy
    Of the beast Caliban and his confederates
    Against my life; the minute of their plot
    Is almost come.
 Never till this day
    Saw I him touch'd with anger so distemper'd.
 We are such stuff
    As dreams are made on; and our little life
    Is rounded with a sleep.

    If you be pleas'd, retire into my cell  
    And there repose; a turn or two I'll walk
    To still my beating mind.
 I will plague them all,
    Even to roaring.

  
       Re-enter ARIEL, loaden with glistering apparel, &c.

                          [PROSPERO and ARIEL remain, invisible]

         Enter CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO, all wet

  CALIBAN.
 Pray you, tread softly, that the blind mole may not
    Hear a foot fall; we now are near his cell.
 Thou wert but a lost monster.

    Be patient, for the prize I'll bring thee to
    Shall hoodwink this mischance; therefore speak softly.
 There is not only disgrace and dishonour in
    that, monster, but an infinite loss.

  CALIBAN.

    Do that good mischief which may make this island
    Thine own for ever, and I, thy Caliban,
    For aye thy foot-licker.
 O King Stephano!
  STEPHANO.

  CALIBAN.
 I thank thee for that jest; here's a garment
    for't.
 I will have none on't.

  STEPHANO.
 Monster, lay-to your fingers; help to bear this
    away where my hogshead of wine is, or I'll turn you out
    of my kingdom.


          A noise of hunters beard.
 Hey, Mountain, hey!
  ARIEL.
 At this hour
    Lies at my mercy all mine enemies.
 I did say so,
    When first I rais'd the tempest.
 And mine shall.
 I'll fetch them, sir.
 But this rough magic
    I here abjure; and, when I have requir'd  
    Some heavenly music-which even now I do-
    To work mine end upon their senses that
    This airy charm is for, I'll break my staff,
    Bury it certain fathoms in the earth,
    And deeper than did ever plummet sound
    I'll drown my book.
 Why, that's my dainty Ariel! I shall miss thee;
    But yet thou shalt have freedom.
 Behold, Sir King,
    The wronged Duke of Milan, Prospero.
 Whe'er thou be'st he or no,
    Or some enchanted trifle to abuse me,
    As late I have been, I not know.
 Thy pulse
    Beats, as of flesh and blood; and, since I saw thee,
    Th' affliction of my mind amends, with which,
    I fear, a madness held me.

  GONZALO.

  PROSPERO.
 No.

  PROSPERO.

  PROSPERO.
 In this last tempest.
 I perceive these lords
    At this encounter do so much admire
    That they devour their reason, and scarce think
    Their eyes do offices of truth, their words
    Are natural breath; but, howsoe'er you have
    Been justled from your senses, know for certain
    That I am Prospero, and that very duke
    Which was thrust forth of Milan; who most strangely
    Upon this shore, where you were wrecked, was landed
    To be the lord on't.

    My dukedom since you have given me again,
    I will requite you with as good a thing;
    At least bring forth a wonder, to content ye
    As much as me my dukedom.


          Here PROSPERO discovers FERDINAND and MIRANDA,
                      playing at chess

  MIRANDA.
 No, my dearest love,
    I would not for the world.
 Now all the blessings
    Of a glad father compass thee about!
    Arise, and say how thou cam'st here.

    I chose her when I could not ask my father
    For his advice, nor thought I had one.

  GONZALO.
 I have inly wept,
    Or should have spoke ere this.
 I say, Amen, Gonzalo!
  GONZALO.
  [To FERDINAND and MIRANDA]  Give me your
    hands.
 Be it so.
  [Aside to ARIEL]  My tricksy spirit!
  ALONSO.

  ARIEL.
 Thou  
    shalt be free.
 Coragio,
    bully-monster, coragio!
  TRINCULO.

  SEBASTIAN.
 Mark but the badges of these men, my lords,
    Then say if they be true.
 This mis-shapen knave-
    His mother was a witch, and one so strong
    That could control the moon, make flows and ebbs,
    And deal in her command without her power.
 Why, how now, Stephano!
  STEPHANO.
 You'd be king o' the isle, sirrah?
  STEPHANO.
 Go, sirrah, to my cell;
    Take with you your companions; as you look
    To have my pardon, trim it handsomely.
 What a thrice-double ass
    Was I to take this drunkard for a god,
    And worship this dull fool!
  PROSPERO.
 Hence, and bestow your luggage where you found it.
 Or stole it, rather.

  ALONSO.
 I long
    To hear the story of your life, which must
    Take the ear strangely.
  [Aside to ARIEL]  My Ariel,
      chick,
    That is thy charge.
 Let me not,
          Since I have my dukedom got,
          And pardon'd the deceiver, dwell
          In this bare island by your spell;
          But release me from my bands
          With the help of your good hands.

          Gentle breath of yours my sails
          Must fill, or else my project fails,
          Which was to please.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

Athens.

  PAINTER.

  POET.
 Ay, that's well known.

  PAINTER.
 O, pray let's see't.
 If he will touch the estimate.

  MERCHANT.

  JEWELLER.

  PAINTER.

  POET.
 'Tis a good piece.

  POET.
  
  PAINTER.
 How this lord is followed!
  POET.
 You see this confluence, this great flood of visitors.
 I will unbolt to you.

    You see how all conditions, how all minds-
    As well of glib and slipp'ry creatures as
    Of grave and austere quality, tender down
    Their services to Lord Timon.
 The base o' th' mount
    Is rank'd with all deserts, all kind of natures
    That labour on the bosom of this sphere
    To propagate their states.

    This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks,
    With one man beckon'd from the rest below,
    Bowing his head against the steepy mount
    To climb his happiness, would be well express'd
    In our condition.
 When Fortune in her shift and change of mood
    Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants,
    Which labour'd after him to the mountain's top
    Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down,
    Not one accompanying his declining foot.
 'Tis common.

    Your honourable letter he desires
    To those have shut him up; which failing,
    Periods his comfort.
 Here, at your lordship's service.

  OLD ATHENIAN.
 I am a man
    That from my first have been inclin'd to thrift,
    And my estate deserves an heir more rais'd
    Than one which holds a trencher.
 The man is honest.

  OLD ATHENIAN.
  
    To build his fortune I will strain a little,
    For 'tis a bond in men.

  LUCILIUS.
 Never may
    That state or fortune fall into my keeping
    Which is not owed to you!
                                Exeunt LUCILIUS and OLD ATHENIAN
  POET.

    The painting is almost the natural man;
    For since dishonour traffics with man's nature,  
    He is but outside; these pencill'd figures are
    Even such as they give out.
 The gods preserve ye!
  TIMON.
 No, my good lord; he speaks the common tongue,
    Which all men speak with him.
 Look who comes here; will you be chid?
  JEWELLER.
 We'll bear, with your lordship.

  MERCHANT.
 Why dost thou call them knaves? Thou know'st them not.
 Are they not Athenians?
  TIMON.

  JEWELLER.
 Thou know'st I do; I call'd thee by thy name.
 Thou art proud, Apemantus.

  APEMANTUS.
 Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.
 That's a deed thou't die for.
 He wrought better that made the painter; and yet he's
    but a filthy piece of work.
 An thou shouldst, thou'dst anger ladies.

  APEMANTUS.
 So thou apprehend'st it take it for thy labour.

  TIMON.
 What dost thou think 'tis worth?
  APEMANTUS.
 Not worth my thinking.
 Then thou liest.
 Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy
    labour.
 Ay.
 That I had no angry wit to be a lord.
 Ay, Apemantus.

  TIMON.
 When dinner's done
    Show me this piece.
 I am joyful of your sights.
 Right welcome, sir!
    Ere we depart we'll share a bounteous time
    In different pleasures.
 Thou art going to Lord Timon's feast.
 Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.
  
  SECOND LORD.
 Hang thyself.
 He pours it out: Plutus, the god of gold,
    Is but his steward; no meed but he repays
    Sevenfold above itself; no gift to him
    But breeds the giver a return exceeding
    All use of quittance.

Then comes, dropping after all, APEMANTUS, discontentedly, like himself

  VENTIDIUS.
 O, by no means,
    Honest Ventidius! You mistake my love;
    I gave it freely ever; and there's none
    Can truly say he gives, if he receives.
 A noble spirit!
  TIMON.
 Ho, ho, confess'd it! Hang'd it, have you not?
  TIMON.

    I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.
 Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon.
 Let it flow this way, my good lord.

    This and my food are equals; there's no odds.

  ALCIBIADES.

  TIMON.
 You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than dinner of
    friends.
 Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that you
    would once use our hearts, whereby we might express some part of
    our zeals, we should think ourselves for ever perfect.
 O you gods, think I, what
    need we have any friends if we should ne'er have need of 'em?
    They were the most needless creatures living, should we ne'er
    have use for 'em; and would most resemble sweet instruments hung  
    up in cases, that keep their sounds to themselves.

  THIRD LORD.
 I promise you, my lord, you mov'd me much.
 Much!                                [Sound tucket]
  TIMON.
 Ladies! What are their wills?
  SERVANT.
 There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, which bears
    that office to signify their pleasures.
 Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all
    That of his bounties taste! The five best Senses
    Acknowledge thee their patron, and come freely
    To gratulate thy plenteous bosom.
 They're welcome all; let 'em have kind admittance.
 Hoy-day, what a sweep of vanity comes this way!
    They dance? They are mad women.

    We make ourselves fools to disport ourselves,
    And spend our flatteries to drink those men
    Upon whose age we void it up again
    With poisonous spite and envy.
 Faith, for the worst is filthy, and would not hold
    taking, I doubt me.

  ALL LADIES.

                                         Exeunt CUPID and LADIES
  TIMON.
 My lord?
  TIMON.
 Here, my lord, in readiness.
 Look you, my good lord,
    I must entreat you honour me so much
    As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it,
    Kind my lord.


                       Enter a SERVANT

  SERVANT.

  TIMON.
 [Aside] What will this come to?
    He commands us to provide and give great gifts,
    And all out of an empty coffer;
    Nor will he know his purse, or yield me this,
    To show him what a beggar his heart is,
    Being of no power to make his wishes good.

    Well, would I were gently put out of office
    Before I were forc'd out!
    Happier is he that has no friend to feed
    Than such that do e'en enemies exceed.
                           Exit
  TIMON.
 With more than common thanks I will receive it.
 I take all and your several visitations
    So kind to heart 'tis not enough to give;
    Methinks I could deal kingdoms to my friends
    And ne'er be weary.
 Alcibiades,
    Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich.

    It comes in charity to thee; for all thy living
    Is 'mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast
    Lie in a pitch'd field.
 Lights, more lights!
  FIRST LORD.
 Ready for his friends.

    Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on curtsies.

    If I would sell my horse and buy twenty moe
    Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon,
    Ask nothing, give it him, it foals me straight,
    And able horses.
 Caphis, ho!
    Caphis, I say!

                         Enter CAPHIS
  
  CAPHIS.
 Here, sir; what is your pleasure?
  SENATOR.
 Get you gone;
    Put on a most importunate aspect,
    A visage of demand; for I do fear,
    When every feather sticks in his own wing,
    Lord Timon will be left a naked gull,
    Which flashes now a phoenix.
 Never mind
    Was to be so unwise to be so kind.
 Now he comes from hunting.
 What, you come for money?
  VARRO'S SERVANT.
 Is't not your business too?
  CAPHIS.
 And yours too, Isidore?
  ISIDORE'S SERVANT.

  CAPHIS.
 Here comes the lord.
 Of Athens here, my lord.

  CAPHIS.

  TIMON.

    See them well entertain'd.

    Let's ha' some sport with 'em.
 A plague upon him, dog!
  VARRO'S SERVANT.
 No, 'tis to thyself.
 What are we, Apemantus?
  APEMANTUS.
 That you ask me what you are, and do not know
    yourselves.
 She's e'en setting on water to scald such chickens as you
    are.

  APEMANTUS.

  PAGE.

    Answer not: I am gone.
 E'en so thou outrun'st grace.
 If Timon stay at home.
 So would I- as good a trick as ever hangman serv'd
    thief.
 Ay, fool.
 I think no usurer but has a fool to his servant.
 My mistress  
    is one, and I am her fool.

  VARRO'S SERVANT.

  APEMANTUS.

  VARRO'S SERVANT.
 I do not always follow lover, elder brother, and woman;
    sometime the philosopher.
 O my good lord,
    At many times I brought in my accounts,  
    Laid them before you; you would throw them off
    And say you found them in mine honesty.

  TIMON.

  FLAVIUS.
 The future comes apace;
    What shall defend the interim? And at length
    How goes our reck'ning?
  TIMON.

  FLAVIUS.

  TIMON.

  FLAVIUS.

    No villainous bounty yet hath pass'd my heart;
    Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given.

    Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack
    To think I shall lack friends? Secure thy heart:
    If I would broach the vessels of my love,
    And try the argument of hearts by borrowing,
    Men and men's fortunes could I frankly use
    As I can bid thee speak.

  FLAVIUS.
 Assurance bless your thoughts!
  TIMON.
 You shall perceive how you
    Mistake my fortunes; I am wealthy in my friends.

    Within there! Flaminius! Servilius!

           Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and another SERVANT
  
  SERVANTS.
 My lord! my lord!
  TIMON.

  FLAMINIUS.
 [Aside] Lord Lucius and Lucullus? Humh!
  TIMON.

  TIMON.
 When he was poor,  
    Imprison'd, and in scarcity of friends,
    I clear'd him with five talents.

  FLAMINIUS.
 I thank you, sir.
 Fill me some wine.

  LUCULLUS.
 Here's to thee.
 Your lordship speaks your pleasure.
 Here's three solidares for thee.
 Is't possible the world should so much differ,
    And we alive that liv'd? Fly, damned baseness,
    To him that worships thee.

 Exit
  FLAMINIUS.
 May these add to the number that may scald thee!
    Let molten coin be thy damnation,
    Thou disease of a friend and not himself!
    Has friendship such a faint and milky heart
    It turns in less than two nights? O you gods,
    I feel my master's passion! This slave
    Unto his honour has my lord's meat in him;
    Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment
    When he is turn'd to poison?  
    O, may diseases only work upon't!
    And when he's sick to death, let not that part of nature
    Which my lord paid for be of any power
    To expel sickness, but prolong his hour!                Exit




SCENE II.
 But I can tell you one thing, my lord, and
    which I hear from common rumours: now Lord Timon's happy hours
    are done and past, and his estate shrinks from him.
 But believe you this, my lord, that not long ago
     one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus to borrow so many
    talents; nay, urg'd extremely for't, and showed what necessity
    belong'd to't, and yet was denied.
 I tell you, denied, my lord.
 See, by good hap, yonder's my lord; I have sweat to see
    his honour.
 Servilius? You are kindly met, sir.
 Ha! What has he sent? I am so much endeared to that lord:
    he's ever sending.
 Has only sent his present occasion now, my lord,
    requesting your lordship to supply his instant use with so many
    talents.

  LUCIUS.
 I know his lordship is but merry with me;
    He cannot want fifty-five hundred talents.
 Good Servilius, will you befriend me so far
    as to use mine own words to him?
  SERVILIUS.
 Who can call him his friend
    That dips in the same dish? For, in my knowing,
    Timon has been this lord's father,
    And kept his credit with his purse;
    Supported his estate; nay, Timon's money
    Has paid his men their wages.

  FIRST STRANGER.
 But I perceive
    Men must learn now with pity to dispense;
    For policy sits above conscience.

SEMPRONIUS' house

Enter SEMPRONIUS and a SERVANT of TIMON'S

  SEMPRONIUS.
 Must he needs trouble me in't? Hum! 'Bove all others?
    He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus;
    And now Ventidius is wealthy too,
    Whom he redeem'd from prison.

  SERVANT.
 My lord,
    They have all been touch'd and found base metal, for
    They have all denied him.

    Must I be his last refuge? His friends, like physicians,
    Thrice give him over.
 I see no sense for't,
    But his occasions might have woo'd me first;  
    For, in my conscience, I was the first man
    That e'er received gift from him.
 How fairly this lord strives to appear foul!
    Takes virtuous copies to be wicked, like those that under hot
    ardent zeal would set whole realms on fire.
         Exit




SCENE IV.

  LUCIUS' SERVANT.
 welcome, good brother, what do you think the hour?
  PHILOTUS.
 So much?
  PHILOTUS.
 I am of your fear for that.
 I'll show you how t' observe a strange event.

  HORTENSIUS.

  HORTENSIUS.

  LUCIUS' SERVANT.
 Five thousand mine.
 We attend his lordship; pray signify so much.

  FLAVIUS.
 What do ye ask of me, my friend?
  TITUS.

    Believe't, my lord and I have made an end:
    I have no more to reckon, he to spend.

  FLAVIUS.
 If 'twill not serve, 'tis not so base as you,
    For you serve knaves.
 No matter what; he's poor, and that's
    revenge enough.

  SERVILIUS.
 Good gods!  
  TITUS.

  FLAMINIUS.
 And mine, my lord.
 And ours, my lord.
 Alas, my lord-
  TIMON.

  TITUS.
  
  TIMON.
 Tell out my blood.
 Five thousand crowns, my lord.

  TIMON.
 Five thousand drops pays that.
 These debts may well be call'd desperate ones, for a
    madman owes 'em.
                                      Exeunt

                    Re-enter TIMON and FLAVIUS

  TIMON.

    Creditors? Devils!
  FLAVIUS.
 My dear lord-
  TIMON.
 My lord-
  TIMON.
 I'll have it so.

    Go, I charge thee, invite them all; let in the tide
    Of knaves once more; my cook and I'll provide.
 My lord, you have my voice to't: the fault's bloody.

  SECOND SENATOR.

    It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy
    Upon a friend of mine, who in hot blood
    Hath stepp'd into the law, which is past depth
    To those that without heed do plunge into't.
  
    If wrongs be evils, and enforce us kill,
    What folly 'tis to hazard life for ill!
  ALCIBIADES.
 My lord-
  FIRST SENATOR.

  ALCIBIADES.
 What's that?
  ALCIBIADES.
 Why, I say, my lords, has done fair service,
    And slain in fight many of your enemies;
    How full of valour did he bear himself
    In the last conflict, and made plenteous wounds!
  SECOND SENATOR.
 Friend or brother,
    He forfeits his own blood that spills another.
 How!
  ALCIBIADES.

  ALCIBIADES.
 Banish me!
    Banish your dotage! Banish usury
    That makes the Senate ugly.

A banqueting hall in TIMON'S house

Music.
 Tables set out; servants attending.

  SECOND LORD.
 Upon that were my thoughts tiring when we encount'red.
 Every man here's so.
 A thousand pieces!
  FIRST LORD.
 He sent to me, sir- here he comes.
 [Aside] Nor more willingly leaves winter; such summer-birds
    are men- Gentlemen, our dinner will not recompense this long
    stay; feast your ears with the music awhile, if they will fare so
    harshly o' th' trumpet's sound; we shall to't presently.

  FIRST LORD.
 My most honourable lord, I am e'en sick of shame that,
    when your lordship this other day sent to me, I was so
    unfortunate a beggar.
 Think not on't, sir.
 If you had sent but two hours before-
  TIMON.
 How do you? What's the news?
  THIRD LORD.
 I'll tell you more anon.

  THIRD LORD.
 It does; but time will- and so-
  THIRD LORD.
 Each man to his stool with that spur as he would to the lip
    of his mistress; your diet shall be in all places alike.

    For your own gifts make yourselves prais'd; but reserve still to
    give, lest your deities be despised.
 I know not.

  FOURTH LORD.

  THIRD LORD.
 One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones.

                                                          Exeunt




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

Without the walls of Athens

Enter TIMON

  TIMON.

    The gods confound- hear me, you good gods all-  
    The Athenians both within and out that wall!
    And grant, as Timon grows, his hate may grow
    To the whole race of mankind, high and low!
    Amen.
 Hear you, Master Steward, where's our master?
    Are we undone, cast off, nothing remaining?
  FLAVIUS.
 As we do turn our backs
    From our companion, thrown into his grave,
    So his familiars to his buried fortunes
    Slink all away; leave their false vows with him,
    Like empty purses pick'd; and his poor self,
    A dedicated beggar to the air,
    With his disease of all-shunn'd poverty,
    Walks, like contempt, alone.
 All broken implements of a ruin'd house.

  FLAVIUS.

                                [Embrace, and part several ways]  
    O the fierce wretchedness that glory brings us!
    Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt,
    Since riches point to misery and contempt?
    Who would be so mock'd with glory, or to live
    But in a dream of friendship,
    To have his pomp, and all what state compounds,
    But only painted, like his varnish'd friends?
    Poor honest lord, brought low by his own heart,
    Undone by goodness! Strange, unusual blood,
    When man's worst sin is he does too much good!
    Who then dares to be half so kind again?
    For bounty, that makes gods, does still mar men.

    I'll ever serve his mind with my best will;  
    Whilst I have gold, I'll be his steward still.
 O blessed breeding sun, draw from the earth
    Rotten humidity; below thy sister's orb
    Infect the air! Twinn'd brothers of one womb-
    Whose procreation, residence, and birth,
    Scarce is dividant- touch them with several fortunes:
    The greater scorns the lesser.

    It is the pasture lards the rother's sides,
    The want that makes him lean.
 Thou't go, strong thief,
    When gouty keepers of thee cannot stand.

    For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dog,
    That I might love thee something.
 I know thee well;
    But in thy fortunes am unlearn'd and strange.
 Thy lips rot off!
  TIMON.
 Noble Timon,
    What friendship may I do thee?
  TIMON.

  ALCIBIADES.

  TIMANDRA.
 Art thou Timandra?
  TIMANDRA.

  TIMANDRA.

    I have but little gold of late, brave Timon,
    The want whereof doth daily make revolt
    In my penurious band.
 Ay, Timon, and have cause.
  
  TIMON.
 The gods confound them all in thy conquest;
    And thee after, when thou hast conquer'd!
  ALCIBIADES.
 Why me, Timon?
  TIMON.
 Go on.
 Swear against abjects;
    Put armour on thine ears and on thine eyes,
    Whose proof nor yells of mothers, maids, nor babes,
    Nor sight of priests in holy vestments bleeding,
    Shall pierce a jot.
 What then?
    Believe't that we'll do anything for gold.
 Consumptions sow
    In hollow bones of man; strike their sharp shins,
    And mar men's spurring.
 Down with the nose,
    Down with it flat, take the bridge quite away
    Of him that, his particular to foresee,
    Smells from the general weal.

  ALCIBIADES.

  TIMON.

  TIMON.
 That nature, being sick of man's unkindness,  
    Should yet be hungry! Common mother, thou,         [Digging]
    Whose womb unmeasurable and infinite breast
    Teems and feeds all; whose self-same mettle,
    Whereof thy proud child, arrogant man, is puff'd,
    Engenders the black toad and adder blue,
    The gilded newt and eyeless venom'd worm,
    With all th' abhorred births below crisp heaven
    Whereon Hyperion's quick'ning fire doth shine-
    Yield him, who all thy human sons doth hate,
    From forth thy plenteous bosom, one poor root!
    Ensear thy fertile and conceptious womb,
    Let it no more bring out ingrateful man!
    Go great with tigers, dragons, wolves, and bears;
    Teem with new monsters whom thy upward face
    Hath to the marbled mansion all above
    Never presented!- O, a root! Dear thanks!-
    Dry up thy marrows, vines, and plough-torn leas,
    Whereof ingrateful man, with liquorish draughts
    And morsels unctuous, greases his pure mind,
    That from it all consideration slips-  

                        Enter APEMANTUS

    More man? Plague, plague!
  APEMANTUS.

    Be thou a flatterer now, and seek to thrive
    By that which has undone thee: hinge thy knee,
    And let his very breath whom thou'lt observe
    Blow off thy cap; praise his most vicious strain,  
    And call it excellent.

  TIMON.

  APEMANTUS.
 I flatter not, but say thou art a caitiff.
 Thou'dst courtier be again
    Wert thou not beggar.

    The one is filling still, never complete;
    The other, at high wish.

  TIMON.

  APEMANTUS.
 Ay, that I am not thee.

  APEMANTUS.

    That the whole life of Athens were in this!
    Thus would I eat it.
 First mend my company: take away thyself.
 What wouldst thou have to Athens?
  TIMON.

  APEMANTUS.
 Under that's above me.

    Where feed'st thou a days, Apemantus?
  APEMANTUS.
 finds meat; or rather, where I eat it.
 To sauce thy dishes.
 When thou wast in thy gilt and thy
    perfume, they mock'd thee for too much curiosity; in thy rags  
    thou know'st none, but art despis'd for the contrary.
 There's a
    medlar for thee; eat it.

  TIMON.

  APEMANTUS.
 Women nearest; but men, men are the things themselves.

  TIMON.
 The commonwealth of Athens is
    become a forest of beasts.
 When I
    know not what else to do, I'll see thee again.

  TIMON.
 Would thou wert clean enough to spit upon!
  APEMANTUS.
 There is no leprosy but what thou speak'st.
 If I name thee.

  APEMANTUS.
 I would my tongue could rot them off!
  TIMON.
 Away,  
    Thou tedious rogue! I am sorry I shall lose
    A stone by thee.
 Rogue, rogue, rogue!
    I am sick of this false world, and will love nought
    But even the mere necessities upon't.

    Then, Timon, presently prepare thy grave;
    Lie where the light foam of the sea may beat
    Thy gravestone daily; make thine epitaph,
    That death in me at others' lives may laugh.

  APEMANTUS.
 Let us make the assay upon him; if he care not for't,
    he will supply us easily; if he covetously reserve it, how
    shall's get it?
  SECOND BANDIT.
 We cannot live on grass, on berries, water,
    As beasts and birds and fishes.
 I'll example you with thievery:
    The sun's a thief, and with his great attraction
    Robs the vast sea; the moon's an arrant thief,
    And her pale fire she snatches from the sun;
    The sea's a thief, whose liquid surge resolves
    The moon into salt tears; the earth's a thief,
    That feeds and breeds by a composture stol'n  
    From gen'ral excrement- each thing's a thief.
 Cut throats;
    All that you meet are thieves.
 To Athens go,
    Break open shops; nothing can you steal
    But thieves do lose it.
 Steal not less for this
    I give you; and gold confound you howsoe'er!
    Amen.
              Exeunt THIEVES

                         Enter FLAVIUS, to TIMON
  
  FLAVIUS.
 Away! What art thou?
  FLAVIUS.
  
  TIMON.
 Then I know thee not.

    How fain would I have hated all mankind!
    And thou redeem'st thyself.
 Look thee, 'tis so! Thou singly honest man,
    Here, take.
 Be men like blasted woods,
    And may diseases lick up their false bloods!
    And so, farewell and thrive.
 O, let me stay
    And comfort you, my master.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 SCENE I.
 Before TIMON's cave

Enter POET and PAINTER

  PAINTER.
 As I took note of the place, it cannot be far where he
    abides.
  
  POET.
 Good as the best.
 Performance is ever the duller
    for his act, and but in the plainer and simpler kind of people
    the deed of saying is quite out of use.
 I am thinking what I shall say I have provided for him.

  TIMON.
 [Aside] Must thou needs stand for a villain in thine own
    work? Wilt thou whip thine own faults in other men? Do so, I have  
    gold for thee.
 Nay, let's seek him;
    Then do we sin against our own estate
    When we may profit meet and come too late.
 True;
    When the day serves, before black-corner'd night,
    Find what thou want'st by free and offer'd light.

    To thee be worship! and thy saints for aye
    Be crown'd with plagues, that thee alone obey!
    Fit I meet them.
                   [Advancing from his cave]
  POET.
 Sir,  
    Having often of your open bounty tasted,
    Hearing you were retir'd, your friends fall'n off,
    Whose thankless natures- O abhorred spirits!-
    Not all the whips of heaven are large enough-
    What! to you,
    Whose star-like nobleness gave life and influence
    To their whole being! I am rapt, and cannot cover
    The monstrous bulk of this ingratitude
    With any size of words.

    You that are honest, by being what you are,
    Make them best seen and known.
 We are hither come to offer you our service.
 Most honest men! Why, how shall I requite you?
    Can you eat roots, and drink cold water- No?
  BOTH.
 What we can do, we'll do, to do you service.

  PAINTER.
 Good honest men! Thou draw'st a counterfeit
    Best in all Athens.

  TIMON.
 [To To POET] And for thy fiction,
    Why, thy verse swells with stuff so fine and smooth
    That thou art even natural in thine art.

    Marry, 'tis not monstrous in you; neither wish I
    You take much pains to mend.
 Most thankfully, my lord.
 Doubt it not, worthy lord.

  BOTH.
 I know not such, my lord.

    Hang them or stab them, drown them in a draught,
    Confound them by some course, and come to me,
    I'll give you gold enough.

  BOTH.
 Name them, my lord; let's know them.

    [To the PAINTER] If, where thou art, two villians shall not be,  
    Come not near him.

    [To the PAINTER] You have work for me; there's payment; hence!
    [To the POET] You are an alchemist; make gold of that.
 Thou sun that comforts, burn.
 O, forget  
    What we are sorry for ourselves in thee.
 They confess
    Toward thee forgetfulness too general, gross;
    Which now the public body, which doth seldom
    Play the recanter, feeling in itself
    A lack of Timon's aid, hath sense withal
    Of it own fail, restraining aid to Timon,
    And send forth us to make their sorrowed render,
    Together with a recompense more fruitful
    Than their offence can weigh down by the dram;
    Ay, even such heaps and sums of love and wealth
    As shall to thee blot out what wrongs were theirs
    And write in thee the figures of their love,
    Ever to read them thine.

  TIMON.
 Therefore, Timon-
  TIMON.
 Well, sir, I will.
 Therefore I will, sir, thus:
    If Alcibiades kill my countrymen,
    Let Alcibiades know this of Timon,
    That Timon cares not.

  FLAVIUS.
 Stay not, all's in vain.
 Why, I was writing of my epitaph;
    It will be seen to-morrow.
 Go, live still;
    Be Alcibiades your plague, you his,
    And last so long enough!
  FIRST SENATOR.

  FIRST SENATOR.
 I have a tree, which grows here in my close,
    That mine own use invites me to cut down,
    And shortly must I fell it.
 Tell my friends,
    Tell Athens, in the sequence of degree
    From high to low throughout, that whoso please  
    To stop affliction, let him take his haste,
    Come hither, ere my tree hath felt the axe,
    And hang himself.
 His discontents are unremovably
    Coupled to nature.
 Thou hast painfully discover'd; are his files
    As full as thy report?
  MESSENGER.
 We stand much hazard if they bring not Timon.
 This man was riding
    From Alcibiades to Timon's cave
    With letters of entreaty, which imported
    His fellowship i' th' cause against your city,
    In part for his sake mov'd.
 No talk of Timon, nothing of him expect.

The TIMON's cave, and a rude tomb seen

Enter a SOLDIER in the woods, seeking TIMON

  SOLDIER.
                 Exit




SCENE IV.
 Enter ALCIBIADES with his powers before Athens

  ALCIBIADES.
 The SENATORS appear upon the walls

    Till now you have gone on and fill'd the time
    With all licentious measure, making your wills
    The scope of justice; till now, myself, and such
    As slept within the shadow of your power,
    Have wander'd with our travers'd arms, and breath'd
    Our sufferance vainly.
 So did we woo
    Transformed Timon to our city's love
    By humble message and by promis'd means.

  FIRST SENATOR.
 Like a shepherd
    Approach the fold and cull th' infected forth,
    But kill not all together.
 What thou wilt,
    Thou rather shalt enforce it with thy smile
    Than hew to't with thy sword.
 Set but thy foot
    Against our rampir'd gates and they shall ope,  
    So thou wilt send thy gentle heart before
    To say thou't enter friendly.

  ALCIBIADES.
 'Tis most nobly spoken.
'
    These well express in thee thy latter spirits.
 Dead
    Is noble Timon, of whose memory
    Hereafter more.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE

COMMERCIALLY.

1594

THE TRAGEDY OF TITUS ANDRONICUS

by William Shakespeare



Dramatis Personae

  SATURNINUS, son to the late Emperor of Rome, afterwards Emperor
  BASSIANUS, brother to Saturninus
  TITUS ANDRONICUS, a noble Roman
  MARCUS ANDRONICUS, Tribune of the People, and brother to Titus

    Sons to Titus Andronicus:
  LUCIUS
  QUINTUS
  MARTIUS
  MUTIUS

  YOUNG LUCIUS, a boy, son to Lucius
  PUBLIUS, son to Marcus Andronicus

    Kinsmen to Titus:
  SEMPRONIUS
  CAIUS
  VALENTINE

  AEMILIUS, a noble Roman  

    Sons to Tamora:
  ALARBUS
  DEMETRIUS
  CHIRON

  AARON, a Moor, beloved by Tamora
  A CAPTAIN
  A MESSENGER
  A CLOWN

  TAMORA, Queen of the Goths
  LAVINIA, daughter to Titus Andronicus
  A NURSE, and a black CHILD

  Romans and Goths, Senators, Tribunes, Officers, Soldiers, and
    Attendants




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
 Noble patricians, patrons of my right,
    Defend the justice of my cause with arms;
    And, countrymen, my loving followers,
    Plead my successive title with your swords.
 Princes, that strive by factions and by friends
    Ambitiously for rule and empery,
    Know that the people of Rome, for whom we stand
    A special party, have by common voice
    In election for the Roman empery
    Chosen Andronicus, surnamed Pius
    For many good and great deserts to Rome.

    He by the Senate is accited home,
    From weary wars against the barbarous Goths,
    That with his sons, a terror to our foes,
    Hath yok'd a nation strong, train'd up in arms.

  SATURNINUS.
 How fair the Tribune speaks to calm my thoughts.

                    [Flourish.
 They go up into the Senate House]

                      Enter a CAPTAIN  

  CAPTAIN.

    Thou great defender of this Capitol,
    Stand gracious to the rites that we intend!
    Romans, of five and twenty valiant sons,
    Half of the number that King Priam had,
    Behold the poor remains, alive and dead!
    These that survive let Rome reward with love;
    These that I bring unto their latest home,
    With burial amongst their ancestors.
 I give him you- the noblest that survives,
    The eldest son of this distressed queen.
 Stay, Roman brethen! Gracious conqueror,
    Victorious Titus, rue the tears I shed,
    A mother's tears in passion for her son;
    And if thy sons were ever dear to thee,
    O, think my son to be as dear to me!
    Sufficeth not that we are brought to Rome
    To beautify thy triumphs, and return
    Captive to thee and to thy Roman yoke;  
    But must my sons be slaughtered in the streets
    For valiant doings in their country's cause?
    O, if to fight for king and commonweal
    Were piety in thine, it is in these.
 Oppose not Scythia to ambitious Rome.
 Let it be so, and let Andronicus
    Make this his latest farewell to their souls.

  MARCUS.
 Romans, do me right.
 People of Rome, and people's Tribunes here,  
    I ask your voices and your suffrages:
    Will ye bestow them friendly on Andronicus?
  TRIBUNES.
 Tribunes, I thank you; and this suit I make,
    That you create our Emperor's eldest son,
    Lord Saturnine; whose virtues will, I hope,
    Reflect on Rome as Titan's rays on earth,
    And ripen justice in this commonweal.
 With voices and applause of every sort,
    Patricians and plebeians, we create
    Lord Saturninus Rome's great Emperor;
    And say 'Long live our Emperor Saturnine!'
                           [A long flourish till they come down]
  SATURNINUS.
 Titus Andronicus, for thy favours done
    To us in our election this day
    I give thee thanks in part of thy deserts,  
    And will with deeds requite thy gentleness;
    And for an onset, Titus, to advance
    Thy name and honourable family,
    Lavinia will I make my emperess,
    Rome's royal mistress, mistress of my heart,
    And in the sacred Pantheon her espouse.

    Tell me, Andronicus, doth this motion please thee?
  TITUS.

  SATURNINUS.
-
    Clear up, fair Queen, that cloudy countenance;
    Though chance of war hath wrought this change of cheer,
    Thou com'st not to be made a scorn in Rome-
    Princely shall be thy usage every way.

  SATURNINUS.

                                                      [Flourish]  
  BASSIANUS.
 Suum cuique is our Roman justice:
    This prince in justice seizeth but his own.

  TITUS.
 My lord, you pass not here.

  TITUS.

    Was there none else in Rome to make a stale
    But Saturnine? Full well, Andronicus,
    Agree these deeds with that proud brag of thine
    That saidst I begg'd the empire at thy hands.

  TITUS.
 And therefore, lovely Tamora, Queen of Goths,
    That, like the stately Phoebe 'mongst her nymphs,
    Dost overshine the gallant'st dames of Rome,
    If thou be pleas'd with this my sudden choice,
    Behold, I choose thee, Tamora, for my bride
    And will create thee Emperess of Rome.
  
    Speak, Queen of Goths, dost thou applaud my choice?
    And here I swear by all the Roman gods-
    Sith priest and holy water are so near,
    And tapers burn so bright, and everything
    In readiness for Hymenaeus stand-
    I will not re-salute the streets of Rome,
    Or climb my palace, till from forth this place
    I lead espous'd my bride along with me.
 O Titus, see, O, see what thou hast done!
    In a bad quarrel slain a virtuous son.

  TITUS.
 Traitors, away! He rests not in this tomb.

    Bury him where you can, he comes not here.

  MARCUS.
  
    My nephew Mutius' deeds do plead for him;
    He must be buried with his bretheren.
 Marcus, even thou hast struck upon my crest,
    And with these boys mine honour thou hast wounded.

  MARCUS.

    Thou art a Roman- be not barbarous.
 Rise, Marcus, rise;
    The dismal'st day is this that e'er I saw,
    To be dishonoured by my sons in Rome!
    Well, bury him, and bury me the next.
  [Kneeling]  No man shed tears for noble Mutius;
    He lives in fame that died in virtue's cause.
 Yes, and will nobly him remunerate.
 So, Bassianus, you have play'd your prize:
    God give you joy, sir, of your gallant bride!
  BASSIANUS.

  BASSIANUS.

    Rome and the righteous heavens be my judge
    How I have lov'd and honoured Saturnine!
  TAMORA.

  SATURNINUS.

    Then at my suit look graciously on him;
    Lose not so noble a friend on vain suppose,
    Nor with sour looks afflict his gentle heart.
 Rise, Titus, rise; my Empress hath prevail'd.

  TAMORA.

    And fear not, lords- and you, Lavinia.

  LUCIUS.
 We do, and vow to heaven and to his Highness
    That what we did was mildly as we might,
    Tend'ring our sister's honour and our own.
 That on mine honour here do I protest.

  SATURNINUS.

    I will not be denied.

  SATURNINUS.

    Lavinia, though you left me like a churl,
    I found a friend; and sure as death I swore  
    I would not part a bachelor from the priest.
 To-morrow, and it please your Majesty
    To hunt the panther and the hart with me,
    With horn and hound we'll give your Grace bonjour.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.

  DEMETRIUS.

  DEMETRIUS.

  DEMETRIUS.
 Youngling, learn thou to make some meaner choice:
    Lavina is thine elder brother's hope.
  [Aside]  Ay, and as good as Saturninus may.
 Then why should he despair that knows to court it
    With words, fair looks, and liberality?
    What, hast not thou full often struck a doe,
    And borne her cleanly by the keeper's nose?
  AARON.

  AARON.

    'Tis policy and stratagem must do
    That you affect; and so must you resolve
    That what you cannot as you would achieve,  
    You must perforce accomplish as you may.

    Take this of me: Lucrece was not more chaste
    Than this Lavinia, Bassianus' love.

    This way, or not at all, stand you in hope.

  CHIRON.
                           Exeunt




SCENE II.

    Uncouple here, and let us make a bay,
    And wake the Emperor and his lovely bride,
    And rouse the Prince, and ring a hunter's peal,
    That all the court may echo with the noise.

    I have been troubled in my sleep this night,
    But dawning day new comfort hath inspir'd.

  SATURNINUS.

  MARCUS.
 Chiron, we hunt not, we, with horse nor hound,
    But hope to pluck a dainty doe to ground.

    Here comes a parcel of our hopeful booty,
    Which dreads not yet their lives' destruction.
 Ah, my sweet Moor, sweeter to me than life!
  AARON.

  BASSIANUS.

    A barren detested vale you see it is:
    The trees, though summer, yet forlorn and lean,
    Overcome with moss and baleful mistletoe;
    Here never shines the sun; here nothing breeds,
    Unless the nightly owl or fatal raven.

    And then they call'd me foul adulteress,
    Lascivious Goth, and all the bitterest terms
    That ever ear did hear to such effect;
    And had you not by wondrous fortune come,
    This vengeance on me had they executed.

  DEMETRIUS.

  DEMETRIUS.
 An if she do, I would I were an eunuch.

    Come, mistress, now perforce we will enjoy
    That nice-preserved honesty of yours.
 O Tamora! thou bearest a woman's face-
  TAMORA.
 I will not hear her speak; away with her!
  LAVINIA.
 Sweet lords, entreat her hear me but a word.
  
    Yet every mother breeds not sons alike:
    [To CHIRON]  Do thou entreat her show a woman's pity.
 What, wouldst thou have me prove myself a bastard?
  LAVINIA.

    Some say that ravens foster forlorn children,
    The whilst their own birds famish in their nests;
    O, be to me, though thy hard heart say no,
    Nothing so kind, but something pitiful!
  TAMORA.
 Hadst thou in person ne'er offended me,
    Even for his sake am I pitiless.
 O Tamora, be call'd a gentle queen,
    And with thine own hands kill me in this place!
    For 'tis not life that I have begg'd so long;
    Poor I was slain when Bassianus died.

  LAVINIA.
 So should I rob my sweet sons of their fee;
    No, let them satisfy their lust on thee.
  
    This is the hole where Aaron bid us hide him.


                 DEMETRIUS throws the body
           of BASSIANUS into the pit; then exeunt
         DEMETRIUS and CHIRON, dragging off LAVINIA

  TAMORA.

    Now will I hence to seek my lovely Moor,
    And let my spleenful sons this trull deflower.
 O brother, with the dismal'st object hurt
    That ever eye with sight made heart lament!
  AARON.
  [Aside]  Now will I fetch the King to find them here,
    That he thereby may have a likely guess
    How these were they that made away his brother.
         Exit
  MARTIUS.
 I am surprised with an uncouth fear;
    A chilling sweat o'er-runs my trembling joints;
    My heart suspects more than mine eye can see.

  MARTIUS.
 Lord Bassianus lies beray'd in blood,
    All on a heap, like to a slaughtered lamb,
    In this detested, dark, blood-drinking pit.

  QUINTUS.
 The unhappy sons of old Andronicus,
    Brought hither in a most unlucky hour,
    To find thy brother Bassianus dead.

  TAMORA.

                                 [She giveth SATURNINE a letter]  
    SATURNINUS.

  AARON.
 My gracious lord, here is the bag of gold.

    Sirs, drag them from the pit unto the prison;
    There let them bide until we have devis'd
    Some never-heard-of torturing pain for them.
 High Emperor, upon my feeble knee
    I beg this boon, with tears not lightly shed,
    That this fell fault of my accursed sons-
    Accursed if the fault be prov'd in them-
  SATURNINUS.

    Who found this letter? Tamora, was it you?
  TAMORA.

  TITUS.

  TITUS.
 Write down thy mind, bewray thy meaning so,
    An if thy stumps will let thee play the scribe.
 Go home, call for sweet water, wash thy hands.
 If thou hadst hands to help thee knit the cord.

    Ah, now thou turn'st away thy face for shame!
    And notwithstanding all this loss of blood-
    As from a conduit with three issuing spouts-
    Yet do thy cheeks look red as Titan's face  
    Blushing to be encount'red with a cloud.

    Shall I speak for thee? Shall I say 'tis so?
    O, that I knew thy heart, and knew the beast,
    That I might rail at him to ease my mind!
    Sorrow concealed, like an oven stopp'd,
    Doth burn the heart to cinders where it is.
>>



ACT III.

                          [ANDRONICUS lieth down, and the judges
                     pass by him with the prisoners, and exeunt]
    For these, Tribunes, in the dust I write  
    My heart's deep languor and my soul's sad tears.

    Speak, Lavinia, what accursed hand
    Hath made thee handless in thy father's sight?
    What fool hath added water to the sea,
    Or brought a fagot to bright-burning Troy?
    My grief was at the height before thou cam'st,
    And now like Nilus it disdaineth bounds.
 O, that delightful engine of her thoughts
    That blabb'd them with such pleasing eloquence
    Is torn from forth that pretty hollow cage,  
    Where like a sweet melodious bird it sung
    Sweet varied notes, enchanting every ear!
  LUCIUS.

    But that which gives my soul the greatest spurn
    Is dear Lavinia, dearer than my soul.

    Had I but seen thy picture in this plight,
    It would have madded me; what shall I do  
    Now I behold thy lively body so?
    Thou hast no hands to wipe away thy tears,
    Nor tongue to tell me who hath martyr'd thee;
    Thy husband he is dead, and for his death
    Thy brothers are condemn'd, and dead by this.

    Look, Marcus! Ah, son Lucius, look on her!
    When I did name her brothers, then fresh tears
    Stood on her cheeks, as doth the honey dew
    Upon a gath'red lily almost withered.
 If they did kill thy husband, then be joyful,
    Because the law hath ta'en revenge on them.

    Gentle Lavinia, let me kiss thy lips,
    Or make some sign how I may do thee ease.

  TITUS.
 Ah, Marcus, Marcus! Brother, well I wot
    Thy napkin cannot drink a tear of mine,
    For thou, poor man, hast drown'd it with thine own.
 Titus Andronicus, my lord the Emperor
    Sends thee this word, that, if thou love thy sons,
    Let Marcus, Lucius, or thyself, old Titus,
    Or any one of you, chop off your hand
    And send it to the King: he for the same
    Will send thee hither both thy sons alive,
    And that shall be the ransom for their fault.
 Stay, father! for that noble hand of thine,
    That hath thrown down so many enemies,
    Shall not be sent.
 Nay, come, agree whose hand shall go along,
    For fear they die before their pardon come.

  LUCIUS.
  
  MARCUS.

  MARCUS.
 What shall be is dispatch'd.

    Good Aaron, give his Majesty my hand;
    Tell him it was a hand that warded him
    From thousand dangers; bid him bury it.

  TITUS.

    Here are the heads of thy two noble sons;
    And here's thy hand, in scorn to thee sent back-
    Thy grief their sports, thy resolution mock'd,
    That woe is me to think upon thy woes,
    More than remembrance of my father's death.

  TITUS.
 Now farewell, flatt'ry; die, Andronicus.

    Ah! now no more will I control thy griefs.

    Farewell, proud Rome; till Lucius come again,
    He leaves his pledges dearer than his life.

Rome.
 TITUS' house

A banquet.

  MARCUS.
 Fie, brother, fie! Teach her not thus to lay
    Such violent hands upon her tender life.
 How now! Has sorrow made thee dote already?
    Why, Marcus, no man should be mad but I.

    What violent hands can she lay on her life?
    Ah, wherefore dost thou urge the name of hands?
    To bid Aeneas tell the tale twice o'er
    How Troy was burnt and he made miserable?
    O, handle not the theme, to talk of hands,
    Lest we remember still that we have none.

  TITUS.

    There's for thyself, and that's for Tamora.

    Ah, sirrah!  
    Yet, I think, we are not brought so low
    But that between us we can kill a fly
    That comes in likeness of a coal-black Moor.
 Alas, poor man! grief has so wrought on him,
    He takes false shadows for true substances.

  TITUS.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.


Enter TITUS and MARCUS

  BOY.

  MARCUS.

    See, Lucius, see how much she makes of thee.
 My lord, I know not, I, nor can I guess,
    Unless some fit or frenzy do possess her;
    For I have heard my grandsire say full oft
    Extremity of griefs would make men mad;
    And I have read that Hecuba of Troy
    Ran mad for sorrow.
 Lucius, I will.
           [LAVINIA turns over with her
                     stumps the books which Lucius has let fall]
  TITUS.

  TITUS.

  MARCUS.

    Or slunk not Saturnine, as Tarquin erst,
    That left the camp to sin in Lucrece' bed?
  MARCUS.
  
    Curs'd be that heart that forc'd us to this shift!
    Write thou, good niece, and here display at last
    What God will have discovered for revenge.
 'Stuprum- Chiron- Demetrius.
 O, calm thee, gentle lord! although I know
    There is enough written upon this earth
    To stir a mutiny in the mildest thoughts,
    And arm the minds of infants to exclaims.

    My lord, kneel down with me; Lavinia, kneel;
    And kneel, sweet boy, the Roman Hector's hope;
    And swear with me- as, with the woeful fere  
    And father of that chaste dishonoured dame,
    Lord Junius Brutus sware for Lucrece' rape-
    That we will prosecute, by good advice,
    Mortal revenge upon these traitorous Goths,
    And see their blood or die with this reproach.
 The angry northern wind
    Will blow these sands like Sibyl's leaves abroad,
    And where's our lesson, then? Boy, what say you?
  BOY.

  BOY.

  TITUS.

    Lucius and I'll go brave it at the court;
    Ay, marry, will we, sir! and we'll be waited on.
  [Aside]  That you are both decipher'd, that's the news,
    For villains mark'd with rape.
 What's here? A scroll, and written round about.
'
  CHIRON.
 Ay, just- a verse in Horace.

    But let her rest in her unrest awhile-
    And now, young lords, was't not a happy star
    Led us to Rome, strangers, and more than so,
    Captives, to be advanced to this height?  
    It did me good before the palace gate
    To brave the Tribune in his brother's hearing.

  DEMETRIUS.
 But me more good to see so great a lord
    Basely insinuate and send us gifts.
 Here lacks but your mother for to say amen.

  CHIRON.
 I mean she is brought a-bed.

  DEMETRIUS.
 Villain, what hast thou done?
  AARON.
 Thou hast undone our mother.

  AARON.
 It shall not die.

  AARON.
 Sooner this sword shall plough thy bowels up.
  
                     [Takes the CHILD from the NURSE, and draws]
    Stay, murderous villains, will you kill your brother!
    Now, by the burning tapers of the sky
    That shone so brightly when this boy was got,
    He dies upon my scimitar's sharp point
    That touches this my first-born son and heir.
 I blush to think upon this ignomy.

  AARON.
'
    He is your brother, lords, sensibly fed
    Of that self-blood that first gave life to you;
    And from your womb where you imprisoned were
    He is enfranchised and come to light.

    Nay, he is your brother by the surer side,  
    Although my seal be stamped in his face.
      [He kills her]  
    Weeke weeke!
    So cries a pig prepared to the spit.

  DEMETRIUS.
 O Lord, sir, 'tis a deed of policy.
 You see I have given her physic,
                                         [Pointing to the NURSE]
    And you must needs bestow her funeral;  
    The fields are near, and you are gallant grooms.

    The midwife and the nurse well made away,
    Then let the ladies tattle what they please.

                                             Exit with the CHILD




SCENE III.
 Come, Marcus, come; kinsmen, this is the way.

    Tell him it is for justice and for aid,  
    And that it comes from old Andronicus,
    Shaken with sorrows in ungrateful Rome.

  MARCUS.
 Therefore, my lords, it highly us concerns
    By day and night t' attend him carefully,
    And feed his humour kindly as we may
    Till time beget some careful remedy.
 Publius, how now? How now, my masters?  
    What, have you met with her?
  PUBLIUS.

    Marcus, we are but shrubs, no cedars we,
    No big-bon'd men fram'd of the Cyclops' size;
    But metal, Marcus, steel to the very back,
    Yet wrung with wrongs more than our backs can bear;
    And, sith there's no justice in earth nor hell,
    We will solicit heaven, and move the gods
    To send down justice for to wreak our wrongs.
 Marcus, loose when I bid.
 Now, masters, draw.

  TITUS.
 God forbid I
    should be so bold to press to heaven in my young days.
  
  MARCUS.
 Why, sir, that is as fit as can be to serve for your
    oration; and let him deliver the pigeons to the Emperor from you.
 Sirrah, can you with a grace deliver up a
    supplication?
  CLOWN.

    But if I live, his feigned ecstasies
    Shall be no shelter to these outrages;
    But he and his shall know that justice lives
    In Saturninus' health; whom, if she sleep,
    He'll so awake as he in fury shall
    Cut off the proud'st conspirator that lives.

                                   [SATURNINUS reads the letter]
  SATURNINUS.

  CLOWN.
 Come, sirrah, you must be hang'd.

  CLOWN.
  
    May this be borne- as if his traitorous sons
    That died by law for murder of our brother
    Have by my means been butchered wrongfully?
    Go drag the villain hither by the hair;
    Nor age nor honour shall shape privilege.

    For this proud mock I'll be thy slaughterman,
    Sly frantic wretch, that holp'st to make me great,
    In hope thyself should govern Rome and me.

    [To AEMILIUS]  Go thou before to be our ambassador;
    Say that the Emperor requests a parley
    Of warlike Lucius, and appoint the meeting
    Even at his father's house, the old Andronicus.
 Your bidding shall I do effectually.
            Exit
  TAMORA.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
 Approved warriors and my faithful friends,
    I have received letters from great Rome
    Which signifies what hate they bear their Emperor
    And how desirous of our sight they are.
 O worthy Goth, this is the incarnate devil
    That robb'd Andronicus of his good hand;
    This is the pearl that pleas'd your Empress' eye;
    And here's the base fruit of her burning lust.

    Say, wall-ey'd slave, whither wouldst thou convey
    This growing image of thy fiend-like face?
    Why dost not speak? What, deaf? Not a word?
    A halter, soldiers! Hang him on this tree,
    And by his side his fruit of bastardy.
 Lucius, save the child,
    And bear it from me to the Emperess.
 Tell on thy mind; I say thy child shall live.

  LUCIUS.

  LUCIUS.

  LUCIUS.

    I pried me through the crevice of a wall,
    When, for his hand, he had his two sons' heads;
    Beheld his tears, and laugh'd so heartily
    That both mine eyes were rainy like to his;
    And when I told the Empress of this sport,
    She swooned almost at my pleasing tale,
    And for my tidings gave me twenty kisses.

  GOTH.

    Even now I curse the day- and yet, I think,
    Few come within the compass of my curse-
    Wherein I did not some notorious ill;
    As kill a man, or else devise his death;
    Ravish a maid, or plot the way to do it;
    Accuse some innocent, and forswear myself;
    Set deadly enmity between two friends;  
    Make poor men's cattle break their necks;
    Set fire on barns and hay-stacks in the night,
    And bid the owners quench them with their tears.
 Lord Lucius, and you Princes of the Goths,
    The Roman Emperor greets you all by me;
    And, for he understands you are in arms,
    He craves a parley at your father's house,
    Willing you to demand your hostages,
    And they shall be immediately deliver'd.

  FIRST GOTH.
 What says our general?
  LUCIUS.

  TITUS.
 Know thou, sad man, I am not Tamora:
    She is thy enemy and I thy friend.

    I am Revenge, sent from th' infernal kingdom
    To ease the gnawing vulture of thy mind
    By working wreakful vengeance on thy foes.

    Come down and welcome me to this world's light;  
    Confer with me of murder and of death;
    There's not a hollow cave or lurking-place,
    No vast obscurity or misty vale,
    Where bloody murder or detested rape
    Can couch for fear but I will find them out;
    And in their ears tell them my dreadful name-
    Revenge, which makes the foul offender quake.

  TITUS.

  TITUS.

    O sweet Revenge, now do I come to thee;
    And, if one arm's embracement will content thee,
    I will embrace thee in it by and by.

    Whate'er I forge to feed his brain-sick humours,
    Do you uphold and maintain in your speeches,
    For now he firmly takes me for Revenge;  
    And, being credulous in this mad thought,
    I'll make him send for Lucius his son,
    And whilst I at a banquet hold him sure,
    I'll find some cunning practice out of hand
    To scatter and disperse the giddy Goths,
    Or, at the least, make them his enemies.

    Welcome, dread Fury, to my woeful house.

  CHIRON.
 Look round about the wicked streets of Rome,
    And when thou find'st a man that's like thyself,
    Good Murder, stab him; he's a murderer.

    Go thou with him, and when it is thy hap
    To find another that is like to thee,
    Good Rapine, stab him; he is a ravisher.

    I pray thee, do on them some violent death;
    They have been violent to me and mine.
  
    But would it please thee, good Andronicus,
    To send for Lucius, thy thrice-valiant son,
    Who leads towards Rome a band of warlike Goths,
    And bid him come and banquet at thy house;
    When he is here, even at thy solemn feast,
    I will bring in the Empress and her sons,
    The Emperor himself, and all thy foes;
    And at thy mercy shall they stoop and kneel,
    And on them shalt thou ease thy angry heart.

  MARCUS.
 Now will I hence about thy business,
    And take my ministers along with me.
 Nay, nay, let Rape and Murder stay with me,
    Or else I'll call my brother back again,
    And cleave to no revenge but Lucius.
 Farewell, Andronicus, Revenge now goes  
    To lay a complot to betray thy foes.
 Tut, I have work enough for you to do.

    O villains, Chiron and Demetrius!
    Here stands the spring whom you have stain'd with mud;
    This goodly summer with your winter mix'd.

    You kill'd her husband; and for that vile fault
    Two of her brothers were condemn'd to death,
    My hand cut off and made a merry jest;
    Both her sweet hands, her tongue, and that more dear
    Than hands or tongue, her spotless chastity,
    Inhuman traitors, you constrain'd and forc'd.

                                         [He cuts their throats]
    So.

    FIRST GOTH.
 Flourish within
    The trumpets show the Emperor is at hand.
 Although the cheer be poor,
    'Twill fill your stomachs; please you eat of it.
 Because the girl should not survive her shame,
    And by her presence still renew his sorrows.
 Why, there they are, both baked in this pie,
    Whereof their mother daintily hath fed,
    Eating the flesh that she herself hath bred.
 Die, frantic wretch, for this accursed deed!
                                                [He stabs TITUS]
  LUCIUS.

    My heart is not compact of flint nor steel;
    Nor can I utter all our bitter grief,
    But floods of tears will drown my oratory
    And break my utt'rance, even in the time
    When it should move ye to attend me most,
    And force you to commiseration.

    But, soft! methinks I do digress too much,
    Citing my worthless praise.

                  [Pointing to the CHILD in an attendant's arms]  
    Of this was Tamora delivered,
    The issue of an irreligious Moor,
    Chief architect and plotter of these woes.

    Speak, Romans, speak; and if you say we shall,
    Lo, hand in hand, Lucius and I will fall.
 Go, go into old Titus' sorrowful house,
    And hither hale that misbelieving Moor
    To be adjudg'd some direful slaught'ring death,
    As punishment for his most wicked life.
 Tear for tear and loving kiss for kiss
    Thy brother Marcus tenders on thy lips.
 Set him breast-deep in earth, and famish him;
    There let him stand and rave and cry for food.
 This is our doom.

  AARON.
 Some loving friends convey the Emperor hence,
    And give him burial in his father's grave.

    As for that ravenous tiger, Tamora,  
    No funeral rite, nor man in mourning weed,
    No mournful bell shall ring her burial;
    But throw her forth to beasts and birds to prey.

    Her life was beastly and devoid of pity,
    And being dead, let birds on her take pity.
           Exeunt

THE END

1602

THE HISTORY OF TROILUS AND CRESSIDA

by William Shakespeare


DRAMATIS PERSONAE

  PRIAM, King of Troy

    His sons:
  HECTOR
  TROILUS
  PARIS
  DEIPHOBUS
  HELENUS

  MARGARELON, a bastard son of Priam

     Trojan commanders:
  AENEAS
  ANTENOR

  CALCHAS, a Trojan priest, taking part with the Greeks
  PANDARUS, uncle to Cressida
  AGAMEMNON, the Greek general
  MENELAUS, his brother
  
    Greek commanders:
  ACHILLES
  AJAX
  ULYSSES
  NESTOR
  DIOMEDES
  PATROCLUS

  THERSITES, a deformed and scurrilous Greek
  ALEXANDER, servant to Cressida
  SERVANT to Troilus
  SERVANT to Paris
  SERVANT to Diomedes

  HELEN, wife to Menelaus
  ANDROMACHE, wife to Hector
  CASSANDRA, daughter to Priam, a prophetess
  CRESSIDA, daughter to Calchas

  Trojan and Greek Soldiers, and Attendants  

                          SCENE:
             Troy and the Greek camp before it

PROLOGUE
                  TROILUS AND CRESSIDA
                        PROLOGUE

    In Troy, there lies the scene.
>>



ACT I.
 Will this gear ne'er be mended?
  TROILUS.
 The Greeks are strong, and skilful to their strength,
    Fierce to their skill, and to their fierceness valiant;
    But I am weaker than a woman's tear,
    Tamer than sleep, fonder than ignorance,
    Less valiant than the virgin in the night,
    And skilless as unpractis'd infancy.

  TROILUS.
 Have I not tarried?
  PANDARUS.
 Ay, the bolting; but you must tarry the leavening.
 Patience herself, what goddess e'er she be,
    Doth lesser blench at suff'rance than I do.

    At Priam's royal table do I sit;
    And when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts-
    So, traitor, then she comes when she is thence.

  PANDARUS.
 But, for
    my part, she is my kinswoman; I would not, as they term it,
    praise her, but I would somebody had heard her talk yesterday, as
    I did.
 I tell thee I am mad
    In Cressid's love.
 O, that her hand,
    In whose comparison all whites are ink
    Writing their own reproach; to whose soft seizure
    The cygnet's down is harsh, and spirit of sense
    Hard as the palm of ploughman! This thou tell'st me,
    As true thou tell'st me, when I say I love her;
    But, saying thus, instead of oil and balm,  
    Thou lay'st in every gash that love hath given me
    The knife that made it.
 I have had my labour for my travail, ill thought on of
    her and ill thought on of you; gone between and between, but
    small thanks for my labour.

  TROILUS.
 For my part, I'll meddle nor make no  
    more i' th' matter.
 This woman's answer sorts,
    For womanish it is to be from thence.

    What news, Aeneas, from the field to-day?
  AENEAS.
 Better at home, if 'would I might' were 'may.
 Are you bound thither?
  AENEAS.
 Come, go we then together.
 SCENE 2.
 Who were those went by?
  ALEXANDER.

  ALEXANDER.
 This man, lady, hath robb'd many beasts of their
    particular additions: he is as valiant as a lion, churlish as the
    bear, slow as the elephant-a man into whom nature hath so crowded
    humours that his valour is crush'd into folly, his folly sauced
    with discretion.

  CRESSIDA.

  ALEXANDER.
 That were we talking of, and of his anger.
 So he says here.
 And there's Troilus will not
    come far behind him; let them take heed of Troilus, I can tell
    them that too.
 Who, Troilus? Troilus is the better man of the two.
 O Jupiter! there's no comparison.

  PANDARUS.

  PANDARUS.

  PANDARUS.

  PANDARUS.

  CRESSIDA.
 He is elder.
 Pardon me, pardon me.

  CRESSIDA.
 No, but brown.

  CRESSIDA.
 Then Troilus should have too much.
 Nay, I am sure she does.

  PANDARUS.
 But to prove to you that Helen loves him: she came and
    puts me her white hand to his cloven chin-
  CRESSIDA.

  CRESSIDA.

  PANDARUS.
 I cannot choose but laugh to think how she tickled his
    chin.
 Without the rack.
 And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on his chin.
 Did her eyes run o'er too?
  PANDARUS.

  CRESSIDA.
 They laugh'd not so much at the hair as at his pretty
    answer.
 What was his answer?
  PANDARUS.
 This is her question.
 'Two and fifty
    hairs,' quoth he 'and one white.
' But there was such laughing! and
    Helen so blush'd, and Paris so chaf'd; and all the rest so  
    laugh'd that it pass'd.
 So let it now; for it has been a great while going by.
 So I do.

  CRESSIDA.


                       AENEAS passes

  CRESSIDA.
 He has a shrewd wit, I can tell you; and
    he's a man good enough; he's one o' th' soundest judgments in
    Troy, whosoever, and a proper man of person.
 When comes Troilus?
    I'll show you Troilus anon.
 If he see me, you shall see him nod
    at me.

  CRESSIDA.
 You shall see.

  CRESSIDA.
 Be those with swords?
  PANDARUS.
 Yonder
    comes Paris, yonder comes Paris.
 Who's that?
  PANDARUS.
 That's Helenus.
 That's Helenus.
 Hem! Brave Troilus, the prince of chivalry!
  CRESSIDA.
 Peace, for shame, peace!
  PANDARUS.
 O brave Troilus! Look well upon him,
    niece; look you how his sword is bloodied, and his helm more
    hack'd than Hector's; and how he looks, and how he goes! O
    admirable youth! he never saw three and twenty.

  PANDARUS.

  CRESSIDA.

  PANDARUS.
 Good boy, tell him I come.
 Fare ye well, good niece.

  CRESSIDA.
 With due observance of thy godlike seat,
    Great Agamemnon, Nestor shall apply
    Thy latest words.
 The sea being smooth,
    How many shallow bauble boats dare sail
    Upon her patient breast, making their way  
    With those of nobler bulk!
    But let the ruffian Boreas once enrage
    The gentle Thetis, and anon behold
    The strong-ribb'd bark through liquid mountains cut,
    Bounding between the two moist elements
    Like Perseus' horse.
 Great Agamemnon,
    This chaos, when degree is suffocate,
    Follows the choking.
 To end a tale of length,
    Troy in our weakness stands, not in her strength.
 At this fusty stuff
    The large Achilles, on his press'd bed lolling,
    From his deep chest laughs out a loud applause;
    Cries 'Excellent! 'tis Agamemnon just.
 And at this sport  
    Sir Valour dies; cries 'O, enough, Patroclus;
    Or give me ribs of steel! I shall split all
    In pleasure of my spleen.

  NESTOR.
 From Troy.
 Even this.
 How?
  AENEAS.

  AGAMEMNON.
 Ay, Greek, that is my name.

  AGAMEMNON.
 What's your affair, I pray you?
  AENEAS.
 He hears nought privately that comes from Troy.

  AENEAS.
 Trumpet, blow loud,
    Send thy brass voice through all these lazy tents;
    And every Greek of mettle, let him know
    What Troy means fairly shall be spoke aloud.

  AGAMEMNON.

    If none of them have soul in such a kind,
    We left them all at home.
  
    If then one is, or hath, or means to be,
    That one meets Hector; if none else, I am he.
 His youth in flood,
    I'll prove this truth with my three drops of blood.

  AENEAS.

    Achilles shall have word of this intent;
    So shall each lord of Greece, from tent to tent.

  NESTOR.

  NESTOR.

  ULYSSES.
 And wake him to the answer, think you?
  NESTOR.
 Why, 'tis most meet.
 Do not consent
    That ever Hector and Achilles meet;
    For both our honour and our shame in this
    Are dogg'd with two strange followers.

  NESTOR.
 No, make a lott'ry;
    And, by device, let blockish Ajax draw
    The sort to fight with Hector.
          Exeunt




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
>>



ACT II.
 Thersites!
  THERSITES.
 Agamemnon-how if he had boils full, an over, generally?
  AJAX.
 Thersites!
  THERSITES.
 Did not the general run
    then? Were not that a botchy core?
  AJAX.
 Dog!
  THERSITES.
 The plague of Greece upon thee, thou mongrel beef-witted
    lord!
  AJAX.
 I will beat thee
    into handsomeness.
 Toadstool, learn me the proclamation.

  THERSITES.
 When thou art forth in the incursions, thou strikest as
    slow as another.
 Thou shouldst strike him.
 Cobloaf!
  THERSITES.
 You whoreson cur!                               [Strikes him]  
  THERSITES.
 If thou use to beat me, I will begin at thy heel and tell
    what thou art by inches, thou thing of no bowels, thou!
  AJAX.
 Mars his idiot! Do, rudeness; do, camel; do, do.
 You see him there, do you?
  ACHILLES.
 Ay; what's the matter?
  THERSITES.

  THERSITES.
 Ay, but that fool knows not himself.

  THERSITES.

  ACHILLES.

  ACHILLES.
 I bade the vile owl go learn me the tenour of the
    proclamation, and he rails upon me.
 I serve thee not.
 E'en so; a great deal of your wit too lies in your
    sinews, or else there be liars.

  ACHILLES.
 To Achilles, to Ajax, to-
  AJAX.
 I will hold my peace when Achilles' brach bids me, shall
    I?
  ACHILLES.
 Marry, this, sir, is proclaim'd through all our host,
    That Hector, by the fifth hour of the sun,  
    Will with a trumpet 'twixt our tents and Troy,
    To-morrow morning, call some knight to arms
    That hath a stomach; and such a one that dare
    Maintain I know not what; 'tis trash.
 Farewell.
 I know not; 'tis put to lott'ry.

  AJAX.
 O, meaning you! I will go learn more of it.
            Exeunt




ACT II.
 SCENE 2.

Troy.
' Hector, what say you to't?
  HECTOR.
 The wound of peace is surety,
    Surety secure; but modest doubt is call'd
    The beacon of the wise, the tent that searches
    To th' bottom of the worst.
 I take to-day a wife, and my election
    Is led on in the conduct of my will;
    My will enkindled by mine eyes and ears,
    Two traded pilots 'twixt the dangerous shores
    Of will and judgment: how may I avoid,
    Although my will distaste what it elected,
    The wife I chose? There can be no evasion
    To blench from this and to stand firm by honour.
 What noise, what shriek is this?
  TROILUS.

  CASSANDRA.
 [Within] Cry, Troyans.


                  Enter CASSANDRA, raving

  CASSANDRA.
 Lend me ten thousand eyes,
    And I will fill them with prophetic tears.

    Troy must not be, nor goodly Ilion stand;
    Our firebrand brother, Paris, burns us all.
                  Exit
  HECTOR.
 Paris, you speak
    Like one besotted on your sweet delights.

    You have the honey still, but these the gall;
    So to be valiant is no praise at all.
 Yet, ne'er the less,  
    My spritely brethren, I propend to you
    In resolution to keep Helen still;
    For 'tis a cause that hath no mean dependence
    Upon our joint and several dignities.
 Why, there you touch'd the life of our design.
 I am yours,
    You valiant offspring of great Priamus.
                            Exeunt




ACT II.

The Grecian camp.
 Before the tent of ACHILLES

Enter THERSITES, solus

  THERSITES.
 How now, Thersites! What, lost in the labyrinth of thy
    fury? Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He beats me, and I
    rail at him.
 Then there's Achilles, a rare engineer! If Troy be
    not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till
    they fall of themselves.
 O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus,
    forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods, and, Mercury, lose
    all the serpentine craft of thy caduceus, if ye take not that
    little little less-than-little wit from them that they have!
    which short-arm'd ignorance itself knows is so abundant scarce,
    it will not in circumvention deliver a fly from a spider without
    drawing their massy irons and cutting the web.
 After this, the
    vengeance on the whole camp! or, rather, the Neapolitan
    bone-ache! for that, methinks, is the curse depending on those
    that war for a placket.
' What ho! my Lord Achilles!

                      Enter PATROCLUS

  PATROCLUS.
 If I could 'a rememb'red a gilt counterfeit, thou
    wouldst not have slipp'd out of my contemplation; but it is no
    matter; thyself upon thyself! The common curse of mankind, folly
    and ignorance, be thine in great revenue! Heaven bless thee from
    a tutor, and discipline come not near thee! Let thy blood be thy
    direction till thy death.

  ACHILLES.
 Then tell me, Patroclus, what art
    thou?
  PATROCLUS.
 Agamemnon commands
    Achilles; Achilles is my lord; I am Patroclus' knower; and
    Patroclus is a fool.
 Derive this; come.
 Look you, who comes here?
  ACHILLES.
 Within his tent; but ill-dispos'd, my lord.
 Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart.
 But why, why? Let him show us a cause.

                                              [Takes AGAMEMNON aside]
  NESTOR.
 All the better; their fraction is more our wish than their
    faction.
 Hear you, Patroclus.
 Yet all his virtues,
    Not virtuously on his own part beheld,
