    Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss;
    Yea, like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish,
    Are like to rot untasted.
 Tell him so.
 I shall, and bring his answer presently.
 No, noble Ajax; you are as strong, as valiant, as wise,
    no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether more tractable.

  AGAMEMNON.

  AGAMEMNON.
 Let Ajax go to him.

    Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent.
 [Aside] And how his silence drinks up this applause!
  AJAX.

  AGAMEMNON.
 Can he not be sociable?
  ULYSSES.
 [Aside] He will be the physician that should be the  
    patient.

  NESTOR.
 [To AGAMEMNON] My lord, you feed too much on this dislike.

  DIOMEDES.
 You must prepare to fight without Achilles.
 Wherefore should you so?
    He is not emulous, as Achilles is.
 What a vice were it in Ajax now-
  ULYSSES.
 Or covetous of praise.
 Or strange, or self-affected.

  DIOMEDES.

  ULYSSES.
 Let Achilles sleep.

    Exeunt




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
 Enter PANDARUS and a SERVANT

  PANDARUS.

  PANDARUS.
 Sir, I do depend upon the lord.
 Faith, sir, superficially.
 Wholly, sir.
 To the hearers, sir.

  PANDARUS.
 I come to speak with Paris from the Prince Troilus; I
    will make a complimental assault upon him, for my business
    seethes.
 Dear lord, you are full of fair words.
 You have broke it, cousin; and by my life, you shall make it
    whole again; you shall piece it out with a piece of your
    performance.
 Truly, lady, no.

  PARIS.
 We'll hear you sing,
    certainly-
  PANDARUS.
 Go to, sweet queen, go to-commends himself most
    affectionately to you-
  HELEN.

  PANDARUS.
 My Lord Pandarus!
  PANDARUS.

  PARIS.
 I'll lay my life, with my disposer Cressida.

  PARIS.

  HELEN.

  PANDARUS.

  PANDARUS.
 Love! Ay, that it shall, i' faith.
 Ay, good now, love, love, nothing but love.

    These lovers cry, O ho, they die!
       Yet that which seems the wound to kill
    Doth turn O ho! to ha! ha! he!
       So dying love lives still.
 He eats nothing but doves, love; and that breeds hot blood,
    and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot thoughts beget hot
    deeds, and hot deeds is love.
 How chance my brother Troilus went not?
  HELEN.
 I long to hear how they spend
    to-day.
 Farewell, sweet queen.
 No, Pandarus.
 I am giddy; expectation whirls me round.
 She does so blush, and fetches her wind so short, as
    if she were fray'd with a sprite.
-
    What, are you gone again? You must be watch'd ere you be made
    tame, must you? Come your ways, come your ways; an you draw
    backward, we'll put you i' th' fills.

    What, billing again? Here's 'In witness whereof the parties
    interchangeably.

      Exit
  CRESSIDA.
 More dregs than water, if my fears have eyes.

  TROILUS.
 Nor nothing monstrous neither?
  TROILUS.
 This is the monstruosity in love, lady, that
    the will is infinite, and the execution confin'd; that the desire
    is boundless, and the act a slave to limit.
 They say all lovers swear more performance than they are
    able, and yet reserve an ability that they never perform; vowing
    more than the perfection of ten, and discharging less than the
    tenth part of one.
 Are there such? Such are not we.
 We will not name desert before his birth; and, being
    born, his addition shall be humble.
 I thank you for that; if my lord get a boy of you, you'll
    give him me.
 You know now your hostages: your uncle's word and my firm
    faith.

  CRESSIDA.

    Prince Troilus, I have lov'd you night and day
    For many weary months.
 Why was my Cressid then so hard to win?
  CRESSIDA.

  CRESSIDA.
 My lord, I do beseech you, pardon me;
    'Twas not my purpose thus to beg a kiss.

  TROILUS.

  CRESSIDA.

    Where is my wit? I know not what I speak.

  TROILUS.
 If ever you
    prove false one to another, since I have taken such pains to
    bring you together, let all pitiful goers- between be call'd to
    the world's end after my name-call them all Pandars; let all
    constant men be Troiluses, all false women Cressids, and all
    brokers between Pandars.
 Say 'Amen.
 Amen.
 Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, DIOMEDES, NESTOR, AJAX, MENELAUS,
and CALCHAS

  CALCHAS.
 Let Diomedes bear him,
    And bring us Cressid hither.
 This shall I undertake; and 'tis a burden
    Which I am proud to bear.
 'Tis like he'll question me
    Why such unplausive eyes are bent, why turn'd on him?
    If so, I have derision med'cinable
    To use between your strangeness and his pride,
    Which his own will shall have desire to drink.
 Pride hath no other glass
    To show itself but pride; for supple knees
    Feed arrogance and are the proud man's fees.
 I will lead the way.

  ACHILLES.

  AGAMEMNON.
 The better.

                                          Exeunt AGAMEMNON and NESTOR
  ACHILLES.

  MENELAUS.

  ACHILLES.
 I do believe it; for they pass'd by me
    As misers do by beggars-neither gave to me
    Good word nor look.
 The welcome ever smiles,
    And farewell goes out sighing.

    All the commerce that you have had with Troy
    As perfectly is ours as yours, my lord;
    And better would it fit Achilles much
    To throw down Hector than Polyxena.
          Exit
  PATROCLUS.

    Sweet, rouse yourself; and the weak wanton Cupid
    Shall from your neck unloose his amorous fold,  
    And, like a dew-drop from the lion's mane,
    Be shook to airy air.
 Shall Ajax fight with Hector?
  PATROCLUS.

  ACHILLES.

    I'll send the fool to Ajax, and desire him
    T' invite the Troyan lords, after the combat,
    To see us here unarm'd.
 He knows not me.
 Who, I? Why, he'll answer nobody; he professes not
    answering.
 Speaking is for beggars: he wears his tongue in's
    arms.

  PATROCLUS.
 I come from the worthy Achilles-
  THERSITES.
 And to procure safe conduct from Agamemnon.

  PATROCLUS.

  THERSITES.
 Your answer, sir.

  THERSITES.

  ACHILLES.
  
  THERSITES.
 Let me carry another to his horse; for that's the more
    capable creature.
 SCENE 1.
 A street

Enter, at one side, AENEAS, and servant with a torch; at another,
PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES the Grecian, and others, with torches

  PARIS.
 Is the Prince there in person?
    Had I so good occasion to lie long
    As you, Prince Paris, nothing but heavenly business
    Should rob my bed-mate of my company.
 A valiant Greek, Aeneas -take his hand:
    Witness the process of your speech, wherein
    You told how Diomed, a whole week by days,
    Did haunt you in the field.

    Our bloods are now in calm; and so long health!
    But when contention and occasion meet,
    By Jove, I'll play the hunter for thy life
    With all my force, pursuit, and policy.
 Jove let Aeneas live,
    If to my sword his fate be not the glory,
    A thousand complete courses of the sun!
    But in mine emulous honour let him die
    With every joint a wound, and that to-morrow!
  AENEAS.

    Let's have your company; or, if you please,
    Haste there before us.
 That I assure you:
    Troilus had rather Troy were borne to Greece
    Than Cressid borne from Troy.
 There is no help;
    The bitter disposition of the time
    Will have it so.

  AENEAS.

  DIOMEDES.
 Hear me, Paris:
    For every false drop in her bawdy veins
    A Grecian's life hath sunk; for every scruple  
    Of her contaminated carrion weight
    A Troyan hath been slain; since she could speak,
    She hath not given so many good words breath
    As for her Greeks and Troyans suff'red death.

Troy.
 Are you aweary of me?
  TROILUS.
 O Cressida! but that the busy day,
    Wak'd by the lark, hath rous'd the ribald crows,
    And dreaming night will hide our joys no longer,
    I would not from thee.
 Prithee tarry.

    You men will never tarry.

    O foolish Cressid! I might have still held off,
    And then you would have tarried.

    My lord, come you again into my chamber.

    You smile and mock me, as if I meant naughtily.

  TROILUS.

                                          Exeunt TROILUS and CRESSIDA
  PANDARUS.
 Good morrow, lord, good morrow.
 Who!-nay, then.
 Come, come, you'll do him wrong ere you are
    ware; you'll be so true to him to be false to him.
 Do not you
    know of him, but yet go fetch him hither; go.
 Is it so concluded?
  AENEAS.
 Good, good, my lord, the secrets of neighbour Pandar
    Have not more gift in taciturnity.
 Is't possible? No sooner got but lost? The devil take
    Antenor! The young prince will go mad.


                     Re-enter CRESSIDA

  CRESSIDA.

  CRESSIDA.
 I have forgot my father;
    I know no touch of consanguinity,
    No kin, no love, no blood, no soul so near me
    As the sweet Troilus.
' I will not go from Troy.

    Exeunt




ACT IV.
 A street before PANDARUS' house

Enter PARIS, TROILUS, AENEAS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, and DIOMEDES

  PARIS.
 I know what 'tis to love,
    And would, as I shall pity, I could help!
    Please you walk in, my lords.
 Be moderate, be moderate.
 Why tell you me of moderation?
    The grief is fine, full, perfect, that I taste,
    And violenteth in a sense as strong
    As that which causeth it.
 Ah, sweet ducks!
  CRESSIDA.
 And is it true that I must go from Troy?
  TROILUS.

  CRESSIDA.
 What, and from Troilus too?
  TROILUS.
 From Troy and Troilus.
 And suddenly; where injury of chance  
    Puts back leave-taking, justles roughly by
    All time of pause, rudely beguiles our lips
    Of all rejoindure, forcibly prevents
    Our lock'd embrasures, strangles our dear vows
    Even in the birth of our own labouring breath.

    As many farewells as be stars in heaven,
    With distinct breath and consign'd kisses to them,
    He fumbles up into a loose adieu,
    And scants us with a single famish'd kiss,
    Distasted with the salt of broken tears.

    Bid them have patience; she shall come anon.

    I speak not 'Be thou true' as fearing thee,
    For I will throw my glove to Death himself
    That there's no maculation in thy heart;
    But 'Be thou true' say I to fashion in
    My sequent protestation: be thou true,
    And I will see thee.
 Hear why I speak it, love.
 Who, I? Alas, it is my vice, my fault!
    Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion,
    I with great truth catch mere simplicity;
    Whilst some with cunning gild their copper crowns,
    With truth and plainness I do wear mine bare.

  DIOMEDES.
 Grecian, thou dost not use me courteously
    To shame the zeal of my petition to the
    In praising her.

    Let me be privileg'd by my place and message
    To be a speaker free: when I am hence
    I'll answer to my lust.

    Lady, give me your hand; and, as we walk,
    To our own selves bend we our needful talk.
 Hark! Hector's trumpet.
 How have we spent this morning!  
    The Prince must think me tardy and remiss,
    That swore to ride before him to the field.
 Come, come to field with him.

  AENEAS.

The Grecian camp.
 Lists set out

Enter AJAX, armed; AGAMEMNON, ACHILLES, PATROCLUS, MENELAUS, ULYSSES,
NESTOR, and others

  AGAMEMNON.
 Even she.

  NESTOR.

    Achilles bids you welcome.

  MENELAUS.
 Paris and I kiss evermore for him.
 I'll have my kiss, sir.

  CRESSIDA.
 In kissing, do you render or receive?
  PATROCLUS.
 I'll make my match to live,
    The kiss you take is better than you give;
    Therefore no kiss.
 No, I'll be sworn.
 Lady, a word.

    O these encounters so glib of tongue
    That give a coasting welcome ere it comes,
    And wide unclasp the tables of their thoughts
    To every ticklish reader! Set them down
    For sluttish spoils of opportunity,  
    And daughters of the game.
 If not Achilles, nothing.
 Here is Sir Diomed.

  AGAMEMNON.

    They call him Troilus, and on him erect
    A second hope as fairly built as Hector.
 Now, Ajax, hold thine own!
  TROILUS.
 Hector, thou sleep'st;
    Awake thee.

  AGAMEMNON.

    Thou art, great lord, my father's sister's son,
    A cousin-german to great Priam's seed;
    The obligation of our blood forbids
    A gory emulation 'twixt us twain:
    Were thy commixtion Greek and Troyan so
    That thou could'st say 'This hand is Grecian all,  
    And this is Troyan; the sinews of this leg
    All Greek, and this all Troy; my mother's blood
    Runs on the dexter cheek, and this sinister
    Bounds in my father's'; by Jove multipotent,
    Thou shouldst not bear from me a Greekish member
    Wherein my sword had not impressure made
    Of our rank feud; but the just gods gainsay
    That any drop thou borrow'dst from thy mother,
    My sacred aunt, should by my mortal sword
    Be drained! Let me embrace thee, Ajax.

    Cousin, all honour to thee!
  AJAX.

    I came to kill thee, cousin, and bear hence
    A great addition earned in thy death.
 There is expectance here from both the sides
    What further you will do.
 'Tis Agamemnon's wish; and great Achilles
    Doth long to see unarm'd the valiant Hector.
 Aeneas, call my brother Troilus to me,
    And signify this loving interview
    To the expecters of our Troyan part;
    Desire them home.


        AGAMEMNON and the rest of the Greeks come forward

  AJAX.
Worthy all arms! as welcome as to one
    That would be rid of such an enemy.
 I thank thee, most imperious Agamemnon.

  HECTOR.

  HECTOR.

  MENELAUS.
 O, pardon; I offend.

  NESTOR.
 'Tis the old Nestor.

  HECTOR.
 I would they could.
 I know your favour, Lord Ulysses, well.

  ULYSSES.

    There they stand yet; and modestly I think
    The fall of every Phrygian stone will cost
    A drop of Grecian blood.
 The end crowns all;
    And that old common arbitrator, Time,
    Will one day end it.

  ACHILLES.

  HECTOR.

  HECTOR.
 Stand again.
 Henceforth guard thee well;
    For I'll not kill thee there, nor there, nor there;  
    But, by the forge that stithied Mars his helm,
    I'll kill thee everywhere, yea, o'er and o'er.

    You wisest Grecians, pardon me this brag.
 I pray you let us see you in the field;
    We have had pelting wars since you refus'd
    The Grecians' cause.

  AGAMEMNON.
 First, all you peers of Greece, go to my tent;  
    There in the full convive we; afterwards,
    As Hector's leisure and your bounties shall
    Concur together, severally entreat him.
 You shall command me, sir.
 Will you walk on, my lord?
    She was belov'd, she lov'd; she is, and doth;
    But still sweet love is food for fortune's tooth.
 SCENE 1.
 Why, thou picture of what thou seemest, and idol of
    idiot worshippers, here's a letter for thee.
 Why, his masculine whore.

  THERSITES.

    Away, Patroclus!                              Exit with PATROCLUS
  THERSITES.
 Here's Agamemnon, an honest fellow
    enough, and one that loves quails, but he has not so much brain
    as ear-wax; and the goodly transformation of Jupiter there, his
    brother, the bull, the primitive statue and oblique memorial of
    cuckolds, a thrifty shoeing-horn in a chain, hanging at his
    brother's leg-to what form but that he is, should wit larded with
    malice, and malice forced with wit, turn him to? To an ass, were  
    nothing: he is both ass and ox.
 Hey-day!
    sprites and fires!

         Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES,
            NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights

  AGAMEMNON.

  HECTOR.
  
  ACHILLES.
 Welcome, brave Hector; welcome, Princes all.
 Sweet draught! 'Sweet' quoth 'a?
    Sweet sink, sweet sewer!
  ACHILLES.

  AGAMEMNON.

                                             Exeunt all but THERSITES
  THERSITES.
 I'll after.

    Nothing but lechery! All incontinent varlets!                Exit




ACT V.
 SCENE 2.

The Grecian camp.
 Before CALCHAS' tent

Enter DIOMEDES

  DIOMEDES.
 Calchas, I think.
 Stand where the torch may not discover us.

  DIOMEDES.

  THERSITES.

  THERSITES.
 Roguery!
  DIOMEDES.
 What did you swear you would bestow on me?
  CRESSIDA.

  DIOMEDES.
 And so, good night.

  TROILUS.
 In faith, I will, lo; never trust me else.
                                  Exit
  ULYSSES.
 Here, Diomed, keep this sleeve.
 O beauty! where is thy faith?
  ULYSSES.

  DIOMEDES.

  CRESSIDA.
 Ay, that.

  CRESSIDA.
 Nay, do not snatch it from me;
    He that takes that doth take my heart withal.

  DIOMEDES.
 Whose was it?
  CRESSIDA.
 Well, well, 'tis done, 'tis past; and yet it is not;
    I will not keep my word.

  DIOMEDES.

  THERSITES.
 What, shall I come? The hour-
  CRESSIDA.

  CRESSIDA.

  ULYSSES.
 Cressid was here but now.

  TROILUS.

  THERSITES.
 This she? No; this is Diomed's Cressida.
 O madness of discourse,
    That cause sets up with and against itself!
    Bifold authority! where reason can revolt
    Without perdition, and loss assume all reason
    Without revolt: this is, and is not, Cressid.
 Ay, Greek; and that shall be divulged well
    In characters as red as Mars his heart
    Inflam'd with Venus.
 Not the dreadful spout
    Which shipmen do the hurricano call,
    Constring'd in mass by the almighty sun,
    Shall dizzy with more clamour Neptune's ear
    In his descent than shall my prompted sword
    Falling on Diomed.

  TROILUS.
 O Cressid! O false Cressid! false, false, false!
    Let all untruths stand by thy stained name,
    And they'll seem glorious.


                       Enter AENEAS

  AENEAS.
  
    Hector, by this, is arming him in Troy;
    Ajax, your guard, stays to conduct you home.

  TROILUS.
 Patroclus will give me
    anything for the intelligence of this whore; the parrot will not
    do more for an almond than he for a commodious drab.

  ANDROMACHE.
 Here, sister, arm'd, and bloody in intent.

  CASSANDRA.

    Mine honour keeps the weather of my fate.

    Life every man holds dear; but the dear man
    Holds honour far more precious dear than life.
 Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you
    Which better fits a lion than a man.
 Troilus, I would not have you fight to-day.

  TROILUS.
 Come, Hector, come, go back.

  PRIAM.
 I must not break my faith.

                                                      Exit ANDROMACHE
  TROILUS.
 Look how thy eye turns pale.
                  Exit
  HECTOR.
 Farewell.
 The gods with safety stand about thee!  
                           Exeunt severally PRIAM and HECTOR.
 They are at it, hark! Proud Diomed, believe,
    I come to lose my arm or win my sleeve.

  PANDARUS.
 A whoreson tisick, a whoreson rascally tisick so troubles
    me, and the foolish fortune of this girl, and what one thing,
    what another, that I shall leave you one o' th's days; and I have
    a rheum in mine eyes too, and such an ache in my bones that
    unless a man were curs'd I cannot tell what to think on't.
 Now they are clapper-clawing one another; I'll go look
    on.

  TROILUS.
 Yet, in a sort, lechery eats itself.
                                        Exit

                       Enter AGAMEMNON

  AGAMEMNON.
 Go, bear Patroclus' body to Achilles,
    And bid the snail-pac'd Ajax arm for shame.

  
                       Enter ULYSSES

  ULYSSES.
 O, courage, courage, courage, Princes! Great
    Achilles Is arming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengeance.
 Ay, there, there.
 So, so, we draw together.
 What wouldst thou?
  DIOMEDES.
 Troilus, I say! What, Troilus!

                      Enter TROILUS

  TROILUS.
 Yea, Troilus? O, well fought, my youngest brother!

                     Enter ACHILLES

  ACHILLES.

  ACHILLES.
 Fare thee well.

    I would have been much more a fresher man,
    Had I expected thee.
 Shall it be?
    No, by the flame of yonder glorious heaven,
    He shall not carry him; I'll be ta'en too,
    Or bring him off.
 Stand, stand, thou Greek; thou art a goodly mark.
 The cuckold and the cuckold-maker are at it.
 Turn, slave, and fight.

      Exit
  MARGARELON.
 SCENE 8.
  
    On, Myrmidons, and cry you an amain
    'Achilles hath the mighty Hector slain.
 Enter AGAMEMNON, AJAX, MENELAUS, NESTOR, DIOMEDES,
and the rest, marching

  AGAMEMNON.

    If in his death the gods have us befriended;
    Great Troy is ours, and our sharp wars are ended.

Another part of the plain

Enter AENEAS, PARIS, ANTENOR, and DEIPHOBUS

  AENEAS.
 Stand, ho! yet are we masters of the field.

    Never go home; here starve we out the night.

    Frown on, you heavens, effect your rage with speed.
 Hector is gone.

    Who shall tell Priam so, or Hecuba?
    Let him that will a screech-owl aye be call'd
    Go in to Troy, and say there 'Hector's dead.

    Stay yet.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

    That strain again! It had a dying fall;
    O, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound
    That breathes upon a bank of violets,
    Stealing and giving odour! Enough, no more;
    'Tis not so sweet now as it was before.

  DUKE.
 O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame
    To pay this debt of love but to a brother,
    How will she love when the rich golden shaft
    Hath kill'd the flock of all affections else
    That live in her; when liver, brain, and heart,
    These sovereign thrones, are all supplied and fill'd,
    Her sweet perfections, with one self king!
    Away before me to sweet beds of flow'rs:
    Love-thoughts lie rich when canopied with bow'rs.
 This is Illyria, lady.

  VIOLA.
 And what should I do in Illyria?
    My brother he is in Elysium.

  VIOLA.

  CAPTAIN.

    Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,
    Whereto thy speech serves for authority,
    The like of him.
 Know'st thou this country?
  CAPTAIN.
 Ay, madam, well; for I was bred and born
    Not three hours' travel from this very place.
 Orsino! I have heard my father name him.

  VIOLA.

    I prithee, and I'll pay thee bounteously,
    Conceal me what I am, and be my aid
    For such disguise as haply shall become
    The form of my intent.

    What else may hap to time I will commit;
    Only shape thou silence to my wit.
 What a plague means my niece to take the death of her
    brother thus? I am sure care's an enemy to life.
 By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights;
    your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.

  SIR TOBY.
 That quaffing and drinking will undo you; I heard my lady
    talk of it yesterday, and of a foolish knight that you brought in
    one night here to be her wooer.

  MARIA.
 He hath indeed, almost natural; for, besides that he's a
    fool, he's a great quarreller; and but that he hath the gift of a
    coward to allay the gust he hath in quarrelling, 'tis thought
    among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.
 Sir Toby Belch! How now, Sir Toby Belch!
  SIR TOBY.
 Sweet Sir Andrew!
  AGUECHEEK.
 Bless you, fair shrew.
 And you too, sir.

  SIR TOBY.
 An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never
    draw sword again!
  AGUECHEEK.
 Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?  
  MARIA.
 Sir, I have not you by th' hand.

  AGUECHEEK.
 Wherefore, sweetheart? What's your metaphor?
  MARIA.

  AGUECHEEK.
 What is 'pourquoi'- do or not do? I would I had bestowed
    that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing, and
    bear-baiting.
 Faith, I'll home to-morrow, Sir Toby.
 Your niece will
    not be seen, or if she be, it's four to one she'll none of me;
    the Count himself here hard by woos her.
 I am a fellow o' th' strangest
    mind i' th' world; I delight in masques and revels sometimes
    altogether.
  
  SIR TOBY.
 What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?
  AGUECHEEK.
 Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have these
    gifts a curtain before 'em? Are they like to take dust, like
    Mistress Mall's picture? Why dost thou not go to church in a
    galliard and come home in a coranto? My very walk should be a
    jig; I would not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace.
 What
    dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in? I did think, by
    the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was form'd under the
    star of a galliard.
 Shall we set about some revels?
  SIR TOBY.
 Taurus? That's sides and heart.

  VIOLA.
 You either fear his humour or my negligence, that you call
    in question the continuance of his love.

  DUKE.
 Be clamorous and leap all civil bounds,
    Rather than make unprofited return.
 Prosper well in this,
    And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord
    To call his fortunes thine.





SCENE V.
 He shall see none to fear.

  MARIA.

  CLOWN.
 Apt, in good faith, very apt! Well, go thy way; if Sir Toby
    would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece of Eve's flesh
    as any in Illyria.
                      Exit

                     Enter OLIVIA and MALVOLIO

  CLOWN.
' God bless
    thee, lady!
  OLIVIA.
  
  OLIVIA.
 Go to, y'are a dry fool; I'll no more of you.
 Besides, you
    grow dishonest.
 Anything
    that's mended is but patch'd; virtue that transgresses is but
    patch'd with sin, and sin that amends is but patch'd with virtue.
 The lady bade take away the fool; therefore, I
    say again, take her away.
 Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, 'Cucullus non facit
    monachum'; that's as much to say as I wear not motley in my
    brain.
 I must catechize you for it, madonna.

  CLOWN.
 Look you now, he's out of
    his guard already; unless you laugh and minister occasion to him,  
    he is gagg'd.

  CLOWN.
 Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speak'st well
    of fools!

                             Re-enter MARIA

  MARIA.

  OLIVIA.
  
    Fie on him! [Exit MARIA] Go you, Malvolio: if it be a suit from
    the Count, I am sick, or not at home- what you will to dismiss
    it.
 [Exit MALVOLIO] Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old,
    and people dislike it.
 A gentleman! What gentleman?
  SIR TOBY.
 Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this
    lethargy?
  SIR TOBY.

  OLIVIA.
 Well, it's all one.
 What's a drunken man like, fool?
  CLOWN.
 Like a drown'd man, a fool, and a madman: one draught above
    heat makes him a fool; the second mads him; and a third drowns
    him.
 Go thou and seek the crowner, and let him sit o' my coz;
    for he's in the third degree of drink, he's drown'd; go look
    after him.
 What is to be said to him,
    lady? He's fortified against any denial.
 Has been told so; and he says he'll stand at your door
    like a sheriff's post, and be the supporter to a bench, but he'll
    speak with you.
 What kind o' man is he?
  MALVOLIO.
 Of what personage and years is he?
  MALVOLIO.

  OLIVIA.
 Let him approach.
 Your will?
  VIOLA.
 I can say little more than I have studied, and that
    question's out of my part.
 Good gentle one, give me modest
    assurance if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in
    my speech.
 If I do not usurp myself, I am.
 Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself; for
    what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve.
 Alas, I took great pains to study it, and 'tis poetical.
 It is the more like to be feigned; I pray you keep it in.

  VIOLA.
 I bring no overture of war, no  
    taxation of homage: I hold the olive in my hand; my words are as
    full of peace as matter.
 Yet you began rudely.
 The rudeness that hath appear'd in me have I learn'd from my
    entertainment.

  OLIVIA.
 Give us the place alone; we will hear this divinity.
 In Orsino's bosom.

  OLIVIA.
 Excellently done, if God did all.

    Lady, you are the cruell'st she alive,
    If you will lead these graces to the grave,
    And leave the world no copy.
 I see you what you are: you are too proud;
    But, if you were the devil, you are fair.
 With adorations, fertile tears,
    With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.
  
  OLIVIA.

    He might have took his answer long ago.
 Why, what would you?
  VIOLA.
 Make me a willow cabin at your gate,
    And call upon my soul within the house;
    Write loyal cantons of contemned love
    And sing them loud even in the dead of night;
    Halloo your name to the reverberate hals,
    And make the babbling gossip of the air
    Cry out 'Olivia!' O, you should not rest
    Between the elements of air and earth  
    But you should pity me!
  OLIVIA.
 Get you to your lord.

    I cannot love him; let him send no more-
    Unless perchance you come to me again
    To tell me how he takes it.

    I thank you for your pains; spend this for me.

  VIOLA.

    What ho, Malvolio!

                        Re-enter MALVOLIO

  MALVOLIO.

    If that the youth will come this way to-morrow,
    I'll give him reasons for't.

The sea-coast

Enter ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN

  ANTONIO.

  ANTONIO.

  SEBASTIAN.
 But I perceive in you so excellent a touch of
    modesty that you will not extort from me what I am willing to
    keep in; therefore it charges me in manners the rather to express
    myself.
 He left behind him
    myself and a sister, both born in an hour; if the heavens had
    been pleas'd, would we had so ended! But you, sir, alter'd that;
    for some hour before you took me from the breach of the sea was  
    my sister drown'd.

  ANTONIO.
 She is drown'd already, sir, with salt water, though I seem
    to drown her remembrance again with more.

 Exit
  ANTONIO.
 And one thing more: that you be never so hardy to
    come again in his affairs, unless it be to report your lord's
    taking of this.

 Exit
  VIOLA.

    How easy is it for the proper-false
    In women's waxen hearts to set their forms!
    Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we!
    For such as we are made of, such we be.

    What will become of this? As I am man,
    My state is desperate for my master's love;
    As I am woman- now alas the day!-
    What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!  
    O Time, thou must untangle this, not I;
    It is too hard a knot for me t' untie!                  Exit




SCENE III.
 Faith, so they say; but I think it rather consists of
    eating and drinking.
 Th'art a scholar; let us therefore eat and drink.
 Now let's have a catch.
 By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast.
 I sent thee sixpence for thy leman; hadst it?
  CLOWN.
 There's a testril of me too; if one knight give a-
CLOWN.
 Would you have a love-song, or a song of good life?
  SIR TOBY.
 A love-song, a love-song.

           Trip no further, pretty sweeting;
           Journeys end in lovers meeting,
           Every wise man's son doth know.
 Excellent good, i' faith!
  SIR TOBY.
 A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.

  AGUECHEEK.
 Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.
 To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion.
 My lady's a Cataian, we are politicians, Malvolio's a
    Peg-a-Ramsey, and                                    [Sings]
                  Three merry men be we.
 My masters, are you mad? Or what are you? Have you no
    wit, manners, nor honesty, but to gabble like tinkers at this
    time of night? Do ye make an ale-house of my lady's house, that
    ye squeak out your coziers' catches without any mitigation or  
    remorse of voice? Is there no respect of place, persons, nor
    time, in you?
  SIR TOBY.
 We did keep time, sir, in our catches.
 My lady bade me tell
    you that, though she harbours you as her kins-man, she's nothing
    allied to your disorders.
 [Sings] Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.

  MARIA.
 [Sings] But I will never die.
 [Sings] Sir Toby, there you lie.

  SIR TOBY.
 [Sings] What an if you do?
  SIR TOBY.
 [Sings] Shall I bid him go, and spare not?
  CLOWN.

    A stoup of wine, Maria!
  MALVOLIO.
 Go shake your ears.
 Do't, knight.

  SIR TOBY.
 Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of Puritan.
 What, for being a Puritan? Thy exquisite reason, dear
    knight?
  AGUECHEEK.
 I have no exquisite reason for't, but I have reason good
    enough.
 The devil a Puritan that he is, or anything constantly but a
    time-pleaser; an affection'd ass that cons state without book and
     utters it by great swarths; the best persuaded of himself, so
    cramm'd, as he thinks, with excellencies that it is his grounds
    of faith that all that look on him love him; and on that vice in
    him will my revenge find notable cause to work.

  SIR TOBY.
 I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of love;
    wherein, by the colour of his beard, the shape of his leg, the
    manner of his gait, the expressure of his eye, forehead, and
    complexion, he shall find himself most feelingly personated.
 Excellent! I smell a device.

  MARIA.
 And your horse now would make him an ass.
 O, 'twill be admirable!
  MARIA.

  SIR TOBY.
 Give me some music.

    Come, but one verse.

  DUKE.
 He is about the house.
 If ever thou shalt love,
    In the sweet pangs of it remember me;
    For such as I am all true lovers are,  
    Unstaid and skittish in all motions else
    Save in the constant image of the creature
    That is belov'd.
 I think it well, my lord.
 And so they are; alas, that they are so!
    To die, even when they to perfection grow!

                  Re-enter CURIO and CLOWN

  DUKE.

          My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,
                 O, prepare it!
          My part of death no one so true
                 Did share it.
 There's for thy pains.

  CLOWN.
 Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid one time or another.
 Give me now leave to leave thee.
 But if she cannot love you, sir?
  DUKE.

  DUKE.
 But died thy sister of her love, my boy?
  VIOLA.
 Ay, that's the theme.
 Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.

  FABIAN.

  SIR TOBY.
 Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascally
    sheep-biter come by some notable shame?
  FABIAN.
 And we do not, it is pity of our lives.
 Close, in the name of jesting! [As the men hide she drops
    a letter] Lie thou there; for here comes the trout that must be
    caught with tickling.

 Exit

                      Enter MALVOLIO

  MALVOLIO.

  MALVOLIO.

  AGUECHEEK.
 Having been three months married to her, sitting in my
    state-
  SIR TOBY.
 Bolts and shackles!
  FABIAN.
  
  MALVOLIO.
 Shall this fellow live?
  FABIAN.

  MALVOLIO.
 Out, scab!
  FABIAN.
 What employment have we here?  
                                          [Taking up the letter]
  FABIAN.

  AGUECHEEK.
 [Reads] 'To the unknown belov'd, this, and my good
    wishes.

    To whom should this be?
  FABIAN.
 This wins him, liver and all.

  MALVOLIO.
 [Reads]

                    Jove knows I love,
                      But who?
                    Lips, do not move;
                    No man must know.
 O.
 A.
'
    Nay, but first let me see, let me see, let me see.

  FABIAN.
 What dish o' poison has she dress'd him!
  SIR TOBY.
 And with what wing the staniel checks at it!
  MALVOLIO.
 A.
 I.
 M.
 I.
 Soft! here follows prose.

                                                         [Reads]
      'If this fall into thy hand, revolve.
 Some are born great, some  
    achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em.
 She thus advises thee that
    sighs for thee.
 I say, remember, Go to,
    thou art made, if thou desir'st to be so; if not, let me see thee
    a steward still, the fellow of servants, and not worthy to touch
    Fortune's fingers.
 I will be
    proud, I will read politic authors, I will baffle Sir Toby, I
    will wash off gross acquaintance, I will be point-devise the very
    man.
 If thou
    entertain'st my love, let it appear in thy smiling; thy smiles
    become thee well.
 I will smile; I will do everything that thou
    wilt have me.
 I could marry this wench for this device.

  AGUECHEEK.
 And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.
 If you will then see the fruits of the sport, mark his
    first approach before my lady.
 SCENE I.
 No, sir, I live by the church.

  VIOLA.
 You have said, sir.
 Nay, that's certain; they that dally nicely with words may
    quickly make them wanton.

  CLOWN.
 Not so, sir; I do care for something; but in my conscience,
    sir, I do not care for you.
 Art not thou the Lady Olivia's fool?
  CLOWN.

  VIOLA.
 I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.
  
    Hold, there's expenses for thee.
- Is thy lady
    within?
  CLOWN.
 Yes, being kept together and put to use.

  CLOWN.
 My lady is within, sir.
 I will construe to
    them whence you come; who you are and what you would are out of
    my welkin- I might say 'element' but the word is overworn.

  AGUECHEEK.
 Et vous aussi; votre serviteur.

  AGUECHEEK.
 I hope, sir, you are; and I am yours.

  VIOLA.
 I mean, to go, sir, to enter.
 My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant
    and vouchsafed car.

  AGUECHEEK.
 Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.

  OLIVIA.

  VIOLA.
 What might you think?
    Have you not set mine honour at the stake,  
    And baited it with all th' unmuzzled thoughts
    That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiving
    Enough is shown: a cypress, not a bosom,
    Hides my heart.

  VIOLA.
 I Pity YOU.

  OLIVIA.
 No, not a grize; for 'tis a vulgar proof
    That very oft we pity enemies.
 Would it be better, madam, than I am?
    I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

    And so adieu, good madam; never more
    Will I my master's tears to you deplore.
 'Slight! will you make an ass o' me?
  FABIAN.

  SIR TOBY.
 Go, write it in a martial hand; be curst and brief; it is
    no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention.

    Taunt him with the license of ink; if thou thou'st him some
    thrice, it shall not be amiss; and as many lies as will lie in  
    thy sheet of paper, although the sheet were big enough for the
    bed of Ware in England, set 'em down; go about it.
 Let there be
    gall enough in thy ink, though thou write with a goose-pen, no
    matter.

  AGUECHEEK.
 Where shall I find you?
  SIR TOBY.
 Never trust me then; and by all means stir on the youth
    to an answer.
 For Andrew, if he were open'd and you find so much
    blood in his liver as will clog the foot of a flea, I'll eat the
    rest of th' anatomy.
 And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no great
    presage of cruelty.
 Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.
 I have dogg'd him like his murderer.
         Exeunt




SCENE III.

A street

Enter SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO

  SEBASTIAN.

  ANTONIO.
 My willing love,
    The rather by these arguments of fear,
    Set forth in your pursuit.
 Would you'd pardon me.

  SEBASTIAN.

  ANTONIO.
 Do not then walk too open.
 I will bespeak our diet,
    Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge
    With viewing of the town; there shall you have me.
 Haply your eye shall light upon some toy
    You have desire to purchase; and your store,
    I think, is not for idle markets, sir.

  OLIVIA.
 Your ladyship were
    best to have some guard about you if he come; for sure the man is
    tainted in's wits.

  OLIVIA.
 Sweet lady, ho, ho.
 This does make some
    obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering; but what of that?
    If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true
    sonnet is: 'Please one and please all.
'
  OLIVIA.

    It did come to his hands, and commands shall be executed.
 Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?
  MALVOLIO.

  OLIVIA.
 God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so, and kiss thy hand
    so oft?
  MARIA.

  OLIVIA.
 Ha?
  MALVOLIO.
 Heaven restore thee!
  MALVOLIO.
 'Go to, thou an made, if thou desir'st to be so';-
  OLIVIA.
 Am I made?
  MALVOLIO.
 Why, this is very midsummer madness.
 I'll come to him.

                                         Exeunt OLIVIA and MARIA
  MALVOLIO.
 I have lim'd her; but it is
    Jove's doing, and Jove make me thankful! And when she went away
    now- 'Let this fellow be look'd to.

  FABIAN.
 How is't with you, man?
  MALVOLIO.
 Marry, and it shall be done to-morrow morning, if I live.
 My
    lady would not lose him for more than I'll say.
 How now, mistress!
  MARIA.
 Do you not
    see you move him? Let me alone with him.
 The fiend is rough,
    and will not be roughly us'd.
 Why, how now, my bawcock!
    How dost thou, chuck?
  MALVOLIO.
 What, man, 'tis not for gravity
    to play at cherrypit with Satan.
 Hang him, foul collier!
  MARIA.
 No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.

 Exit
  SIR TOBY.
 Is't possible?
  FABIAN.
 If this were play'd upon a stage now, I could condemn it as
    an improbable fiction.
 His very genius hath taken the infection of the device,
    man.

  MARIA.

  SIR TOBY.

  AGUECHEEK.
 I warrant there's vinegar
    and pepper in't.
 [Reads] 'Thou com'st to the Lady Olivia, and in my sight
    she uses thee kindly; but thou liest in thy throat; that is not
    the matter I challenge thee for.
'
  FABIAN.

  SIR TOBY.
 You may have very fit occasion for't; he is now in some
    commerce with my lady, and will by and by depart.
 But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by word of
    mouth, set upon Aguecheek notable report of valour, and drive the
    gentleman- as know his youth will aptly receive it- into a most
    hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity.
 Fare thee well;
    A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.
 Gentleman, God save thee.
 You'll find it otherwise, I assure you; therefore, if you
    hold your life at any price, betake you to your guard; for your
    opposite hath in him what youth, strength, skill, and wrath, can
    furnish man withal.
 Sir, no; his indignation derives itself out of a very
    competent injury; therefore, get you on and give him his desire.
 This is as uncivil as strange.
 Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman
    till my return.
 Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?
  FABIAN.
 I know the knight is incens'd against you, even to a mortal
    arbitrement; but nothing of the circumstance more.
 I beseech you, what manner of man is he?
  FABIAN.
 I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he
    gives me the stuck in with such a mortal motion that it is
    inevitable; and on the answer, he pays you as surely as your feet
    hit the ground they step on.
 Pox on't, I'll not meddle with him.
 I'll make the motion.
 Give ground if you see him furious.
 Come, Sir Andrew, there's no remedy; the gentleman will,
    for his honour's sake, have one bout with you; he cannot by the
    duello avoid it; but he has promis'd me, as he is a gentleman and  
    a soldier, he will not hurt you.
 If this young gentleman
    Have done offence, I take the fault on me:
    If you offend him, I for him defy you.

  SIR TOBY.
 One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more
    Than you have heard him brag to you he will.
  
  AGUECHEEK.

  FIRST OFFICER.

    Take him away; he knows I know him well.
 I Must obey.

    I hate ingratitude more in a man
    Than lying, vainness, babbling drunkenness,
    Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption
    Inhabits our frail blood.
 O heavens themselves!
  SECOND OFFICER.
 Let me speak a little.

    In nature there's no blemish but the mind:
    None can be call'd deform'd but the unkind.
 Methinks his words do from such passion fly
    That he believes himself; so do not I.
  
  VIOLA.
 He nam'd Sebastian.
 O, if it prove,
    Tempests are kind, and salt waves fresh in love!        Exit
  SIR TOBY.
 I dare lay any money 'twill be nothing yet.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.

Before OLIVIA'S house

Enter SEBASTIAN and CLOWN

  CLOWN.
 Well held out, i' faith! No, I do not know you; nor I am not
    sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her; nor your
    name is not Master Cesario; nor this is not my nose neither.

    Nothing that is so is so.

  CLOWN.
 Vent my folly! He has heard that word of some great man, and
    now applies it to a fool.
 I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me;
    There's money for thee; if you tarry longer
    I shall give worse payment.


             Enter SIR ANDREW, SIR TOBY, and FABIAN

  AGUECHEEK.

    Are all the people mad?
  SIR TOBY.

                                             [Holding SEBASTIAN]
  CLOWN.
 Nay, let him alone.
 What, what? Nay, then I must have an ounce or two of this
    malapert blood from you.
 Hold, Toby; on thy life, I charge thee hold.
 Well, I'll put it on, and I will dissemble myself in't; and
    I would I were the first that ever dissembled in such a gown.
 Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio the
    lunatic.
 Well said, Master Parson.
 Good Sir Topas, do
    not think I am mad; they have laid me here in hideous darkness.

  CLOWN.
 I say to you this house is dark.
 I say this house is as dark as ignorance, though
    ignorance were as dark as hell; and I say there was never man
    thus abus'd.

  CLOWN.

  MALVOLIO.

  MALVOLIO.
 Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my hand,
    help me to a candle, and pen, ink, and paper; as I am a
    gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee for't.

  CLOWN.
 Advise you what.
 Maintain no words with him, good fellow.
 God buy you, good Sir Topas.

    I tell thee I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.
 Good fool, some ink, paper, and
    light; and convey what I will set down to my lady.
 But tell me true, are you not mad
    indeed, or do you but counterfeit?
  MALVOLIO.
 Believe me, I am not; I tell thee true.

  CLOWN.
 Nay, I'll ne'er believe a madman till I see his brains.

    I will fetch you light and paper and ink.

    His counsel now might do me golden service;
    For though my soul disputes well with my sense
    That this may be some error, but no madness,
    Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune
    So far exceed all instance, all discourse,
    That I am ready to distrust mine eyes
    And wrangle with my reason, that persuades me
    To any other trust but that I am mad,
    Or else the lady's mad; yet if 'twere so,
    She could not sway her house, command her followers,  
    Take and give back affairs and their dispatch
    With such a smooth, discreet, and stable bearing,
    As I perceive she does.
 There's something in't
    That is deceivable.
 If you mean well,
    Now go with me and with this holy man
    Into the chantry by; there, before him
    And underneath that consecrated roof,
    Plight me the fun assurance of your faith,
    That my most jealous and too doubtful soul
    May live at peace.
 What do you say?
  SEBASTIAN.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.

  FABIAN.
 Do not desire to see this letter.
 Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?
  CLOWN.
 I know thee well.

  CLOWN.
 There's gold.

  CLOWN.

  DUKE.
 Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for this once, and let
    your flesh and blood obey it.
 Well, I will be so much a sinner to be a double-dealer.

  VIOLA.

  DUKE.

  VIOLA.
 How can this be?
  DUKE.
  

              Enter OLIVIA and ATTENDANTS

  DUKE.
 What would my lord, but that he may not have,
    Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
    Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.
 My lord would speak; my duty hushes me.

  OLIVIA.
 Still so constant, lord.
 And I, most jocund, apt, and willingly,  
    To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.
 Ay me, detested! How am I beguil'd!
  VIOLA.
 Husband?
  OLIVIA.
 Her husband, sirrah?
  VIOLA.

  PRIEST.
 O thou dissembling cub! What wilt thou be,  
    When time hath sow'd a grizzle on thy case?
    Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow
    That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow?
    Farewell, and take her; but direct thy feet
    Where thou and I henceforth may never meet.
 We took him for a
    coward, but he's the very devil incardinate.
 My gentleman, Cesario?
  AGUECHEEK.
 If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me; I think
    you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb.

  DUKE.
 Who hath made this havoc with them?
  AGUECHEEK.

  DUKE.
 Antonio, O my dear Antonio!  
    How have the hours rack'd and tortur'd me
    Since I have lost thee!
  ANTONIO.
 I had a sister
    Whom the blind waves and surges have devour'd.

  SEBASTIAN.
 And so had mine.
 And died that day when Viola from her birth
    Had numb'red thirteen years.
 If nothing lets to make us happy both
    But this my masculine usurp'd attire,
    Do not embrace me till each circumstance
    Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump
    That I am Viola; which to confirm,
    I'll bring you to a captain in this town,
    Where lie my maiden weeds; by whose gentle help
    I was preserv'd to serve this noble Count.


        Re-enter CLOWN, with a letter, and FABIAN

    A most extracting frenzy of mine own
    From my remembrance clearly banish'd his.
 Has here writ a letter to you; I
    should have given 't you to-day morning, but as a madman's
    epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are
    deliver'd.
 Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers the
    madman.
 No, madam, I do but read madness.
 Prithee read i' thy right wits.

  CLOWN.

  OLIVIA.

  FABIAN.

                                        THE MADLY-US'D MALVOLIO'

  OLIVIA.
 Did he write this?
  CLOWN.

  DUKE.
  
                                                     Exit FABIAN
    My lord, so please you, these things further thought on,
    To think me as well a sister as a wife,
    One day shall crown th' alliance on't, so please you,
    Here at my house, and at my proper cost.


                Re-enter FABIAN, with MALVOLIO

  DUKE.
 Madam, you have done me wrong,
    Notorious wrong.
 Well, grant it then,
    And tell me, in the modesty of honour,
    Why you have given me such clear lights of favour,
    Bade me come smiling and cross-garter'd to you,
    To put on yellow stockings, and to frown
    Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people;
    And, acting this in an obedient hope,
    Why have you suffer'd me to be imprison'd,
    Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest,
    And made the most notorious geck and gul
    That e'er invention play'd on? Tell me why.

    And now I do bethink me, it was she
    First told me thou wast mad; then cam'st in smiling,
    And in such forms which here were presuppos'd
    Upon thee in the letter.
 Maria writ
    The letter, at Sir Toby's great importance,
    In recompense whereof he hath married her.

    How with a sportful malice it was follow'd  
    May rather pluck on laughter than revenge,
    If that the injuries be justly weigh'd
    That have on both sides pass'd.
 He hath been most notoriously abus'd.

                                        Exeunt all but the CLOWN

                        CLOWN sings

           When that I was and a little tiny boy,
             With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,
           A foolish thing was but a toy,
             For the rain it raineth every day.


           But when I came, alas! to wive,
             With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,
           By swaggering could I never thrive,
             For the rain it raineth every day.


           A great while ago the world begun,
             With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,
           But that's all one, our play is done,
           And we'll strive to please you every day.
>>



1595

THE TWO GENTLEMEN OF VERONA

by William Shakespeare



DRAMATIS PERSONAE

  DUKE OF MILAN, father to Silvia
  VALENTINE, one of the two gentlemen
  PROTEUS,    "  "   "   "     "
  ANTONIO, father to Proteus
  THURIO, a foolish rival to Valentine
  EGLAMOUR, agent for Silvia in her escape
  SPEED, a clownish servant to Valentine
  LAUNCE, the like to Proteus
  PANTHINO, servant to Antonio
  HOST, where Julia lodges in Milan
  OUTLAWS, with Valentine

  JULIA, a lady of Verona, beloved of Proteus
  SILVIA, the Duke's daughter, beloved of Valentine
  LUCETTA, waiting-woman to Julia

  SERVANTS
  MUSICIANS




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.

Verona.
 Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adieu!
    Think on thy Proteus, when thou haply seest
    Some rare noteworthy object in thy travel.

  PROTEUS.
 Over the boots! Nay, give me not the boots.
 What?
  VALENTINE.

  PROTEUS.
  
    To Milan let me hear from thee by letters
    Of thy success in love, and what news else
    Betideth here in absence of thy friend;
    And I likewise will visit thee with mine.
 As much to you at home; and so farewell!
                                                  Exit VALENTINE
  PROTEUS.

  SPEED.

  SPEED.
 Therefore, thou art a
    sheep.
 Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.
 But what said she?
  SPEED.

  PROTEUS.
 Why, sir, how do you bear with me?
  SPEED.
 Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.

  PROTEUS.
 What said she? Nothing?
  SPEED.
' To testify  
    your bounty, I thank you, you have testern'd me; in requital
    whereof, henceforth carry your letters yourself; and so, sir,
    I'll commend you to my master.

  JULIA.
 Please you, repeat their names; I'll show my mind
    According to my shallow simple skill.

  JULIA.
 As of a knight well-spoken, neat, and fine;
    But, were I you, he never should be mine.
 Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?
  LUCETTA.
 Then thus: of many good I think him best.
 And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?
  LUCETTA.

  LUCETTA.
 Yet he, of all the rest, I think, best loves ye.

  JULIA.

  JULIA.
 O, they love least that let men know their love.

  JULIA.
 Peruse this paper, madam.
 'To Julia'- Say, from whom?
  LUCETTA.

  JULIA.
 Say, say, who gave it thee?  
  LUCETTA.
 Sir Valentine's page; and sent, I think, from Proteus.
 To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.
 Will ye be gone?
  LUCETTA.

    It were a shame to call her back again,
    And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.
 What would your ladyship?
  JULIA.

  JULIA.
 What is't that you took up so gingerly?
  LUCETTA.
 And is that paper nothing?
  LUCETTA.

  JULIA.
 As little by such toys as may be possible.

    Best sing it to the tune of 'Light o' Love.
'
  LUCETTA.
  
    And yet methinks I do not like this tune.
 No, madam; 'tis too sharp.
 The mean is drown'd with your unruly bass.

  LUCETTA.
 This babble shall not henceforth trouble me.

    But twice or thrice was 'Proteus' written down.
 I see you have a month's mind to them.

  LUCETTA.

Verona.
 Tell me, Panthino, what sad talk was that
    Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?
  PANTHINO.
 Nor need'st thou much importune me to that
    Whereon this month I have been hammering.

    Then tell me whither were I best to send him.

  PANTHINO.

  ANTONIO.

  PANTHINO.

  PROTEUS.
 My will is something sorted with his wish.

    I am resolv'd that thou shalt spend some time
    With Valentinus in the Emperor's court;
    What maintenance he from his friends receives,
    Like exhibition thou shalt have from me.
 Look what thou want'st shall be sent after thee.

    No more of stay; to-morrow thou must go.

    Come on, Panthino; you shall be employ'd
    To hasten on his expedition.

    O, how this spring of love resembleth
    The uncertain glory of an April day,
    Which now shows all the beauty of the sun,
    And by an by a cloud takes all away!

                       Re-enter PANTHINO

  PANTHINO.
 Why, this it is: my heart accords thereto;
    And yet a thousand times it answers 'No.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 How now, sirrah?
  SPEED.
 Well, you'll still be too forward.

  VALENTINE.
 Why, how know you that I am in love?
  SPEED.
 Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learn'd, like  
    Sir Proteus, to wreath your arms like a malcontent; to relish a
    love-song, like a robin redbreast; to walk alone, like one that
    had the pestilence; to sigh, like a school-boy that had lost his
    A B C; to weep, like a young wench that had buried her grandam;
    to fast, like one that takes diet; to watch, like one that fears
    robbing; to speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas.

  VALENTINE.

  SPEED.

  VALENTINE.

  SPEED.
 Sir, I know that well enough.

  VALENTINE.
 That she is not so fair as, of you, well-favour'd.

  SPEED.
 That's because the one is painted, and the other out of all
    count.
 Marry, sir, so painted, to make her fair, that no man counts
    of her beauty.
 I have lov'd her ever since I saw her, and still
    I see her beautiful.
 If you love her, you cannot see her.
 True, sir; I was in love with my bed.

  VALENTINE.
 Last night she enjoin'd me to write some lines to one  
    she loves.
 And have you?
  VALENTINE.
 Are they not lamely writ?
  VALENTINE.
 No, boy, but as well as I can do them.


                           Enter SILVIA

    Peace! here she comes.
 Madam and mistress, a thousand good morrows.
  [Aside]  O, give ye good ev'n!
    Here's a million of manners.

  SILVIA.
 No, madam; so it stead you, I will write,
    Please you command, a thousand times as much;
    And yet-
  SILVIA.

  SPEED.
  [Aside]  And yet you will; and yet another' yet.
 Madam, they are for you.

    And so good morrow, servant.
 What figure?  
  SPEED.
 Why, she hath not writ to me.
 What need she, when she hath made you write to yourself?
    Why, do you not perceive the jest?
  VALENTINE.

  SPEED.

  VALENTINE.
 That's the letter I writ to her friend.

  VALENTINE.
 I would it were no worse.

  VALENTINE.
 O, be not like your mistress! Be moved, be moved.

  JULIA.
 Why, then, we'll make exchange.
 And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.
 He is a stone, a very pebble
    stone, and has no more pity in him than a dog.
 Nay, I'll show you
    the manner of it.
 This
    shoe with the hole in it is my mother, and this my father.

    Now come I to my father: 'Father, your blessing.

  LAUNCE.
 Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the flood, and, in losing
    the flood, lose thy voyage, and, in losing thy voyage, lose thy
    master, and, in losing thy master, lose thy service, and, in
    losing thy service- Why dost thou stop my mouth?
  LAUNCE.
 For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.

  PANTHINO.
 Come, come away, man; I was sent to call thee.
                                Exeunt




SCENE IV.
                       Exit
  SILVIA.
 Haply I do.
 So do counterfeits.
 And how quote you my folly?
  VALENTINE.
 I quote it in your jerkin.
 You have said, sir.
 Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.
 I know it well, sir; you always end ere you begin.

  VALENTINE.
 'Tis indeed, madam; we thank the giver.

  SILVIA.
 Who is that, servant?
  VALENTINE.


                             Enter DUKE

  SILVIA.
  
  DUKE.
 You know him well?
  VALENTINE.
 Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good,
    He is as worthy for an empress' love
    As meet to be an emperor's counsellor.

    Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me
    With commendation from great potentates,
    And here he means to spend his time awhile.

    I will send him hither to you presently.
 Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.
              Exit THURIO

                         Enter PROTEUS  

  SILVIA.
 Have done, have done; here comes the gentleman.

  SILVIA.
 My duty will I boast of, nothing else.
 Come, Sir Thurio,
    Go with me.
 Your friends are well, and have them much commended.
 And how do yours?
  PROTEUS.
 Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter'd now;
    I have done penance for contemning Love,
    Whose high imperious thoughts have punish'd me
    With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,  
    With nightly tears, and daily heart-sore sighs;
    For, in revenge of my contempt of love,
    Love hath chas'd sleep from my enthralled eyes
    And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.

  PROTEUS.
 Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?
  PROTEUS.

  VALENTINE.

  PROTEUS.

  VALENTINE.

  VALENTINE.
 Sweet, except not any;
    Except thou wilt except against my love.

  PROTEUS.
 Then let her alone.
 Not for the world! Why, man, she is mine own;  
    And I as rich in having such a jewel
    As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl,
    The water nectar, and the rocks pure gold.

  VALENTINE.

    How shall I dote on her with more advice
    That thus without advice begin to love her!  
    'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld,
    And that hath dazzled my reason's light;
    But when I look on her perfections,
    There is no reason but I shall be blind.
 Marry, after they clos'd in earnest, they parted very
    fairly in jest.
 What, are they broken?
  LAUNCE.
  
  SPEED.
 What a block art thou that thou canst not! My staff
    understands me.

  SPEED.
 But tell me true, will't be a match?
  LAUNCE.
 If he say ay, it will; if he say no, it will;
    if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.

  LAUNCE.
 To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn;
    To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn;
    To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn;
    And ev'n that pow'r which gave me first my oath
    Provokes me to this threefold perjury:
    Love bade me swear, and Love bids me forswear.

    I will forget that Julia is alive,
    Rememb'ring that my love to her is dead;
    And Valentine I'll hold an enemy,
    Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.
 JULIA'S house

Enter JULIA and LUCETTA

  JULIA.
 Alas, the way is wearisome and long!
  JULIA.
 A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary
    To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps;
    Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly,
    And when the flight is made to one so dear,
    Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.
  
    Didst thou but know the inly touch of love.
 The more thou dam'st it up, the more it burns.

    Then let me go, and hinder not my course.
 Out, out, Lucetta, that will be ill-favour'd.

  LUCETTA.

  LUCETTA.
 That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear:
    A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears,
    And instances of infinite of love,
    Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.
 Pray heav'n he prove so when you come to him.

  JULIA.
 Now, as thou lov'st me, do him not that wrong
    To bear a hard opinion of his truth;
    Only deserve my love by loving him.
 SCENE I.
            Exit THURIO
    Now tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?
  PROTEUS.
 My gracious lord, that which I would discover
    The law of friendship bids me to conceal;
    But, when I call to mind your gracious favours
    Done to me, undeserving as I am,
    My duty pricks me on to utter that
    Which else no worldly good should draw from me.

    This love of theirs myself have often seen,
    Haply when they have judg'd me fast asleep,
    And oftentimes have purpos'd to forbid
    Sir Valentine her company and my court;
    But, fearing lest my jealous aim might err
    And so, unworthily, disgrace the man,
    A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd,
    I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find
    That which thyself hast now disclos'd to me.
         Exit

                        Enter VALENTINE

  DUKE.
 Be they of much import?
  VALENTINE.

  VALENTINE.
 What would your Grace have me to do in this?
  DUKE.
 There is a lady, in Verona here,
    Whom I affect; but she is nice, and coy,
    And nought esteems my aged eloquence.
 Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:
    Dumb jewels often in their silent kind
    More than quick words do move a woman's mind.

  DUKE.
 But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

  VALENTINE.

    If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you,
    But rather to beget more love in you;
    If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone,
    For why, the fools are mad if left alone.

    Take no repulse, whatever she doth say;
    For 'Get you gone' she doth not mean 'Away!'
    Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces;
    Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces.

  VALENTINE.
 Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe,
    That no man hath recourse to her by night.

  DUKE.
 But, hark thee; I will go to her alone;
    How shall I best convey the ladder thither?
  VALENTINE.

  DUKE.
'
    'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose.
    Exit
  VALENTINE.
  
    What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?
    What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by?
    Unless it be to think that she is by,
    And feed upon the shadow of perfection.

    I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:
    Tarry I here, I but attend on death;
    But fly I hence, I fly away from life.

  LAUNCE.
 Valentine?
  VALENTINE.
 No.
 Who then? his spirit?
  VALENTINE.
 Who wouldst thou strike?
  LAUNCE.
  
  VALENTINE.
 No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia.

  VALENTINE.

    What is your news?
  LAUNCE.
 Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

  PROTEUS.
 No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st
    Have some malignant power upon my life:
    If so, I pray thee breathe it in mine ear,
    As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

    Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that,
    And manage it against despairing thoughts.
 She hath more qualities than a
    water-spaniel- which is much in a bare Christian.
' Why, a horse can do no more; nay, a horse
    cannot fetch, but only carry; therefore is she better than a
    jade.


                             Enter SPEED

  SPEED.
 How now, Signior Launce! What news with your mastership?
  LAUNCE.
 Well, your old vice still: mistake the word.
 The black'st news that ever thou heard'st.
 Marry, the son of my grandfather.
 It was the son of thy grandmother.
 'Item: She brews good ale.
'
  LAUNCE.

  SPEED.
 'Item: She can sew.
 'Item: She can spin.

  SPEED.
 'Here follow her vices.
 'Item: She is not to be kiss'd fasting, in respect of her
    breath.
 'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.
 That makes amends for her sour breath.

  SPEED.
 'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.
 'Item: She is slow in words.
'
  LAUNCE.
 O villain, that set this down among her vices! To be slow
    in words is a woman's only virtue.

  SPEED.
 Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy, and cannot be ta'en  
    from her.
'
  LAUNCE.
'
  LAUNCE.

  SPEED.
 More hair than wit.
 For me?
  LAUNCE.
 For thee! ay, who art thou? He hath stay'd for a better man
    than thee.

  SPEED.
 And must I go to him?
  LAUNCE.
 Why didst not tell me sooner? Pox of your love letters!
 Exit
  LAUNCE.
                        Exit




SCENE II.

  PROTEUS.

  DUKE.

    What might we do to make the girl forget
    The love of Valentine, and love Sir Thurio?
  PROTEUS.
 The best way is to slander Valentine
    With falsehood, cowardice, and poor descent-
    Three things that women highly hold in hate.
  
  PROTEUS.
 Ay, if his enemy deliver it;
    Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken
    By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.
 And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind,
    Because we know, on Valentine's report,
    You are already Love's firm votary
    And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.

  PROTEUS.

    After your dire-lamenting elegies,
    Visit by night your lady's chamber window
    With some sweet consort; to their instruments
    Tune a deploring dump- the night's dead silence
    Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.
 This discipline shows thou hast been in love.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
 SCENE I.
 Fellows, stand fast; I see a passenger.

  SPEED.
 That's not so, sir; we are your enemies.
 Peace! we'll hear him.

  THIRD OUTLAW.

  VALENTINE.
 Whither travel you?
  VALENTINE.
 Whence came you?
  VALENTINE.
 From Milan.
 Some sixteen months, and longer might have stay'd,
    If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.
 What, were you banish'd thence?
  VALENTINE.

  THIRD OUTLAW.

  SPEED.
 Peace, villain!
  SECOND OUTLAW.
 And I from Mantua, for a gentleman
    Who, in my mood, I stabb'd unto the heart.

    We'll do thee homage, and be rul'd by thee,
    Love thee as our commander and our king.

  THIRD OUTLAW.
 No, we detest such vile base practices.


                 Enter THURIO and MUSICIANS  

    But here comes Thurio.
 Ay, Silvia- for your sake.
 Now, my young guest, methinks you're allycholly; I pray you,
    why is it?
  JULIA.
 Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.
 Is he among these?
  HOST.
 Ay; but peace! let's hear 'em.

  
         Then to Silvia let us sing
           That Silvia is excelling;
         She excels each mortal thing
           Upon the dull earth dwelling.
 How, out of tune on the strings?
  JULIA.
 You have a quick ear.

  JULIA.
 What's your will?
  PROTEUS.
 That I may compass yours.
 You have your wish; my will is even this,
    That presently you hie you home to bed.

    For me, by this pale queen of night I swear,
    I am so far from granting thy request
    That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit,
    And by and by intend to chide myself
    Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.

  JULIA.

  SILVIA.

  JULIA.

  PROTEUS.

  SILVIA.
 As wretches have o'ernight
    That wait for execution in the morn.
 Host, will you go?
  HOST.
 By my halidom, I was fast asleep.

  JULIA.
 Pray you, where lies Sir Proteus?
  HOST.
 Trust me, I think 'tis almost day.
 Not so; but it hath been the longest night
    That e'er I watch'd, and the most heaviest.

Under SILVIA'S window

Enter EGLAMOUR

  EGLAMOUR.
 This is the hour that Madam Silvia
    Entreated me to call and know her mind;
    There's some great matter she'd employ me in.

  SILVIA.

  EGLAMOUR.

  EGLAMOUR.
 I have taught him, even as one would say
    precisely 'Thus I would teach a dog.
 If I had not had more wit than he, to
    take a fault upon me that he did, I think verily he had been
    hang'd for't; sure as I live, he had suffer'd for't.
 You shall
    judge.
 'Out with the dog' says one; 'What cur is that?' says  
    another; 'Whip him out' says the third; 'Hang him up' says the
    Duke.
 I, having been acquainted with the smell before, knew it
    was Crab, and goes me to the fellow that whips the dogs.
' He makes me no more ado, but whips me out of
    the chamber.
 Did not I bid
    thee still mark me and do as I do? When didst thou see me heave
    up my leg and make water against a gentlewoman's farthingale?
    Didst thou ever see me do such a trick?

               Enter PROTEUS, and JULIA in boy's clothes

  PROTEUS.
 Sebastian is thy name? I like thee well,
    And will employ thee in some service presently.
  [To LAUNCE]  How now, you whoreson
      peasant!
    Where have you been these two days loitering?
  LAUNCE.
 And what says she to my little jewel?
  LAUNCE.

  PROTEUS.
 No, indeed, did she not; here have I brought him back
    again.

    Go presently, and take this ring with thee,
    Deliver it to Madam Silvia-
    She lov'd me well deliver'd it to me.

  JULIA.

  JULIA.
 Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?
  JULIA.


                     Enter SILVIA, attended

    Gentlewoman, good day! I pray you be my mean
    To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.
 If you be she, I do entreat your patience
    To hear me speak the message I am sent on.
 Madam, please you peruse this letter.

    Pardon me, madam; I have unadvis'd
    Deliver'd you a paper that I should not.

  SILVIA.
 I pray thee let me look on that again.

  JULIA.

  SILVIA.
 There, hold!
    I will not look upon your master's lines.
 Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

  SILVIA.

    Though his false finger have profan'd the ring,  
    Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.

  JULIA.
 What say'st thou?
  JULIA.
 I think she doth, and that's her cause of sorrow.
 Is she not passing fair?
  JULIA.

    Madam, 'twas Ariadne passioning
    For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight;
    Which I so lively acted with my tears
    That my poor mistress, moved therewithal,
    Wept bitterly; and would I might be dead
    If I in thought felt not her very sorrow.
                        Exit SILVIA with ATTENDANTS
  JULIA.

    What should it be that he respects in her
    But I can make respective in myself,
    If this fond Love were not a blinded god?  
    Come, shadow, come, and take this shadow up,
    For 'tis thy rival.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
>>



ACT V.

    She will not fail, for lovers break not hours
    Unless it be to come before their time,
    So much they spur their expedition.
 Lady, a happy evening!
  SILVIA.

  EGLAMOUR.
 Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?
  PROTEUS.

  THURIO.
 I'll wear a boot to make it somewhat rounder.
 She says it is a fair one.

  PROTEUS.

  THURIO.
 But well when I discourse of love and peace?  
  JULIA.

  THURIO.

  JULIA.
  [Aside]  She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.
 Neither.

  DUKE.
 And I will follow, more to cross that love
    Than hate for Silvia, that is gone for love.
 Come, come.

  SILVIA.

  FIRST OUTLAW.

Another part of the forest

Enter VALENTINE

  VALENTINE.

    What halloing and what stir is this to-day?
    These are my mates, that make their wills their law,
    Have some unhappy passenger in chase.

  VALENTINE.

  PROTEUS.
 What dangerous action, stood it next to death,
    Would I not undergo for one calm look?
    O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approv'd,
    When women cannot love where they're belov'd!
  SILVIA.

    Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!  
  PROTEUS.
 In love,
    Who respects friend?
  SILVIA.

  SILVIA.

  VALENTINE.
 Valentine!
  VALENTINE.

  VALENTINE.

    And, that my love may appear plain and free,
    All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.
 O me unhappy!                                  [Swoons]
  PROTEUS.
 O good sir, my master charg'd me to deliver a ring to Madam  
    Silvia, which, out of my neglect, was never done.
 But how cam'st thou by this ring?
    At my depart I gave this unto Julia.

    It is the lesser blot, modesty finds,
    Women to change their shapes than men their minds.
 Than men their minds! 'tis true.
 O heaven, were man
    But constant, he were perfect! That one error
    Fills him with faults; makes him run through all th' sins:
    Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.

    What is in Silvia's face but I may spy
    More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?
  VALENTINE.

    Let me be blest to make this happy close;
    'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.
 A prize, a prize, a prize!
  VALENTINE.

    I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

  VALENTINE.

    I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake,
    To grant one boon that I shall ask of you.
 Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them, and thee;
    Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.

  VALENTINE.
 And, as we walk along, I dare be bold
    With our discourse to make your Grace to smile.

    Come, Proteus, 'tis your penance but to hear
    The story of your loves discovered.
 The palace of LEONTES

Enter CAMILLO and ARCHIDAMUS

  ARCHIDAMUS.
 I think this coming summer the King of Sicilia means to
    pay Bohemia the visitation which he justly owes him.
 Beseech you-
  ARCHIDAMUS.
 Verily, I speak it in the freedom of my knowledge: we
    cannot with such magnificence, in so rare- I know not what to
    say.
 Believe me, I speak as my understanding instructs me
    and as mine honesty puts it to utterance.

  CAMILLO.
 I very well agree with you in the hopes of him.

  ARCHIDAMUS.
 If the King had no son, they would desire to live on
    crutches till he had one.
 The palace of LEONTES

Enter LEONTES, POLIXENES, HERMIONE, MAMILLIUS, CAMILLO, and ATTENDANTS

  POLIXENES.

  POLIXENES.
 We'll part the time between's then; and in that
    I'll no gainsaying.

  POLIXENES.

  LEONTES.
 I had thought, sir, to have held my peace until
    You had drawn oaths from him not to stay.
 Tell him you are sure
    All in Bohemia's well- this satisfaction
    The by-gone day proclaim'd.

  LEONTES.
- You'll stay?
  POLIXENES.
 Nay, but you will?
  POLIXENES.
 Your guest, then, madam:
    To be your prisoner should import offending;
    Which is for me less easy to commit
    Than you to punish.
 Had we pursu'd that life,
    And our weak spirits ne'er been higher rear'd
    With stronger blood, we should have answer'd heaven
    Boldly 'Not guilty,' the imposition clear'd
    Hereditary ours.

  HERMIONE.
 By this we gather
    You have tripp'd since.
 Grace to boot!
    Of this make no conclusion, lest you say
    Your queen and I are devils.
 Yet, go on;
    Th' offences we have made you do we'll answer,
    If you first sinn'd with us, and that with us
    You did continue fault, and that you slipp'd not
    With any but with us.

  LEONTES.
 He'll stay, my lord.
 At my request he would not.
 But to th' goal:
    My last good deed was to entreat his stay;
    What was my first? It has an elder sister,
    Or I mistake you.
 'Tis Grace indeed.
  [Aside]  Too hot, too hot!
    To mingle friendship far is mingling bloods.
 But were they false
    As o'er-dy'd blacks, as wind, as waters- false
    As dice are to be wish'd by one that fixes
    No bourn 'twixt his and mine; yet were it true
    To say this boy were like me.
 Then 'tis very credent
    Thou mayst co-join with something; and thou dost-
    And that beyond commission; and I find it,
    And that to the infection of my brains
    And hard'ning of my brows.
 He something seems unsettled.
 How, my lord!
    What cheer? How is't with you, best brother?
  HERMIONE.
 You look
    As if you held a brow of much distraction.
 Mine honest friend,
    Will you take eggs for money?
  MAMILLIUS.

  LEONTES.

  HERMIONE.
 To your own bents dispose you; you'll be found,
    Be you beneath the sky.
 Be it concluded,
    No barricado for a belly.
 How now, boy!
  MAMILLIUS.
 I am like you, they say.
 Why, that's some comfort.
' 'Tis far gone
    When I shall gust it last.
 At the good Queen's entreaty.
 Business, my lord? I think most understand
    Bohemia stays here longer.
 Ay, but why?
  CAMILLO.
 Satisfy
    Th' entreaties of your mistress! Satisfy!
    Let that suffice.
 My gracious lord,
    I may be negligent, foolish, and fearful:
    In every one of these no man is free
    But that his negligence, his folly, fear,
    Among the infinite doings of the world,
    Sometime puts forth.
 These, my lord,
    Are such allow'd infirmities that honesty
    Is never free of.
 Say it be, 'tis true.

  LEONTES.

    I say thou liest, Camillo, and I hate thee;
    Pronounce thee a gross lout, a mindless slave,
    Or else a hovering temporizer that  
    Canst with thine eyes at once see good and evil,
    Inclining to them both.
 Ay, and thou,
    His cupbearer- whom I from meaner form
    Have bench'd and rear'd to worship; who mayst see,
    Plainly as heaven sees earth and earth sees heaven,
    How I am gall'd- mightst bespice a cup
    To give mine enemy a lasting wink;
    Which draught to me were cordial.

    I do; and will fetch off Bohemia for't;
    Provided that, when he's remov'd, your Highness
    Will take again your queen as yours at first,
    Even for your son's sake; and thereby for sealing
    The injury of tongues in courts and kingdoms  
    Known and allied to yours.

  LEONTES.

  LEONTES.
 To do this deed,
    Promotion follows.
 Happy star reign now!
    Here comes Bohemia.
 Not speak?
    Good day, Camillo.

  POLIXENES.
 A sickness caught of me, and yet I well?
    I must be answer'd.
 By the King.
 I know not; but I am sure 'tis safer to
